- Drop in or new students, please get in contact before the start of class to let us know you are interested so we can assess your level and organise a private class if necessary to catch you up. If you just show up on the night, you are welcome to watch the class but will not be able to join in (this is to respect the learning of our regular students as the classes are progressive)
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
CIVIC: Workshops & Open Cypher, Shifting Centre presents CIVIC: Workshops & Open Community Cypher.
Bringing you knowledgable Street-Dance facilitators that will provide high quality and valuable insight into Krump, Waacking, Choreography & the Cypher. A safe and fun space for dancers and non-dancers to delve into the rich craft of Street-Dance (and its sub-genres).
***Please read carefully through the details below to ensure you book a single pass for the correct workshop. If you select ALL WORKSHOP PASS, you are automatically registered for all 3 workshops***
TUESDAY 4th NOVEMBER:
Savvy.B (Krump Foundations) @ 6:00PM - 7:30PM
"Mani Tuaga aka Savvy.B | Mr. Powerpuff | Savage Street Beast | Twin $A’B is a movement artist who specialises in the street style of Krump. With over 9 years of experience across Oceania, he bases his successes on staying true to his style, movement and authentic self. Savvy.B remains future focused on longevity so he can serve the dance community by sharing knowledge handed down from some of the greatest Krumpers known both nationally and abroad."
Open Jamz (Choreography) @ 7:30PM - 9:00PM
“Openjamz is a collective born from friendship, held together by movement, and opened wide for anyone who wants to step inside.
It is a home more than a studio — a place where we teach each other, learn from each other, and let the music guide us.
Here, classes are not just lessons, they are exchanges. Jams are not just sessions, they are conversations”
WEDNESDAY 5th NOVEMBER:
Nay Nay (Waacking Choreography) @ 6:00PM - 7:15PM
“E noho ana au ki te Whanganui a Tara engari nō Tāmaki Makaurau ki te Tonga me Kirikiriroa ahau
He kaikanikani au nō Projekt Team me Two and a Half Brownies hoki
He uri ahau nō Ngāti Ranginui 
Ko Renee tōku ingoa
Tēnā tātou e te whānau. I have had the privilege to dance for over 15 years starting in the choreography scene with my first crew Hopskotch and in the NZ battle scene. Dance became more than just a skill set or a way to perform - it became a gateway to community, to service, to traveling to countries I never thought I'd see, a way to connect and a way to express. I am honoured to impart my experiences in my journey with yours. Mauri ora.”
OPEN COMMUNITY CYPHER (Facilitated by Shifting Centre) @ 7:30PM - 9:30PM
The Cypher is a practice of discovery and navigation. It is held with love and care, and is built for dancers to freely decipher their emotions, dreams, discoveries and more. A safe space for dancers, artists and humans looking for a space to connect. Open for all and FREE of charge.
LOCATION: Tapere Nui, Te Auaha (65 Dixon Street, Te Aro, Wellington).
PRICE: $15 per workshop or $35 for all three / Cypher is FREE of charge (only registrations needed).
*Booking fees apply to all tickets*
Shifting Centre are a Tangata Whenua & Tangata Moana artist collective and we acknowledge that we stand, live, create and exist on the unceded lands of Indigenous Māori. We acknowledge Te Ati Awa & Ngāti Toa as the Mana Whenua of Pōneke.

description:
Cake Decorating Workshop, Description
Cale Decorating Workshop

Join cake expert, Lina, for a hands-on cake building and decorating workshop where creativity meets craftsmanship!

With over 20 years of experience in the culinary and hospitality industries - from managing restaurants across Europe and Asia to running her own cake design business - Lina brings not only technical expertise, but also a genuine passion for sharing the joy of decorating.

Known for her friendly, engaging style and eye for detail, Lina will guide you through each step of the process - from building cakes and decorating including palette knife and gum-paste techniques, to using buttercream and creating a centrepiece.

Whether you're a complete beginner or simply want to sharpen your decorating skills, you'll leave with new techniques, confidence, and of course, your own edible masterpiece.

Let’s make something beautiful - and delicious - together!

You will leave with a tall 6” decorated cake in its own cake box to take home and enjoy. All ingredients included in course fee - just bring an apron and a couple of teatowels.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Calligratherapy - Beginners, Calligratherapy combines science journalist James Nestor's theory on proper breathing with the philosophy of ancient Chinese calligraphy to promote a state of optimal wellbeing. Over five weeks, you will develop and practice the awareness of healthy breathing while learning new techniques of Chinese soft brush calligraphy covering five different scripts.

Description
Many of us live sedentary lifestyles, sitting for up to eight hours or more a day hunched over our keyboard - all the while rarely taking a proper breath! Even if we wanted to take a deep enriching breath into the lower lobes of our lungs, we are limited due to our posture. Often due to the stresses and strains of a busy work and life balance, our unconscious brain can develop a pattern of holding, irregular and shadow breaths.

Does this sound like your experience?

Not being able to breathe properly is the key cause of many chronic respiratory diseases (Nestor, 2020)

Calligratherapy combines science journalist James Nestor's theory on proper breathing with the philosophy of ancient Chinese calligraphy to promote a state of optimal wellbeing.

Calligratherapy has been developed specifically for those who have never practiced calligraphy before and who are interested in deriving the benefits without having to learn the language or all the characters. It integrates the simple and intuitive act of inhaling and exhaling into calligraphy practice with Eastern philosophy behind it.

A range of different breathing exercises are embedded into each 90-minute session focusing on different calligraphy scripts. Over the five weeks, you will develop and practice the awareness of healthy breathing, while learning new techniques of Chinese soft brush calligraphy covering five different scripts.

All materials included in course fee.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Start a new creative practice in Chinese soft brush calligraphy
Develop your own mindfulness strategy
Better manage everyday stress levels and access a calm, empowered and positive state of mind
Find ways to explore eastern philosophy and develop deeper connections with your spiritual self.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".


Duration 5 weeks, Thu 5:30 PM – 7:00 PM
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Chain Maille Course, Our medieval materials expert Achille is ready to be your chain maille master. In this seven class course you will hone in on the chain weaves that incite awe and be bestowed with the agency to create a wearable piece or majestic object of your own design. On the mysterious journey towards mastery, Achille will take you through everything from the dexterity of proper ring closing, to practicing resolve through the depths of theory and mathematics that allow you to design and execute a piece of your very own creation. This is the perfect course to begin your foray into the craft of chain maille.

This course it taught by medieval enthusiast Achille. He is a creature of curiosity and crepes, having spent the last 14 years skulking around the capital publishing “woke leftist paper” as a founder of 5ever books. He has conquered our hearts, minds, and the specialty cheese departments of the local supermarkets. Achille is a master of chain maille, now offering to teach his craft to those willing to take up the challenge.

Some materials and tools are supplied. Depending on the project you choose to create there may be extra material costs, as well as the option to purchase tools for personal use. You are welcome to bring your own bent nose pliers and wire cutters if you have them.

There are variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances! Note that this ticket is a commitment to the entire seven week course. No chain maille experience is required, just a will to delve into the depths of metal weaves. If you're unsure about committing to this craft, perhaps keep an eye out for a one off 101 chain maille class that may come in the future.

Course Outline:
Week 01 - 18th September
101: Basic Skills and Discovery
At this class we'll explore the basics of good chain maille practice.
Opening & closing rings properly
Trying out some simple structures
Begin exploring material options and how to make your own rings
Homework: keep an eye out for recycled or foraged materials that could be utilised in chain maille

Week 02 - 25th September
Play and Exploration
Gathering inspiration and looking into methods for individual projects
Playing with recycled & foraged materials
Homework: Choose a weave from the library to try out at home or explore during the next class

Week 03 - 2nd October
Mathematics of chain maille design, theory, and history.
Math of designing chain maille
Theory & pre-planning
Discussion about ideas for individual projects
Identify materials needed to execute individual designs
Homework: Choose your individual project, identify what materials you will need, and how we will source/make them.

Week 04 - 16th October
By this class you will have you project plan down. We'll be collecting/ making our materials or beginning the execution of our projects with the guidance of Achille.

Week 05 & 06 - 23rd & 30th October
These classes will be open working times to make use of tools in class, ask Achille questions or help with troubleshooting, and to share our progress, challenges, and solutions with each other.

Week 07 - 6th November
At this final class we will make finishing touches to our projects and celebrate our creations together! Perhaps including a catwalk of our chain maille wares, and sharing kai.

description:
Cheers Dad! Pottery, Paint & a Pint!, We're excited to bring you a Father's Day pottery painting event in collaboration with the finest brewery on the coast, Duncan's!

Come along for an afternoon creative session of painting a piece of pottery for Dad - or with Dad, whilst sipping on your choice of brew. This is your opportunity to get sorted for Father's Day (Father's Day NZ is Sun 7th September).

Book a ticket for yourself, your family and your dad, enjoy a creative session altogether, each turning a mug or tumbler into work of Picasso. No family dramas just a fun old time.

If Dad can't make it, make him a custom gift. Bring along your partner or your beer loving bestie!

You will be guided through the process of painting (let's get our facts straight its actually underglaze not paint!) your Mug/Tumbler. Dad will treasure his custom made piece or you could make matching family mugs!

All materials supplied. 
This Pottery painting workshop is absolutely suitable for anyone...even the least creative people!

Ticket price includes:
Your own ceramic Mug/Tumbler ready for decorating 
One Beverage (Beer or non alcoholic)
All the materials needed
Guidance from me to create a piece Dad will treasure forever
1 Kiln firing ~ this makes the piece strong, shiny and food and drink safe

Please note: Your piece will be carefully taken back to my studio and glazed with a clear glaze, this will not only make it look profesh but will make it safe to use everyday.  You can then collect your finished piece from Duncan's the following Friday (05.09)

Disclaimer:

I will take every care with your finished piece but I can not be held responsible for cracks or glaze issues once fired...I'm afraid we put our trust in the kiln gods.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Chess - Learn to Play, Chess – Learn to Play
Starting from the beginning you will discover how to play the 3000-year-old game of Chess. You will learn the principles that guide decision making in all parts of the game, learn algebraic notation and the ability to not only play a game anywhere, anytime, but also knowledge of where and how to play - both online and in person.

Description
Chess is an ancient game of strategy and analysis that hones concentration and focus, as you master the skills allowing you to win at this competitive recreation.

Join tutor, Ryan Hill to learn how to play this game from the beginning.

You will quickly go from understanding the basics to being able to engage in playing confidently and discover where to go for further training or to carry on playing – both in person and online.

Over 600 million people play this game that has remained popular throughout the ages – why don’t you become one of them!

Bring pen and paper to take notes.

By the end of this course you will be able to:

*Be able to use all of the chess pieces to play the game
*Be able to recount and use some of the most common openings and traps
*Recognise where to go for further training or to play
*Develop increasing levels of confidence in your ability to play and possibly win

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Clay Creations: Incense Holders, Clay Creations: Incense Holders
Settle in for a cosy evening of creativity, good company, and delicious food.
In this hands-on workshop, everyone will be guided step-by-step to make their own incense holder from air-dry clay — no pottery wheel or kiln needed. The design inspiration for the night will be a dreamy moon-and-stars theme, but there’s plenty of room for personal flair. Those who love to freestyle can create their own unique style, while those who prefer a little direction can simply follow along and enjoy the process.
It’s an easy-going, beginner-friendly space where conversations flow, laughter is encouraged, and there’s something grounding about feeling clay in your hands. It’s a chance to step away from the usual routine, relax into a slower pace, and take joy in making something from scratch.
After the crafting is done, the evening continues with a beautiful plant-based dinner and dessert shared together — wholesome food to round out a wholesome night. Everyone will head home with their own handmade incense holder, a full belly, and that cozy, satisfied feeling that comes from a night spent creating and connecting.

description:
Community Comms Collective workshop for NFPs: Social marketing essentials - communications that create change, How can we change or maintain people’s behaviour through marketing, and truly benefit the communities we serve?
This hands-on workshop will demonstrate how you can create behaviour change through social marketing. You’ll learn the basics of behaviour change marketing and communications, including best practice approaches to achieve behaviour change for social good outcomes.
Learn tools, tips, and strategies to help you:
·      Develop programmes or services that influence the communities you serve
·      Target resources effectively and choose tactics that have impact
·      Create communications and marketing campaigns that resonate
We are thrilled to have communications expert and social entrepreneur Tracey Bridges lead this workshop. She is a co-founder and director of The Good Registry, a social enterprise that directs consumer spending on gifts towards good causes. Tracey has significant governance experience in the not-for-profit space, including Whānau Āwhina Plunket and the WELLfed Charitable Trust, and is a fellow Public Relations Institute of New Zealand.
Tracey's insights are drawn from international and local practice, and a long career in behaviour change in social marketing, working on projects, including It’s Not OK, Sorted, Like Minds, Like Mine and many more.
Workshop presenter: Tracey Bridges
For out of towners or those who can’t make it on the day, this workshop will be recorded and shared on our website after the event, along with our other resources.
This is a free Community Comms Collective workshop for not-for-profits and collective volunteers hosted by Volunteer Wellington and supported by JacksonStone & Partners. We are grateful for their support and for our speaker for giving their time and talent pro bono.
Koha welcome to help cover venue hire.
St John’s in the City conference room is wheelchair accessible – please contact the Church Office with any queries https://www.stjohnsinthecity.org.nz/contact-us
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Contact Improvisation with Eliza Sanders & Footnote Dance, Contact Improvisation with Eliza Sanders & Footnote Dance
Five-Day Intensive Workshop with Eliza Sanders

About this Event

This intensive week offers a rare opportunity to dive deep into the practical tools and nuanced territories of Contact Improvisation. Fresh from three weeks of intensive CI training in Thailand, Eliza returns with new wisdom and embodied understanding to share with our community.

A Unique Learning Community
This workshop brings together an extraordinary learning environment where Footnote's four full-time dancers will practice alongside independent dancers and community participants, creating a rich exchange of distinct yet equally valuable body wisdoms. Together, we'll explore the multilayered practice of Contact Improvisation in its depth and complexity.

The Journey: Progressive Deepening Throughout the Week
Through structured explorations and guided improvisation, we'll delve into the physical practice while also discovering the connections between how we move together and how we navigate life with greater ease and joy. As is Eliza’s style, we'll explore both the practical tools of the craft and uncover how this embodied practice offers insights for moving through the world with more presence and connection.
We'll venture into advanced techniques and principles of Contact Improvisation. Each day will build organically on the last, allowing for genuine integration and discovery. The specific focus will evolve from the insights and practices Eliza brings back from the Inspiral intensive in Thailand.



Who This Workshop Is For
This intensive creates magic precisely because it brings together diverse perspectives and experience levels. We welcome:
Graduates of Contact Improvisation foundations workshops ready to deepen their practice
Experienced movers curious about the broader applications of CI principles
Proffesional dancers eager to nuance and expand their practice
Community dancers eager to learn alongside professional practitioners
Anyone interested in exploring movement as a pathway to more effective communication and compassionate action
Those drawn to embodied practices for personal and social transformation
Prior Contact Improvisation experience recommended but not essential—our kaupapa embraces the wisdom that emerges when professional and community dancers share the learning space.

Practical Details
When: Monday - Friday, October 13-17, 2025 Time: 9am - 5pm daily Where: Footnote Dance Studios Capacity: Maximum 10 participants (alongside our 4 Footnote dancers) What to Bring: Comfortable clothes for dancing, long sleeves and socks recommended Included: Tea and snacks throughout each day (lunch not included)

Investment
Early Bird: $300 (until September 12th) Regular Price: $350

About Your Facilitator
Eliza brings years of dedicated Contact Improvisation practice and teaching, known for creating environments where technical skill development and personal discovery flourish together. Her recent intensive training in Thailand with internationally renowned teachers adds fresh depth to her already rich understanding of CI as both movement practice and life practice. Former participants consistently highlight her ability to create space where everyone—from newcomers to experienced dancers—can access new layers of understanding and embodied wisdom.

Come As You Are
The most profound discoveries in Contact Improvisation emerge from the unexpected—from the intersection of different bodies, experiences, and ways of moving through the world. Your unique perspective and embodied wisdom are exactly what this learning community needs. Come ready to explore, to be surprised, and to discover how the dance floor becomes a training ground for creating the more compassionate, connected world we all long for.
No perfection required. Just openness to the movement.

description:
Contemporary Realism, Whether you work from objects, the figure, or secondary sources, this is an opportunity to explore working more loosely, using oils or acrylics.

Justine will guide you through drawing and painting exercises to help loosen you up, and will discuss art historical techniques that may be relevant to your individual artistic style and context.

This course will increase your ability to represent perceived objects in a dynamic, painterly way. You will be guided through drawing and painting exercises to help you achieve accuracy of form, working loosely with oils and acrylics to create fresh contemporary paintings. The emphasis is on working with your chosen source material to create a `next level’ painting. This course is for those who have explored some of the basics of painting such as mixing colours, blending etc, but want to find a process that best expresses your unique approach and ideas. Skills learnt in class can be applied across all genres.

Materials are not included in this course.
Materials: Please bring your preferred range of oils, brushes and supports (paper, canvas, or board). A good basic set of oil paints would include cad and lemon yellow, ultramarine and cerulean blue, and cad red and alizarin crimson. Also, black and white. Inverlochy will supply Liquin and Gamsol solvent. No other solvents are allowed in this class. Please also bring a photocopied reference image in both black and white and colour.

Lunch break - 30 minutes. Bring a water bottle and packed lunch to enjoy in the historic Inverlochy house or explore the local cafes in Te Aro.

description:
Cooking - Singapore Nyonya Food, Love scrumptious Nyonya or Peranakan food? Combining Chinese, Malay and other influences, come and discover how to make your own Nyonya cuisine. Some communal ingredients supplied, a list of other ingredients will be sent out before the course starts (approx cost $35).

Description
Create some classic mouth-watering and flavourful Nyonya dishes. Come and discover how to blend ingredients with distinct spices and cooking techniques. You can easily replicate these dishes at home.

Some ingredients supplied but a list of additional ingredients needed (approximate cost $35) will be sent out when course numbers are confirmed.

Please bring an apron, dish cloth, sharp knife, tea towels and containers to take food home.

Target audience: Adventurous food lovers!

Note: Nuts and gluten will be used in some recipes - this course is not suitable for vegetarians.

By the end of the course, you’ll have:
- Made a selection of Nyonya dishes to take home.
- Become more familiar with using the various spices.
- Understood more about the Nyonya cooking.
- Become more confident to cook Nyonya food at home.

Note: Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. While we wish to create an inclusive environment for all participants, it is important to note that our courses are unable to accommodate specific food allergies or deviate from the preplanned dishes and menus.

Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Prerequisites
Basic cooking skills required.
1 day

description:
Cooking Classes, Authentic Indian cooking classes in Wellington with panaromic views over Wellington Harbour.

In each class, you will learn 4-5 recipes like: potato stuff roti, roasted eggplant curry, wholemeal, roti, naan; shahi paneer; dhal, samosa; palak paneer; gourmet chickpeas; vegetable korma; gulab jamun; kheer; mango lassi; masala chai, and many more...

The classes start at 6 pm or 10:30 am on weekends and weekdays with a 2-hour session followed by a dinner or lunch afterwards. The ingredients, copies of recipes, organic karma drink will be provided with a full course meal in a banquet setting. Custom made classes available for gluten free, dairy free and any other food intolerance and dietary requirements.The ingredients, recipes, complimentary organic karma drinks will be provided with a full course meal.

There are 2 to 8 people in each class in purpose built cooking studio. Also a private cooking classes available.

The menu for the class can be:

1) Spicy potato stuffed paratha and roti, rajasthani tomato relish, aalu matter or spicy peas- potato curry, roasted cumin yogurt raita and fresh mint- coriander chutney.

2) Shahi Paneer (cottage cheese cubes with spices and rich tomato-cashew gravy), garlic coriander naan, cumin jeera basmati rice and sweet fragrant rice pudding with cardamom. Also I will teach how to make fresh paneer.

3) Roasted eggplant curry, plain whole wheat chapatti or roti, jeera aaloo or potato curry, Tuar dahl (split yellow lentil) and Basmati rice with homemade pickle.

4) Palak paneer (creamy spinach curry with cubes of paneer), jeera rice (basmati rice with fragrant spices, panjabi chhole or spicy chickpeas curry and mango lassi. Also fresh paneer making.

5) Khadi (chickpeas fritters in yogurt and chickpeas flour soupy gravy), Aloo-Gobhi (cauliflower and potato curry),  savoury wraps with herbs and spices, fresh pickle and basmati rice.

The total cost is $130 per person, this includes ingredient cost. (As an alternative we also sell cooking class gift vouchers.The food options are unlimited and the class provides fresh and best ingredients)
Please contact for booking: indiancooking@xtra.co.nz

So just bring your taste buds! and Enjoy!!
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Cooking class: Sri Lankan cutlets (Proceeds for disaster relief), Brought to you by Multicultural Collective and Aiyō, hosted by The Beer Engine
Sri Lanka has been hit with devastating floods, and thousands of families have lost their homes and livelihoods overnight. 100% of this events proceeds will going to disaster relief in Sri Lanka.
Come join us, learn the art of Sri Lankan cutlet-making, eat well, and make a difference at the same time. Good food. Good people. A real impact when it’s needed most.
Can You Stop at One? (We dare you!)
A Sri Lankan cutlet is history disguised as a snack. European croquettes crash-landed on the island centuries ago, and Sri Lankans didn’t just borrow the idea — they rewired it. Fish and potato for thrift, chilli and mustard seed for heat, curry leaf and lime for brightness, all sealed in breadcrumbs and fried in coconut oil. One bite tells you everything about the island: layered trade routes, colonial collisions, ingenuity in the kitchen, flavour turned into defiance. It’s super-tasty — crisp, molten, impossible to stop at one. 
Now you get to make your own and learn a bit about Sri Lankan culture.
We’re running a hands-on cutlet class where flavour is learned by instinct, not measuring spoons. You mix, taste, adjust, and chase that perfect balance of heat, comfort and citrus brightness. We bring every ingredient; you bring an appetite and the willingness to get your hands involved.
We’re being hosted by the crew at The Beer Engine — and their Yuzu Hazy is the move. Bright and citrusy, it slices through the richness and wraps around the spice in a way that makes you sit back and swear under your breath. When the frying’s done, we sit together and eat your creations with simple rice and Aiyō dhal. Big flavour, cold beer, good people. The kind of night food lovers remember.
For any questions, please email kiaora@multiculturalcollective.nz
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Cooking: Thai Home-Style, Since the 1980’s tourism has exploded in Thailand and this nation’s cuisine has become one of the five most popular food types globally. Come and learn how to prepare and cook some delicious authentic Thai dishes.

Not suitable for vegetarians. All ingredients included in course fee.

Description
Thai cuisine and cooking has a key secret - the secret is that authentic Thai food balances key flavour elements. Combining sweet, salty, bitter, sour and spicy, Thai cuisine creates sumptuous and exciting flavour combinations. Come along to this half-day cooking course and learn to make some home-style Thai dishes.

Not suitable for vegetarians. All ingredients included in course fee, you just need to bring your apron, a couple of tea towels, a dishcloth and containers to take leftovers home in.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Make some Thai dishes at home with more confidence
Use ingredients/spices/herbs to match with dishes

Apply some aspects of the Thai eating style at home or when visiting Thailand

Note: Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. While we wish to create an inclusive environment for all participants, it is important to note that our courses are unable to accommodate specific food allergies or deviate from the preplanned dishes and menus.

description:
Courageous Communication™ | 1-day Workshop | Wellington | 11 Nov 2025, Courageous Communication™ | 1-day Workshop | Wellington | 11 Nov 2025
Get great at having hard conversations with Kaila Colbin

About this Event

Has this ever happened to you?
You’re sitting in a meeting and there are 50 elephants in the room with you that nobody is mentioning, and you’re doing the strategic plan but everyone knows it’s never going to work because the team don’t have the capability or the capacity and that one person never follows through and that other person thinks her work is better than it is, but nobody says anything and as you leave you think well THAT'S three hours I’m never gonna get back…
It’s hard to say the hard thing.
But saying the hard thing is the only way we can deal with what’s actually going on.
The number one indicator of a lack of courage is an inability to have hard conversations.
Hard conversations are scary. Our hearts start pounding, our tummies clench, our mouths go dry.
Hard conversations feel dangerous. If I say this thing, he’ll be offended! She’ll be angry! I’ll get in trouble!
Hard conversations are tempting to avoid. Nobody else is mentioning these elephants. Why should I?
But what if you were great at them?
What would it mean for your relationships?
What would it mean for your career?
What would it mean for your life?
Kaila Colbin has worked with more than 4,000 people to grow courage as a core competency and a clear framework has emerged from that experience.
In this 1-day workshop, you’ll build the skill and muscle to get great at having hard conversations.
We’ll cover the specific elements of how to communicate and what to communicate.

When: Tuesday, 11 November 2025, 9 am-4:30 pm
Where: Rangimarie Room, Te Papa Museum, 55 Cable Street, Wellington 6011
Lunch, afternoon tea and all-day tea and coffee are included in the registration.



Need help with the cost?
If you are an Educator or at a Not-for-Profit, you can automatically access a special rate of $745 + GST when you register (a $250 discount off our standard General Admission rates).



Our Health and Safety Plan
Boma is committed to delivering safe events. We follow best practices suggested by the New Zealand health authorities and work closely with our suppliers to prioritise health and wellbeing.
Our comprehensive health and safety plans ensure you can book with certainty and attend with confidence.



Our refund policy
For details on event refunds and transfers, please see our refund policy.


About the Kaila Colbin
Kaila Colbin is founder and CEO of Boma, an organisation building a world of intentional, intelligent, courageous leaders.
An award-winning leader renowned for impact, Kaila developed TEDxChristchurch into New Zealand’s flagship TEDx event and brought Singularity University to New Zealand and Australia, supporting thousands of people to engage with exponentially accelerating technologies and their impact on humanity. She trained with Dr Brené Brown as a Certified Dare to Lead™ Facilitator.
As a founder of the non-profit Ministry of Awesome, Kaila played a critical role in developing Christchurch’s startup ecosystem. She has extensive governance experience, and has been involved with mergers, capital raises, and company sales in the US and NZ.
A native New Yorker, Kaila’s work to champion Aotearoa New Zealand on a global stage saw her given the 2022 Kea World Class New Zealand “Friend of New Zealand” award. Her purpose in life is to be an uplifting presence.

If you have any questions about this event, please email us at .

description:
Create, Carve, Wear – Your Own Piece of Jewellery, Join Coveted Jewellery's exclusive workshop in Wellington.
Workshops dates are limited in 2026. 
Design your own sterling silver ring. In just a couple of hours, you’ll go from inspiration to creation, designing and carving your very own wax ring or pendant model. Our experienced jewellers will be there to guide you through every step, whether you're a first-timer or a seasoned artist. Once your wax design is complete, we’ll take care of casting and finishing it in sterling silver, and courier to your doorstep within 2-4 weeks. 
Quotes to upgrade to gold or add a stone are available on the day.

Workshop Details:
Dates: One-off session dates usually scheduled monthly.
Time: Saturdays, 2.30-5 pm
Location: Wellington Studio, situated on level 3, 22 Garrett St, Te Aro
Cost: $280 (Includes all materials, tools, and delivery for a piece of jewellery cast in sterling silver weighing up to 12gms)

This workshop is a fantastic way to create a personal piece of jewellery that you can wear and cherish forever. With only 8-10 spots available per session.

We can't wait to see what you create. 
The Coveted Team x

description:
Crochet - Christmas Special!, In this half day crochet special, you will get the patterns to make stars, and icicles, mini wreaths, a mini Christmas jumper, Christmas tree and gifts bunting and a cute mini Christmas hat. Please bring some 4 or 8 ply smooth yarn and a crochet hook - see full description for suitable types of yarn.

Description

Join Monique in this half-day crochet workshop where you will learn how to crochet a range of little projects suitable for the holiday season. Choose from stars, icicles, mini wreaths and Christmas jumpers, Christmas trees and a mini Santa hat! There will be a booklet of patterns for you to take home, to enable you to complete in your own time the projects that you didn’t have time to make during the workshop.

You will also learn how to crochet and decorate Christmas baubles! While you might not finish all the patterns this day, the aim is to have a go at making as many as possible!

You will need to know some basic crochet stitches such as single and double crochet. You’ll also need to have some understanding of how to read a pattern and work with diagrams, as taught in the beginners’ crochet course.

Please bring yarn that you enjoy working with (cotton, acrylic or wool, 4ply or 8 ply) in a variety of colours (red, white and green, a neutral colour for the mouse, and glittery yarns are all good options for the Christmas projects) and a matching crochet hook. You’ll also need a pair of scissors and a darning needle.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Crochet for Calmness, Crochet is great for settling the mind and encouraging relaxation. Learn to do basic stitches, read patterns and complete projects in a relaxed and friendly space – left handers very welcome.

The repetitive movements of crochet help the brain make more serotonin, which can decrease tension and feelings of depression. We’ll move through all the steps from the starting slipknot to reading patterns and diagrams and making your first crochet projects.

You’ll learn to make a granny square, change colours and how to increase and decrease. You’ll also find out more about the notations and abbreviations of crochet stitches so you can make those awesome crochet projects you've been waiting to make!

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Discuss the benefits of crochet for relaxation and alleviation of mood
- Read a basic crochet pattern and recognise crochet terminology
- Choose yarns and hooks for projects
- Use a range of stitches with confidence
- Complete at least one project of your choice (granny square, keychain, garden decoration)

Suitable for all beginners, both left and right-handers and those who may have struggled to learn to crochet. Initial materials provided but bring along any yarn or crochet hooks you may have at home (don’t buy anything until you’ve discussed this with the tutor).

4 weeks, Thu 5:30-7:30pm
Wellington High School
Presented by Monique Lubberink
$129 incl. GST

description:
Designing exceptional volunteer engagement, Join international volunteer engagement expert Tobi Johnson in an interactive workshop to design a complete volunteer journey. 
Tobi Johnson is an internationally sought-after expert, consultant, and expert trainer in volunteer engagement. She is known for her modern thought leadership, highly practical evidence-based strategies, and innovative, “big hat” thinking around engaging, supporting, and acknowledging the work of volunteers. 
This workshop, to be held in Wellington on Tuesday 27 January, will guide participants through the complete volunteer journey using the Best Practice Guidelines as a framework for exploration. 
Through graphic facilitation, collaborative exercises, and practical brainstorming, you will develop creative and actionable strategies to design a volunteer experience based on the spirit of community. 
If you are a nonprofit that relies on volunteers – with lots of passion but limited resources – this workshop is specifically tailored for you. As community champions, this is an opportunity to explore, visualize, and co-create practical ways to strengthen volunteer engagement, grounded in the shared values that make volunteering in Aotearoa unique. 
Hear from Tobi herself here:
About your facilitator Tobi Johnson:
Tobi Johnson is an internationally sought-after expert, consultant, and expert trainer in volunteer engagement. She is known for her modern thought leadership, highly practical evidence-based strategies, and innovative, “big hat” thinking around engaging, supporting, and acknowledging the work of volunteers. 
She is the President of Tobi Johnson & Associates, a consulting firm whose mission is to help nonprofit organizations make connections with remarkable volunteers. In 2015, she founded VolunteerPro, an online training and networking community for leaders of volunteers.  She is host of the Volunteer Nation Podcast and co-host of the Time + Talent Podcast with Jennifer Bennett of VolunteerMatch. In addition, she wrote Chapter 1 of Volunteer Engagement 2.0: Ideas and Insights for Transforming Volunteer Programs in a Changing World. She is also currently at work on a book for volunteers who lead to be published in 2026. 
Tobi has over 30 years boots-on-the-ground experience in nonprofit management, program development and start up, team leadership, training design and delivery and change management across a wide range of cause impact areas from arts and culture, youth development, employment and training, senior services, healthcare advocacy, homelessness, and more. 
Where: Wellington, in person. Level 2, 50 The Terrace (the VNZ offices), Wellington.
When: Tuesday 27 January - 9am to 5pm.
Tickets and pricing:
We have priced tickets based on organisation type, and offer a 25% discount to Volunteering NZ member organisations.
Community Organisations $199 +gst
Government or Business tickets $219 +gst
Limited low cost and complimentary tickets are available for those who need additional support to access tickets. These are aimed at organisations with an annual income between $0 to $140k.
Please contact us directly if you:
Are a Volunteering NZ Member and have not received the discount code of 25%, or
Want to enquire about scholarship or low cost tickets.
Email us on office@volunteeringnz.org.nz or phone us on 04 470 6006. Volunteering NZ member list here.

description:
Dolores Mosquera Wellington New Zealand May 2026, Day 1 – May 10, 2026 (9:00am–4:30pm)
Topic: Working with Dissociative Parts and Their Voices in Complex Trauma and Dissociative Disorders
Overview:
This seminar focuses on adapting EMDR for individuals with dissociative disorders, using the Trauma-Informed Relational Approach for Dissociative Parts (TADP) Dolores has developed. It provides strategies for working with dissociative parts and their voices and integrating a trauma-informed approach to inner conflict safely from early treatment stages.
Key Learning Points:
·         Identifying and working with dissociative parts and their voices.
·         Understanding the function and purpose of “hostile” parts.
·         Addressing dissociative phobias through EMDR informed techniques.
·         Managing resistance and treatment impasses.
·         Structuring work with dissociative parts effectively.
Program Description:
After many early cautions about the potential dangers of using EMDR with individuals suffering from dissociative disorders, limited methods have been offered for adapting standard EMDR procedures to this specific population. Based on these early cautions, EMDR is still considered by many clinicians as limited to the treatment of traumatic memories in high-functioning dissociative clients and only after a long preparation phase that depends on other treatment modalities. Confined by this conceptualisation, the use of EMDR is too often limited, and many survivors of severe traumatisation are unable to benefit from EMDR reprocessing and, if at all, only much later in the treatment process.
Dolores Mosquera developed (with AnabelGonzalez, M.D.) the Progressive Approach model for treating complex trauma and dissociation (2012) and the Trauma-Informed Relational Approach for Dissociative Parts (TADP) (2019, 2025). Using this trauma and AIP-informed models, clinicians can safely utilise a wide range of EMDR interventions (including BLS) from early in the preparatory phase of treatment for patients with dissociative disorders.
In this seminar, she will present her current practice of working with clients, including video demonstrations. Mosquera's deft clinical skills and ground-breaking innovative thinking teach a middle ground between "dissociation blind" aggressive EMDR interventions and overly cautious delays to the use of EMDR reprocessing.
Many dissociative clients have difficulty with hostile, critical voices. The internal conflict is sometimes so intense that the person even has difficulty carrying on an ordinary conversation. One factor that affects this conflict is how the patient deals with the voices or parts of the self.
Key Program Content:
Identify the internal system of dissociation and internal voices that are hostile and critical
How to read the function and purpose behind the saboteur parts of self
Using compassion and understanding to help deal with dissociative phobias within the internal system
Skills to reduce impasses and resistance that may complicate or reduce the efficacy of the treatment
Specific steps to organize the work with hostile parts and voices
 Days 2–3 – May 11–12, 2026 (9:00am–4:30pm)
Topic: From Fragmentation to Integration: A Master Class in Treating Complex Trauma and Dissociation
Format: 2-Day Masterclass: Three Clinical Cases from Start to Finish
Across two days, Dolores will present three distinct new cases illustrating varying levels of dissociation — including one with frequent switching and no initial Adult Self. Each session is interactive, highlighting the therapeutic process from assessment to completion.
Over two immersive days, this advanced master class offers a rare opportunity to observe and analyse complete therapeutic processes under the expert guidance of Dolores Mosquera.

Dolores will present three new and distinct clinical cases, each representing different manifestations of complex trauma and dissociation — including one client who experiences frequent switching and begins therapy without an integrated adult self.
Participants will follow these clients’ journeys from the initial stages of therapy through to treatment completion, gaining deep insight into decision-making, pacing, and the integration of EMDR strategies within complex systems. The format is designed to be highly interactive and reflective, combining video demonstrations, live commentary, and group discussion to deepen understanding of safe, flexible, and attuned clinical practice when working with dissociative clients.
This master class is ideal for clinicians seeking to refine their skills, expand their conceptual framework, and enhance clinical confidence when navigating the challenges of trauma-related dissociation.
Additional Details
·         Eligibility: Must have completed at least Part One of EMDR Basic Training (University of Otago or equivalent).
·         Certification: Participants receive a Professional Development Certificate of Attendance.
·         Dietary needs: Provided upon registration.
·         Parking: Paid on-site parking available.
·         Accommodation: Discounted rates at a local hotel (discount code to be posted on the event site).

description:
Draw the Moon: A Lunar Sketching Workshop at Star Safari, See the Moon like an astronomer — and draw it like an artist.
Join us at the Star Safari Observatory for a unique 90-minute experience where astronomy meets art. In this hands-on workshop, you’ll learn how to sketch the Moon directly at the eyepiece of our telescopes while observing its craters, mountains, shadows, and changing light in real time.

Using quality sketching materials (provided on the night), you’ll be guided step-by-step through:
- recognising key lunar features
- capturing contrast, relief and texture
- translating live telescope views accurately to paper
- fast sketching techniques for an object that’s constantly moving

You’ll have dedicated telescope time with our team, adjusting the optics for you and helping you get the sharpest possible view. This experience is designed to be accessible for beginners, while still rewarding for those with some astronomy or art experience.

Set beneath Wairarapa’s internationally acclaimed dark skies, this workshop offers a quiet, focused creative moment under the Moon. Whether you come for art, astronomy, or simply the pleasure of observing slowly and noticing deeply, you’ll leave with a sketch that is uniquely yours — shaped by the night and the light you saw.

Who is this for?
Adults and older children with an interest in drawing, the night sky, or simply trying something new.

Included:
✔ High-quality sketching pencils and paper
✔ Expert lunar observing guidance
✔ Dedicated telescope time
✔ Use of Star Safari’s professional viewing equipment

What to bring:
Warm clothing, curiosity, and any of your favourite drawing tools if you’d like to use them.

Take home more than a drawing — take home a moment of looking closely.

description:
EC-MENz Summit 2026, EC-MENz vision is for men fully participating at all levels of Early Childhood Education to represent the diversity of our society in Aotearoa.
The EC-MENz Summit 2026 is kindly being hosted and supported by Childspace.

Tāne, wāhine, and irawhiti are warmly invited to participate in a special day of high quality, affordable professional learning. This celebration of gender diversity in ECE will be held in a safe and supportive environment and is a fantastic opportunity to meet others in the profession, share your own story, and be inspired.
Gender Steretoypes in ECE - Mike Collin and Max Christie
What can gender stereotypes teach us about teaching and learning?
Early childhood education relies on diversity within teaching teams. Yet, gender stereotypes often shape how we see ourselves and each other as kaiako. This interactive session invites educators to explore the hidden assumptions that influence teaching roles and team dynamics. In this session, Max and Mike will unpack how stereotypes impact collaboration and how every kaiako adds unique value to teaching teams. Participants will leave with practical strategies to challenge bias, strengthen team culture, and celebrate the richness of varied approaches in ECE settings.
Autism NZ - Thecla Moffat
Men can change the dynamics of play in ECE benefiting autistic tamariki
Male kaiako often bring more energy in the ECE setting with an emphasis on more physical activity, outdoor play, "rough and tumble" play, and positive risk-taking, which appeals to both boys and girls and provides a different dimension to play than may be beneficial to most autistic tamariki. We now know that through fun and engaging interactions kaiako help enhance the autistic tamariki pivotal capacities for later learning. In this talk kaiako will get to know how men in ECE with their positive energy can make a difference through play for autistic tamariki in their centres. The kaiako will be given a few strategies of how to do that and some ideas to encourage tuakana-teina (peer play) between autistic tamariki and their non-autistic peers will be shared.

description:
ESC September Asian Artist meetup, The Eastern Sound Collective is a growing community of creatives with pan-Asian roots, coming together to connect, collaborate, and support each other.
We’d love for you to join us for our next gathering on Thursday, September 4th at 6.30PM!
The evening will kick off with a workshop on Building Sustainable Art Practices with Jem Yoshioka:
About Jem:
Jem Yoshioka is an illustrator, writer and comic artist based in Pōneke, Wellington. Jem's debut graphic novel Folk Remedy Book 1 releases in September 2025, and she's busy working on Book 2. When not making comics you can find Jem dreaming up more story ideas and hanging out with her black cat. You can find her on social media @jemyoshioka most places (Instagram, BlueSky, TikTok, X)
Building Sustainable Art Practices:
In 2025 it feels like it's challenging enough to survive as a person, let alone thrive as an artist. But art has the unique power to nourish us in ways nothing else can. In this workshop Jem will share some of the strategies, habits and tools she uses to fit in making graphic novels alongside full time employment without burning out. This session is practice-agnostic, and is designed to facilitate discussion about what a sustainable art practice can look like, how to build one, and how we can support each other when things are tough. No resources required but feel free to bring any notebooks or tools you use to manage your art or your time

After that, we’ll share some kai (potluck style), have a relaxed kōrero
The gathering will be held at a cozy private space in Wellington CBD, easily accessible by public transport.
Message us for the exact location: easternsoundcollective@gmail.com
Or reach out on Instagram/Facebook: @easternsoundcollective

description:
Early Childhood Centre Emergency Planning Workshop - Paraparaumu, Would you and your staff be confident in an emergency? Do you have a plan, and more importantly have you practiced it recently?

We are holding a free workshop for Early Childhood Education Centres in the Kāpiti Coast to come together to discuss your emergency plans.

This workshop is an opportunity for ECEs to share challenges and solutions and get advice from our Emergency Management Advisors.

It aims to help ECEs plan for significant events such as earthquake, tsunami, armed intruders and to share ideas and network around emergency planning.

This is an opportunity for Centre Managers, Directors, Health & Safety Representatives or Leads to:

- Share solutions, practical advice and learnings from recent events.
- Discuss your current plans with emergency management professionals.
- Learn more about our local hazards and important planning information including lessons learnt from the Christchurch Earthquake, Christchurch Mosque Attack and Cyclone Gabrielle.

Hope to see you there as we build safer and more resilient ECEs and communities together.

Places are limited to a maximum of 30 people attending each session. This workshop is endorsed by the Ministry of Education.

For more information, please email info@wremo.nz

We aim to make our community events inclusive to all people. If you are attending the event and have specific accessibility requirements, you can send us an email at info@wremo.nz with the event name and we will get in touch to see how we can meet your needs as best we can.

description:
Financial Planning for Retirement, Financially successful people don’t achieve their wealth by accident – they make and execute clear plans. Your retirement is on the horizon and research shows you’re most likely nowhere near financially ready for the retirement you desire and deserve! Get a complete and utterly practical financial plan, so you can have the retirement you want.

Massey University's annual Retirement Expenditure Guidelines study (2019) found:

Just 40% of pre-retirees believed they were well-prepared for retirement, and 57% considered retirement to be a concern. They also confirmed, New Zealand Superannuation is not sufficient to fund the retirement most people want.
Ministry of Social Development (2020):

22% of all people receiving New Zealand Superannuation also receive additional support payments, with over 44,000 superannuants receiving additional accommodation support, and if you needed to obtain Government-assisted accommodation, at the end of March 2020, more than 16,300 households were waiting for state or social housing.

Living in a motel or boarding house with strangers (who may have other vulnerable backgrounds) is not an ideal or safe location to spend your retirement years. But for many, it is the only option they can afford.

If you have not planned for your retirement, then this course is you!

This course has been developed for people in their 50s or 60s that are looking at retirement and have no idea if they can financially survive it: what to do, what $’s they need, how or where they can generate additional income, or even where to go to get help.

It is targeted towards those that still have some time (for some - not much) to make adjustments, learn some basic financial skills, make some big decisions, and positively influence the quality of their pending retirement.

You will be introduced to a simple step by step guide to developing a financial plan for retirement.

You will work through a case study in class, and can then go away and repeat the process with your own data/details. You will be provided with comprehensive course notes to enable you to update the case study information with your own information.

At each step, key considerations and financial concepts will be defined, explained and discussed to help you understand the financial requirements of retirement.

Are you ready for the retirement lifestyle you hoped or dreamed of? If not, then this course is for you.

Disclaimer: The tutors are not financial advisors. No investments, products nor specific recommendations will be provided. A step by step planning process will be taught by working through a case study. Key considerations that should be used by the participants when looking at their own options to bridge the financial gap between what is available through superannuation and what is required to meet lifestyle goals will be provided and discussed. Product names may be used in examples and explanations to help participants understand the financial concepts and the planning process.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

1 Day
Presented by Paul and Mary-Ellen Gadd.

description:
Fluid Art Workshop, Fluid Art Workshop
Spend an evening unwinding with paint, good food, and good company. This beginner-friendly class is designed for everyone—you don’t need to be an artist to enjoy it. All the materials will be ready for you, and you’ll get to explore blacklight-reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints, experimenting with marble and swirl effects to create something completely your own.
Since the paint takes a few days to fully dry, your artwork will stay safely with us—you’ll be able to come back on Sunday to pick it up.
It can get a bit messy, so come in clothes you don’t mind getting paint on, and tie your hair back if it’s long.
After the painting, relax over a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, the perfect way to finish a creative and relaxed night.
Meet your host, Alannah
Alannah has been fascinated by blacklight art since she was 15 and has been exploring different mediums to find what really stands out for 20 years. She takes inspiration from all the wonderful artists she encounters in the real world and online. She noticed that this particular type of fluid art hadn't really been done the way she does it, so she has developed her own unique style utilising blacklight reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints. Let her colour your world and explore the possibilities of fluid art together.

description:
Free Postpartum Exercise Class, Are you a mum ready to sparkle, rebuild, and find your strength after having your baby?
The Village NZ and Sparkle Fitness invite you to join a revitalising postpartum exercise class with Sierra Ryland, owner of Sparkle Fitness, at Karori Rec Centre, Wellington!

Sierra is a MumSafe, REPs (Registered Exercise Professional) and Safe Return to Exercise certified personal trainer, running and triathlon coach, and owner of Sparkle Fitness. As a mum herself, she knows how important it is to feel strong and confident in your body while also balancing the demands of motherhood.

This class offers a gentle, supportive approach to rebuilding your strength, focusing on pelvic floor health, core restoration, and functional movement. Whether you’re returning to exercise or just starting, this class is your space to recharge, connect, and feel at home in your body again.

What can you expect from this class?
- A 45min session
- This class will focus on the pelvic floor and restoring your core by teaching you proper cueing to help you activate the right muscles. A fantastic opportunity to make sure you start to heal and strengthen from the inside out.
- Functional strength and cardio exercises so that you can be confident each day.
- Small group size: up to 10 mums per class.
- A chance to connect with other Mum's like you, in a small and comfortable environment.
- Go at your own pace. No pressure! We will focus on working at the pace the level you are comfortable with. No counting reps or how much you can lift!
- Morning tea provided after the session and a chance to chat and ask questions.
What do you need to bring with you?
- You! Babies are welcome if you need to bring them along.
- A workout mat and your own water bottle.

This class is FREE, but registration is essential! Spaces are limited so register now to secure your spot https://wix.to/eWOqgl9
Proudly supported and funded by The Village NZ/Wright Family Foundation
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Freedom and Responsibility in Science - WELLINGTON, Join the Royal Society Te Apārangi for a wide-ranging panel discussion about the many threats to the integrity of science around the world, how they can be addressed, and New Zealand’s place in the global context. The panel will feature expert guest speakers from the International Science Council’s (ISC) Committee for Freedom and Responsibility in Science.
Science today faces many challenges: Scientific and academic freedoms are declining worldwide as anti-science ideology becomes imbedded in many of the world’s governments; state obligations towards enabling science as a human right remain chronically ignored; irresponsible scientific conduct and governance of all kinds increasingly undermine science from within; and the tally of wars and crises which rob the world of the scientific talent held by entire nations is growing year by year.
At precisely the moment when scientific progress on some of the existential threats to humanity is most urgent, science itself is under more pressure than perhaps ever before. So, what can we do?
About the ISC Committee for Freedom and Responsibility in Science:
The Committee monitors trends related to scientific and academic freedom globally, advises the ISC on official statements and positions, and advocates for the Principles of Freedom and Responsibility in Science. The Committee also engages in major projects at the intersection of science, human rights, and philosophy, such as the ISC’s recent interpretation of The Right to Participate in and Benefit from Science.
Event details:
5:40pm - Doors open
6:00pm - Panel discussion
7:15pm - Networking with drinks and canapés till 8:15pm
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Genealogy - Basics of Ancestry.com DNA Tests, Have you done a DNA test with Ancestry.com? Don't know what to do next? This course will cover the basics of what your DNA results mean. We'll look at the tools available on Ancestry.com and other DNA websites to help you use DNA for your family's history.

Got your test results back and still wondering what a centiMorgan or a shared match is? Find out what the size of your match means and the tools available to help you work out possible family relationships.

We'll start by looking at Clustering and how the Grouping tool on Ancestry.com can help with this. We'll also look at the ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools to see how they can provide suggestions for knocking down brick walls in your research.

Also covered during this course are other websites you can upload your results to, how to manage other family member's DNA test results and other tools available when you get a bit more advanced - and just in case you need help in the future, we'll look at some of the places you could get this from.

Please note: This course will only cover DNA tests taken through Ancestry.com

Bring a USB stick and your Ancestry.com login details.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Understand the information provided by Ancestry.com about your DNA matches
- Use the Grouping, ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools on Ancestry.com
- Use the Shared CentiMorgan tool on DNAPainter.com
- Understand where to find other tools
- Understand the options for using other DNA websites
- Understand where to get further help

Prerequisites
For those who have already done a DNA test through Ancestry.com
You will need good computing and internet skills.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Presented by Sarah Hewitt.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Get Animated! Stop-motion Animation Workshop, Get Animated! Stop-motion Animation Workshop
Ever wanted to try your hand at stop-motion animation and bring inanimate objects to life? Now you can!

Join animator Steffen Kreft and storyteller and poet William Connor for a practical, hands-on workshop that will inspire and enable you to make your own magical stop-motion worlds and movies at home.

Supported by Wairarapa Library Service.

You’ll need to download an app on your smartphone, bring a desk-lamp, a snack, your fully charged smart-phone and charger, a steady hand and an open mind. All other materials provided.

Here's the (free) app to download on your smartphone:
i-Phone:
https://apps.apple.com/nz/app/stop-motion-studio/id441651297
Android:
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.cateater.stopmotionstudio&pli=1

Ages 12 and up welcome – no prior experience required.
Places are limited to 16, so get animated!

Workshop 1-4pm, then a break, and at 5.30pm, we'll screen everyone's work.

Registration is required.
To register your interest, please email <events.waiword>.

About the tutors:

WILLIAM CONNOR
William Connor studied German, English literature, and Theatre at Victoria University in Welling-ton, where he completed his Master’s in creative writing in 2016. He lives between Berlin and Greytown, and works as a teacher, translator, editor, writer, and puppeteer. He has published numerous poems and short stories in several anthologies and journals, has written and per-formed in a number of plays that have toured New Zealand and Germany, and is the writer and cocreator of the intercultural comedy web-series Lifeswap, which explores and celebrates the differences between the German and New Zealand cultures.

STEFFEN KREFT
Steffen Kreft is an animation film director, illustrator, marionette maker and puppeteer. He was born in Münster, Germany and is currently living in Greytown in the Wairarapa.
When he first moved to New Zealand in 2007, he did his Masters in design at Massey University and co-founded the animation company National Park Studios in 2010. He taught design, animation and puppet making at Massey University and The Learning Connexion. In 2012, he directed and organised the Greytown Arts Festival and directed and made marionettes for the award winning adult puppet show “The Kitchen at the End of the World”. In 2014, Steffen and his partner William moved to Berlin for a few years where they started the popular animated web series Lifeswap about the cultural differences between New Zealand and Germany.
Now, he spends his time making short films for organisations like the French/German TV channel Arte, several New Zealand ministries, German museums and start-up companies or creates giant puppets and mesmerising marionette shows for festivals. He is also building a beautiful tiny house on wheels – apparently his most creatively challenging as well as satisfying project yet.
He has a passion for making things with his hands and while his projects are so varied, he can be very proud of the attention to detail that is obvious in all of his work.

</events.waiword>

description:
Getting the Most from ChatGPT: Practical AI for Everyday Use, AI tools like ChatGPT are everywhere, but how do you get the best out of them? In this hands-on, phone-based workshop, Jon Bell will guide you through practical techniques to make ChatGPT a more useful, reliable partner in your work and life. Whether you’ve tried it a few times or use it regularly, you’ll learn how to write better prompts, refine responses, and avoid common pitfalls without needing any technical background.
We’ll cover real examples, answer your questions as they come up, and spend plenty of time experimenting together so you leave feeling confident and ready to put your new skills to use.
Please bring: A phone with the ChatGPT app installed, and enough battery to last the day.
By the end of the workshop, you’ll be able to:
Write effective prompts that get clearer, more useful responses
Use ChatGPT for research, brainstorming, and creative work
Recognise the tool’s limitations (and how to work around them)
Apply practical strategies for using AI in your personal or professional projects
Confidently troubleshoot when ChatGPT gives unexpected or unhelpful answers
A condition of enrolment is that you must provide photo ID when you attend.
Note:  Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Gorgeous Texture Earrings and Pendants Taster, A quick taster class that’s ideal as a festive outing for friends, or as a treat for you! In three short hours, learn to craft an amazing pair of textured metal earrings - from scratch!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. After completing this class, you will have one pair of beautiful earrings to wear away or gift to someone special!

You will practice on smaller texture samples to work out what texture and what metal you want to go with, and then move on to creating your earrings in warm copper, yellow brass and sterling silver - with solid sterling silver earring hooks or posts.

The earrings will be made with silver bonded onto copper, giving the bright flash of silver on one side and the dark tone of copper on the other.

Your class materials pack includes everything you need for the class to make a super cool pair of beautiful earrings. You are welcome to purchase extra materials for larger pieces at the studio.

We use quality pre-made sterling silver earring wires, or earring posts with silicone stud backs for these taster classes so that you can focus on making the main part of the earrings and know that your findings will be just perfect.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but an enrolled parent or caregiver must accompany anyone under the age of 16.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Hands-on Sourdough Workshop (Neil's), Sourdough for Beginners - $120 (paid via internet banking)
Come join us for a hands-on, in-person sourdough workshop at Willow Corner Collective headquarters (aka my home)! This workshop is currently the only hands-on sourdough workshop being offered in the Nelson region - I teach and demonstrate to you and then you get to mix and practice on your own dough as we go along.
Whether you're a seasoned baker or a beginner, this event is perfect for anyone looking to master the art of making sourdough bread, learning from someone who has 10+ years of experience. Perhaps you've found all the Youtube tutorials and Instagram how-to's overwhelming and are keen to learn via an in-person class. Then this is for you! I've baked hundreds of loaves in the last year alone, sold at a market, and hosted a pop-up shop. However, my passion really lies with teaching others to bake their own sourdough in their own homes, for their own families (or small businesses - one day!).You will be taught, demonstrated to, and then you get to have a go yourself; whilst learning my tips and tricks along the way. Plus we finish by sampling some delicious, fresh artisan sourdough with some favourite toppings!
You'll go home with all you need to make a good loaf of sourdough bread:
Knowledge
Student Guide, including recipes and troubleshoot guide
Bowl, liner, bowl scraper, and razor blade... all the tools you'd need to make sourdough
Dough made in class to bake the next day at home, to wow your family/friends
Confidence to continue the process yourself
Healthy, bubbling starter to continue your journey at home
Continued support and encouragement via our own private Facebook community group, for class attendees only
Note: You will have your dough to take home after the workshop that will need shaping around 6-8pm, so please ensure that will work for you that day.Also, please double check the date when booking. If for some reason you are unable to attend on the day, due to time constraints, I am unable to refund your ticket. I am happy for you to send someone in your place, though. In extenuating circumstances I may be able to hold your ticket for a future workshop; this is decided on a case-by-case basis.
*Payment to clear in bank account two days after ticket bought, after which time your ticket will be released on to someone else. Please pay immediately upon purchasing ticket.
**All workshop info you need to know ahead of time is in the confirmation email. Please ensure you read this down to the bottom.
***I recommend you already have a pair of digital scales, and a cast iron dutch oven at home to bake your loaf with as this makes the best, artisan sourdough, with great rise. Alternatively, a large, lidded casserole dish or enamel roasting pan work also. (The lids are a necessity).
"Sarah’s sour dough class is for real life! Achieve beautiful delicious bread easily in your own kitchen. Sarah teaches you how to fit sourdough into your busy life. She clearly and passionately gives the essential information, tips and tricks to make your own loaf. I loved getting to have a go at each step in the process. I love Sarah’s catchy philosophy “The goal is good bread, not perfect bread.” This took all the pressure off, for me, and I left the class empowered with all the knowledge and skills needed to give it a go at home. I appreciated the thoughtful and well prepared resources Sarah gave us. Thank you!" - Megan
"Sourdough with Sarah was a delight! From feeling overwhelmed and giving up on the idea of ever making my own loaf of sourdough, to dancing with joy as i watch a beautiful perfect sourdough loaf get nice and golden in the homewood stove!The information was packaged in bite sizes with hands on practice in between, where we all got to experience each step of the whole process, which was cleverly condensed and prepared so that despite normally having waits in between, we were able to see it all play out in a short few hours!The process was beautifully organised with attention to detail that had us fawning, came away feeling so blessed and privileged!Sarah's glowing personality made all the information feel easy and palatable, it was so fun!Such a lovely time, great environment to learn with ease." -Melody

description:
Hataitai community centre Raranga, Te Motu Kairangi, with the support of Hataitai Centre & Community House, warmly invites you to:
Monthly Flax Weaving Wānanga
Experience the joy of learning, sharing, and reconnecting with the art of weaving.
Whether you’re a first-time weaver or returning to refresh your skills, all are welcome. We’ll cover basic weaving techniques and tikanga (customs) and provide a supportive, creative space to connect with Māori arts and crafts alongside others.
Session Times
• Pihinga (Beginners): 11:30am – 1:30pm (pack down starts at 1:15pm)
• Tuākana (Returners): 1:00pm – 4:30pm (pack down starts at 4:00pm)
What to Bring
• New weavers: 5–10 rau (blades) of harakeke, sharp scissors.
• An old towel
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
• Returning weavers: 30–40 rau of harakeke and your weaving tools
• Some tools are available to borrow
• Shared kai (snacks) welcome but not required
• Bring a bag, as you must take away leftover harakeke
Koha appreciated, not required
If you would like to support the kaupapa, please email us at temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com for koha details.
Come and enjoy weaving, learning, and connection in a beautiful, relaxed setting.
Contact
via facebook
https://www.facebook.com/TeMotuKai

Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com
If you would like to koha to TMK, please email (Email temotukairangi.huihui@gmail.com) for the account details.

description:
How To Be A DJ - An Introduction, Always wanted to try being a DJ but not sure where to begin? Experienced and professional DJ Shan (Shannon Chng-Rawiri) will teach you all about the technical aspects, equipment and terminology, as well as the industry in general, and enable you to put together a confident short performance.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

Gain an understanding of the work content and career opportunities in this industry
- Learn the difference between what a DJ is required to deliver in the following situations: Mobile, Club, Radio, Turntablist and Hobby
- Participate in various practical activities: Slip Cueing and Baby Scratch, basic beat matching and song structures

Gain a good understanding of the equipment used and terminology including:
Tables: pitch control
Mixer: crossfader, input faders, EQ, gain, cue system
Needles: back tracking
Slip Mats

Learn about Counting Bars and Matching Tempos - The difference between a Bar, Phrases and BPM - Techniques to Count, Hand position and movement etc
- Confidently present a 5 minute performance in class

The course will be held at DJ Shan’s studio at Shop 21, 71 Cuba Street, Wellington. Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.. Bring headphones, a USB with your favourite music and a laptop, if you have one. Limited to eight participants.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 6 weeks,
DJ Shan
