description:
John Campbell’s Destiny Church Investigation: Part 2 Under His Command, John Campbell investigated Destiny Church in a five-part documentary screened in April this year.
Join us to watch Part 2 of John Campbell’s Destiny Church investigation. John Campbell highlights some consistent themes of Brian Tamaki's Destiny Church: far-right prejudices, manifest anger, and hatred.
In Auckland on 21 June, Destiny Church organised a march to take "a bold public stand for Christian values, Kiwi identity and the future of this nation".
On Saturday, 13 September, Brian Tamaki attended the London “Unite the Kingdom” protest organised by far-right political activist Tommy Robinson that claimed to celebrate 'free speech', but also contained chants of hate, racist conspiracy theories, and Christian nationalist slogans. Among disturbing scenes, some people in the crowd ripped up a flag that read 'Secular Humanism'. To them, the very idea that people of all backgrounds and beliefs can live together with equality and respect is something to fear and destroy. For decades, the far right in the USA has painted humanism as a bogeyman, blaming it for liberal values, the rights of women, and the rights of LGBT people. It shows that those who thrive on fear are deliberately targeting the very values that underpin human rights and human dignity. Humanism is not a fringe or ‘woke’ idea. It is about fairness. It is about reason. It is about believing in the good that people are capable of when they are free to live their lives without fear or prejudice. These protests, which Brian Tamaki is supporting, are a show of force from those who wish to undo progress, to divide communities, and to undermine cherished freedoms.
We have a growing concern for secular values in our community. We cannot be silent. It is essential to keep compassion alive in public life and politics. After watching the documentary, we will discuss our concerns and how we might respond.
Time: Oct 6, 2025 06:30 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88183700512...

description:
Just Sew and Furoshiki Gift Wrapping, Just Sew - December Edition + Furoshiki Gift Wrapping!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it!

Book through our website and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

Seasonal Special: Furoshiki Gift Wrapping Station

To celebrate the season, we are also offering a Furoshiki Gift Wrapping Station! Learn how to wrap your gifts the sustainable way, using beautiful fabric scraps repurposed from the Curtain Bank.

A friendly volunteer will be on hand to guide you through the wrapping technique, so you can add a thoughtful, sustainable touch to your gifts this season.

No booking needed - just drop by during the event to give it a try. You can wrap a gift as a koha, or give a koha for the fabric you use.

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY, Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE PUKERUA BAY SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
3-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
3.15-3.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
3.45-4pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

description:
Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour, Katherine Mansfield's Thorndon: Guided Walking Tour
Part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025

"How hard is it to escape from places. However carefully one goes they hold you – you leave little bits of yourself fluttering on the fences – like rags and shreds of your very life.” Katherine Mansfield in a letter to Ida Baker, 1922

Explore the Thorndon that Katherine Mansfield knew and the traces of her legacy that remain in the landscape today. Beginning with an introductory talk, a viewing of the exhibition 75 Tinakori Road: “This marvel had come to the lane” and a hot drink at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, the guided walking tour will finish at the National Library of New Zealand.

Please note: This is a guided walking tour which will involve approx. 30 minutes of walking on flat ground with frequents stops. Participants are encouraged to wear comfortable shoes and bring appropriate protection from sun and rain. The tour will begin upstairs at Katherine Mansfield House & Garden, if you have accessibility requirements, please see the accessibility information on our website or contact us to discuss.

Bad weather postponement dates: The tour will go ahead if there is light rain, so please bring a raincoat. If there is heavy rain and/or strong winds the Saturday 18 October tour will be postponed to Saturday 25 October; the Thursday 23 October tour will be postponed to Thursday 30 October. Participants will be notified by email and text message (if a mobile number is provided when booking) by 9am on the day of the tour if there is a postponement.

(Image: The Katherine Mansfield Memorial photographed by Charles P S Boyer, c1930s. Wellington City Council Archives, 00157-99)
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kids Rock 4 Palestine, Kids Rock For Palestine
One Day. One Stage. One Cause.
This event is organised by kids in Pōneke to raise funds for kids in Palestine.
Join us for a one-day-only music fundraiser where young voices take centre stage to amplify hope and raise money for children in Palestine.
This isn’t just a concert, it’s a movement. Under-18 musicians, solo artists, and bands (some joined by over-18 allies) are coming together to rock out with purpose, showing that music knows no borders and compassion has no age limit.
These young performers are using their talents to stand in solidarity with kids just like them who are living through unimaginable circumstances.
Organiser Eddie 12: "We see children in Palestine who are being bombed and shot and are starving. We kids want to help. So that is what we are doing."
There will be stalls and crafting available for kids attending - Please come and support so we can raise money for Gaza's families.
100% of proceeds go directly to emergency aid and child-focused relief in Palestine - Convoys of Good and Kiwi Trust for Palestinian Childrens Relief.
Witness the next generation of artists and activists sharing the stage and raising their voices. Please support them with your attendance. Show them young people can make a difference.
Be part of an event where music becomes action, and community becomes change.
Do you want to volunteer to help? Email aotearoa2gaza@gmail.com
ALL UNDER 18s MUST ATTEND WITH A PARENT OR GUARDIAN.

description:
LONG LUNCH in the Waitarere Beach Forest, HELLO BEACH LOVERS
The Waitārere Forest Long Lunch
- Sunday 18 January 2026
- book your tickets online
Get ready for one of the highlights of our Waitārere summer calendar - the Waitārere Forest Long Lunch is returning on Sunday, 18 January 2026, and it’s looking to be our biggest and best yet!
 Held beneath the towering pines of the Waitārere Forest, this annual event is all about community,   connection, and celebration. The Long Lunch has become a much-loved tradition for residents and visitors alike - a day to relax, share good food, and enjoy the easy-going Waitārere lifestyle that makes our beach so special.
We’re proud to announce that "Gareth Heard and the team from Unique Realty" are now our major sponsors for Long Lunch. Their generous support is helping us make this year’s event extra special, including an exciting $500 cash giveaway to one lucky ticket holder! You must be present on the day to claim the prize, so make sure you don’t miss out on what promises to be an unforgettable afternoon.
Early Bird Tickets: $15* per person (01 Dec - 11 Jan)
Standard Tickets: $20* per person (12 Jan - 17 Jan)
Gate Sales Tickets: $25* per person (18 Jan)
*Fee (per Ticket/Order) 3% + 30c
All tables and chairs are provided - bring your own plates, cutlery, glasses, drinks, and a plate of food to share. From homemade favourites to gourmet treats, the shared tables are always overflowing with creativity, flavour, and generosity.
And don’t forget - the Long Lunch is also a major fundraiser for our community. There will be raffles, auctions, and prizes throughout the day, so bring plenty of cash and help us raise funds for local projects that make Waitārere Beach an even better place to live.
This year’s fundraising focus:
The Upgrade of the Community House Preschoolers' playground on Rua Ave.
It’s more than just a meal - it’s a celebration of our people and our place. Whether you’re a full-time local or here on holiday, you’ll be part of something special: great food, great company, and great memories under the forest canopy.
So gather your friends, pack your picnic gear, and join us for the Waitārere Forest Long Lunch. Let’s make this a summer to remember - full of laughter, flavour, and community spirit.
See you under the pines
on Sunday, 18 January 2026!

description:
Labour Day 2025 Open Day, FOR IMMEDIATE USE – OCTOBER 2025.
LABOUR DAY – OPEN DAY- Monday 27th October, 10AM- 4PM
Wellington’s historic Wrights Hill Fortress in Karori will be opened for public inspection again on LABOUR DAY, Monday 27th October, one of the official functions of Wellington Heritage Festival. The World War Two coastal battery will be accessible between 10am and 4pm.
On LABOUR Day people are invited to self-guide themselves through the tunnels and gun emplacements. The walk usually takes about one hour. Bring a torch with you for some fun!
Visitors will be able to explore the 620 metres of underground tunnels with a free map and history pamphlet. They will see the engine room, shell stores, plotting rooms and the huge gun pit where Gun Number 1 used to stand, as well as a replica of the 10-metre-long gun barrel.
On show will be historic photos, and some military memorabilia. A DVD of how a 9.2-inch gun operates will be showing as well.
Wrights Hill Fortress was built from 1942 to protect Wellington from Japanese bombardment. In the early 1960’s, the guns were cut up for scrap and sold, ironically, to the Japanese.
Admission is CASH ONLY- $20 for a family of two adults and three children under 15, or $10 per adult and $5 per child. (Sorry no EFTPOS). Access is via Karori Road, Campbell Street, and Wrights Hill Road. All proceeds go to the continuing restoration of the Fortress.
There is limited car parking at the summit of the Hill. Try walking from the base of the hill. Please wear strong footwear.
A BBQ sausage sizzle and soft drinks will be on sale. Make it a fun day for the family.

description:
Letters out Loud 2025 — Part of Friends of the Turnbull Library Public Programme Series, A 1940 newspaper exhorted its readers to ‘write a letter! Take a little chunk of your heart and spread it over some paper; it goes, oh, such a long way!’
Letters out Loud will expose some of those heart-felt issues people addressed on paper in the past. Well-known personalities will read letters from the Alexander Turnbull Library Collections which reveal concerns, among other things:
* the oldest extant Māori letter, written and read by a child
* the ups and downs of farm life
* Yehudi Menuhin in the bath
* a Member of Parliament in love
* on board the sinking Wahine in 1968.
Brought to life by familiar voices
Letters out Loud will be an evening of historical texts brought to life by familiar voices. Come and enjoy an enlivening of the past that has many resonances for today. Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui- Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, and Jennifer Ward-Lealand.
Doors open at 5pm for drinks and nibbles, readings begin at 6pm.
Book your tickets
Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.
https://events.humanitix.com/copy-of-letters-out-loud
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.
https://turnbullfriends.org.nz/research-grant/
label: Community & Culture

description:
Live & Work in Japan! Q&A Evening with JET Programme Alumni, Have you ever wanted to live and work in Japan?
Come talk
to some people who've done it!
Every year, a diverse range of New Zealanders representing a variety of backgrounds, ages, interests, and cultures start a life-changing adventure in Japan-and next year that could include you!
With applications for the New Zealand JET Programme around the corner, you may have questions about what it's actually like to be sent off to live and teach in Japan for a year or more!
The JET Alumni Association of Wellington, in coordination with The Embassy of Japan, have organised a casual evening event for prospective applicants to ask those questions, and hear some stories to help you make a better decision about if the JET Programme is right for you.
Q&A event details
Date: 6th October 2025
Time: 17:30 - 19:30
Location: Yoshi Sushi & Bento (Press Hall, Willis Street)
Doors open from 5:30, with Q&A starting from 6:00.
Enjoy free
courtesy of Yoshi Sushi & Bento.
(Drinks, including Japanese
will also be available for purchase).
Admission to the event is FREE!
So come along and bring your friends
to this great opportunity to meet a handful of the thousands of Kiwis who've taken part in this programme over the past 40 years
Anyone interested in applying is welcome to attend!

What is the Japan Exchange Teaching (JET) Programme, you ask?
The JET Programme is an overseas employment opportunity to live and work in Japan for a year or more! You could soon head abroad on the adventure of a lifetime, and get paid for it!
Programme criteria includes the following-are you:
A New Zealand citizen?
Already graduated?
Or will have your Bachelor's Degree/Teaching Diploma conferred by early July 2026?
Interested in international activities?
Interested in teaching English to young people and living in Japan?

Positions available:
Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
ALTs help the Japanese foreign language teachers in class and help prepare teaching materials and class activities. They may assist in English language clubs and other extra-curricular activities. Knowledge of Japanese is not required to be an ALT.
Coordinator for International Relations (CIR)
CIRs work in local government offices and are involved in international activities, which might include editing publications, translation work, advising on the planning and implementation of exchange programmes, and interpreting at international events. A functional knowledge of written and spoken Japanese is required to be a CIR.
For more information about the New Zealand JET Programme, visit:
https://www.nz.emb-japan.go.jp/itpr_en/jet.html
https://www.facebook.com/JETProgrammeNZ/
We hope to see you there!

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour, Makara Churches and Historic Cottage Tour
The Makara Churches St Matthias and St Patricks date back to the 1800's. Monk Cottage built in 1867 is used as a local musuem for the area.

The churches and cottage will be open over one weekend from 10am till 3pm for people to visit. They are all within walking distance of each other.

Local people will be on site to talk to visitors. The cottage has information about early settlement of the area. St Patricks church has beautiful stained glass windows dedicated to early settlers. St Matthias has a graveyard where the early settlers are buried.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/makara-churches-and-historic-cottage-tour/


Health & Safety:
No particular health and safety issues apart from possibly someone tripping on an entry step. None of the buildings have difficult entryways, only 2 or 3 steps to get inside.

The road outside is quite busy at weekends so care must be taken getting in and out of cars if parked outside the grounds. There is plenty of parking inside the venue area off the road.

Saturday 22nd November. Marlborough Events Centre

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.

description:
Monthly Life Drawing, Come along and have a go at portraiture with our koha life drawing sessions, hosted monthly at the Gallery.

With a mix of timed short and long poses, you are invited to bring your own materials or use the basic supplies we provide.

The sessions run from 2 pm to 4 pm—please arrive early to set up. We'll take a short kaputī break halfway through. This is a koha event, with all contributions going directly to our models. Friends and whānau are welcome!

Interested in modeling? Contact us—we're always looking for sitters. Everyone is welcome to join!

Accessibility Information: The New Zealand Portrait Gallery is an accessible venue, all on one level. There is an accessible wharepaku at the back of the venue. The gallery has automatic sliding doors and glass doors that can be pushed or pulled to enter. We have a wheelchair available for use within the gallery, and there is low stool seating throughout. If you have any questions regarding accessibility or if there is something we could do to make your visit easier, please get in touch.

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

NAWIC 2025 Annual General Meeting, Join us for NAWIC’s 2025 AGM on Wednesday, 15 October.
The AGM is your opportunity to:
Hear about NAWIC’s progress and plans for the year ahead
Have your say on key decisions shaping our organisation
Connect with fellow members and industry peers
Celebrate 30 years of NAWIC and the collective impact we’ve made
Whether you’re a long-time member or new to NAWIC, your voice matters. Together, we’re shaping an equitable construction sector where women are empowered to thrive.
We look forward to seeing you there.
If you are unable to attend in person, please register your apology here:
NAWIC AGM 2025 Apology
Start time: 5.30pm arrival for a 6.00pm AGM kick-off.

 Come as you are - snacks will be provided

description:
National Library 60th Birthday Open Home, Here’s to 60 years! Your National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa is turning 60 and we’re opening our doors in Wellington to invite you, your whānau and communities to celebrate with us.
Come along to view our collections up close, take part in activities and join guided tours of the He Tohu exhibition and our collection stores.
Our curators, librarians, archivists and conservators will share some of their favourite collection items and take visitors behind the scenes of the Library. There will be tours of He Tohu, a chance to help build a replica waka and a kids’ corner to keep the whānau entertained. At 2pm, we’ll be celebrating with cake.
Our friends at City Gallery Wellington will be open from 1pm to 4pm.
Experience your taonga
View a display of our collections from the National Library and the Alexander Turnbull Library, featuring taonga from books, comics, manuscripts, photos and more.
Learn about what we collect, how we collect and how you can make the Library your whare through making the most of our services and connecting with our collections. Drop in to chat with Library staff, learn more about our work and get up close with the collections.
Build a waka with friends
Help build the replica voyaging waka Whakaura and learn how Māori and Pacific peoples used their knowledge and navigational expertise to sail their amazing waka across one-third of the earth’s surface.
***Join a guided tour***
Explore our back of house — Take a special guided tour of our collection repositories and learn more about how we preserve the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand. Don’t miss out on this very rare opportunity to take a peek behind the scenes and see some exciting taonga in our collection stores.
Tours are 45 minutes and booking is essential as spaces are limited. Please email us to reserve your place — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz.
***Take a tour of He Tohu***
No booking required. Join our friendly kaiārahi for a guided tour of our exhibition He Tohu and view the three iconic constitutional documents that are shaping Aotearoa New Zealand:
*1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
*1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
*1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
History of the National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa: The National Library was formed in 1965 when the General Assembly Library, the Alexander Turnbull Library and the National Library Service (comprising the Country Library Service and the School Library Service) were brought together by the National Library Act 1965. For the past 60 years, we’ve continued to grow and evolve our collections and services.

description:
Neurodivergent Speed Dating 20-35, 35-50, Neurodivergent Speed Dating 20-35, 35-50
Looking to meet new friends to hang out with, or maybe find love in a comfortable, respectful environment? Join us for a speed dating event designed specifically for autistic adults in Wellington!

This inclusive and sensory-considerate evening is all about meaningful conversations and low-pressure socializing. Whether you’re looking for friendship, romance, or just a fun evening out, this is your chance to connect in a space designed with your needs in mind.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

Accessibility and Comfort:
We’re committed to making this event as accessible and welcoming as possible. Sensory-friendly spaces, quiet zones, and fidget-friendly items will be available. There will also be conversation prompts on the table. Let us know any additional accommodations you may need when registering.

Who Can Attend:
All genders and sexualities are welcome to come and mingle and meet others for friendship but the speed dating part of this evening works best for heterosexual people.

Nourish at Home 2025, Nourish at Home 2025
Welcome to Nourish at Home 2025 - a day of fun, touring beautiful homes in the Eastbourne area, enjoying local hospitality all while supporting Nourish - who supply food hampers to families in need across the Wellington Region at Christmas. Your day will begin at the Eastbourne Sports and Services club, where you will receive your tour map, goodie bag - grab a coffee and some home baking to set you up for the first half of the tour. Then grab your lunch -either the delicious salad bowl (chicken/veg/vegan options) supplied by ESSC eats for $15, or you are welcome to visit one of Eastbourne's fabulous cafe's. After refreshments, you will complete your second half of the tour, and then return to the ESSC for a complimentary glass of bubbles and our raffle. Raffle prizes are starting to roll in - we have many wonderful supporters and donors, so please check back in to this event page for updates!

description:
November Full Moon Drumming (10th year anniversary), Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
This upcoming gathering marks our 10th year anniversary. Over 10 years many people from all walks of life have joined and participated, adding to the collective co-creation. Each and every one has made this gathering what it is! We'd like to thank you all and to extend an invitation for a potluck-style birthday celebration from 5pm on Wednesday 5th of November, with Bday cake and lighting the fire at around 7pm. Come along, everyone is welcome!
If this is your first time, make sure to read the full event description bellow:
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising
label: Community & Culture

description:
O-fficial Sneak Peak, You’re Invited to our ‘O-fficial Sneak
P
k’…..

Bring your friends, bring your curiosity, and come celebrate this new chapter with us, we can’t wait to welcome you in!

- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

description:
Our Fair Ladies, Our Fair Ladies
Embark on a journey through the history buried in Karori Cemetery with our tour showcasing the remarkable lives of Wellington’s women.

This tour offers a unique opportunity to celebrate the resilience, creativity and empowerment of women at a time when a woman couldn’t have a bank account in her own name. You’ll hear the stories of women who had a range of interesting occupations.

Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women’s lives in early Wellington.


Booking is REQUIRED.

Cost: $10

Booking info here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/our-fair-ladies-tour/


Health & Safety:
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.

While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.

Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
Our Lady's Home of Compassion, Our Lady's Home of Compassion
Join us for a tour of the newly listed Category 1 Historic Place, The Chapel of Our Lady of Compassion and Resting Place of Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert.

Three thirty minute tours will be offered over the course of each morning. Each tour will include information about the history of the building, the meanings behind the stained glass windows, and the significance of the site as an ongoing place of worship for the wider Compassion community.

Participants will have the opportunity to visit the final Resting Place of Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert who founded the Sisters of Compassion, the only religious order born in Aotearoa New Zealand. Come and experience the rich history and spirituality that are embedded in these sacred places.


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/our-ladys-home-of-compassion/


Health & Safety:
If arriving by foot, we encourage guests to stay within the painted white lines and to avoid walking through the carpark. In case of a fire or earthquake, emergency evacuation procedures and meeting points will be clearly communicated.

Staff will ensure interior tour areas are clear of hazards that may cause harm or tripping. Our gardens and pathways are clearly marked. In the case of injury, staff have valid First Aid certification.

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
PANEL TALK: BALLROOM CULTURE, Ballroom is a queer subculture. The Ballroom scene today was created by Black and Latinx trans women in the late 1960s in Harlem, New York. Since then, ballroom has taken over the world with scenes in Europe, Asia, Africa, South America and Oceania.
The Aotearoa Ballroom scene was ignited by Māori and MVPFAFF+ youth in Tāmaki Makaurau over 10 years ago, and has since inspired other leaders across the motu to forge their own Ballroom communities in their respective cities. 
In preparation for The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, hear from influential figures who have made significant contributions to their own scenes. With international Icons and Legends coming to Aotearoa for the first time, there has never been a better time to learn and enhance our own knowledge and experience of Ballroom. 
Featuring ballroom leaders Arturo Mulan (NYC, USA), Matyouz Royalty (Paris, EU), Jaycee Iman (Auckland, NZ), Karamera Marama and Romé Marama.
Panellists
Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the International House of Miyake-Mugler) (he/him) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the beating heart of Ballroom, NYC. Arturo has been involved in Ballroom since 1996 and has established himself as a visionary choreographer and community leader, with the title of NYC father of the international mainstream House of Miyake Mugler. His influence spans competitive wins, global workshops, and has dedicated his time to bringing diverse artistry into ballroom culture, and ballroom culture into diverse arts opportunities; such as Legendary - Season 2 (HBO Max), Brooklyn Nets performances, Cats the Jellicle Ball on Broadway and more.
Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the International House of Gorgeous Gucci) (he/she/they) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the Paris Ballroom scene and is the creator of the ‘Fashion Killa’ category. They discovered voguing and ballroom culture in 2009 during a trip to New York which they believe changed their life. Their impact within ballroom spans several categories: Commentator vs Commentator, Hands Performance, Runway and Fashion categories. Matyouz has become a staple commentator and music artist within the ballroom community, with a repertoire of modelling and influencer opportunities in their resumé.
Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman aka Jaycee Tanuvasa (she/her) is an inter-disciplinary Sāmoan artist and choreographer of fa’afafine, femme queen & trans experience. Born and raised in South Auckland, Tāmaki Makaurau, her work is firmly rooted in community as she places autonomy and story sovereignty at the core of each of her projects. She celebrates the fullness of young, queer, brown life and works collaboratively to create empowering and responsive reflections of this across a range of media such as theatre, film and activations.
Founding Mother Karamera Marama (he/they) is an emerging multi-disciplinary, queer and Māori artist professing in Graphic Design, Dance and Performance Arts. They are the Co-Founding Mother of the trailblazing Kiki House of Marama, Co-Director of Pōneke-based queer arts collective OVĀ and member of the Aotearoa Ballroom council. Karamera has been involved in Ballroom since 2020 competing in Performance and Fashion categories and winning numerous grand prizes across Aotearoa & so-called Australia respectfully; most notably within Vogue Fem categories.
Founding Mother Romé Marama (he/him) whakapapa to Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Kahungunu, Ngāti Hineuru, and Ngāti Tūwharetoa. He is an emerging multi-disciplinary performing artist, as well as the Co-Founding Mother of the House of Marama and Co-Founding Director of OVĀ. For the past five years, he has been a prominent figure in Aotearoa Ballroom, both competing and facilitating events. Renowned in the RUNWAY category, Romé has secured multiple Grand Prize titles across Aotearoa and so-called Australia.
Facilitator: Kasi Marama (he/him/barb) 
Kasi Valu ('Eua, Ma'ufanga, Lapaha / Tonga) Full-Time sergeant of Gag city #Barbz Part-Time hater of the Rihanna #Navy and Casual staff member of the #Beyhive. Retired Hater of the #swifties and founding member of Azealia Banks support group. Actor, Writer, and Producer. His work currently centres on the experiences, wit, complexities, and universality of Pacific peoples, all whilst being an all-time fia botz, professional guesser and self-deprecating in this miserable world.

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

must obtain the garden owner's consent if you wish to take cuttings.

Practices of Compassion, Explore the practices of the Sisters of Compassion then and now, through the lens of the historic crèche and the ongoing mahi of the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Learn about the historic crèche established by Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert and the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, now known as the Pukeahu Education Centre. Hear the stories of the practices of compassion led by the Sisters in early 20th century Wellington.

Then, walk over to the Compassion Soup Kitchen on Tory Street where the Sisters of Compassion and their co-workers are still supporting people with kai, aroha and much more.

This programme offers a unique look at the past and present practices of compassion emanating from these two influential and historic Wellington sites. Please bring along a cash koha for the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Session times:

Thursday 23 October 12pm — 1:30pm

Booking is required.

The Compassion Soup Kitchen is a two-minute walk from the Pukeahu Education Centre.
Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather.

description:
Pride In Place: Creating a Community Walk Tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please sign-up here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
label: Community & Culture

Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

description:
RETHINK Fundraising Wellington 2026, INTRODUCING AOTEAROA'S NEWEST FUNDRAISING EVENT: RETHINK
RETHINK Fundraising 2026 invites you and your team to look at your fundraising programme from a fresh perspective.
Join us for a full day of inspirational talks, panel discussions and practical workshops that will leave you energised, AND armed with a toolkit of actionable learnings to take your fundraising to the next level.
Date: Thursday, 5 March
Venue: Mākaro Room, Wharewaka Function Centre
Time: 8am-5pm
Cost: $249NZD (exc GST)*
Contact: Anna Shere anna@changeand.co
*If you prefer to pay via invoice, please email accounts@changeand.co.
THE PROGRAM
For those of you who joined us for RETHINK Auckland 2025, please note that RETHINK Wellington will feature many of the same sessions from that event, with a few additions to the program and two new guest speakers.
Branding blindspots 
In a sector focused on campaigns, conversion, and compliance, brand is often overlooked. But brand isn’t just a logo or a nice story. It’s how people feel about supporting you. And if it's not clear, engaging, or modern – you’re leaving both money and meaning on the table. This presentation from Tim Dove at re:brand will challenge a few norms and show some examples of it being done well. He’ll get you thinking about your organisation and how you can ensure you’re avoiding the ‘brand blindspot’. 
Rethinking charity comms 
When it comes to getting people enthused about our cause, too often we focus on the what rather than the why. Worse, we risk boring our audience to death with earnest, organisation-centric communications which neither inspire nor instruct. Dominique Antarakis from Change&Co will show you a new and fun way to look at your charity comms for maximum engagement and donor retention.  
Workshop 1 
Facilitated workshop which will provide the opportunity to take the learnings from the morning sessions and give you the practical branding and comms tools to take back to your organisation - and transform your fundraising! 
Lunch break  
Take a break, mix and mingle, and enjoy a fabulous lunch selection.
Data, behaviour, and hyper-personalisation 
This presentation from MIMO/DATAM will show you how to transform raw data into meaningful, multi-channel interactions across email, SMS, voice, and direct mail - all from a single platform. This session will challenge how you think about personalisation - it’s not just about names in subject lines or open rates in eDMs, it’s about burning down the old school campaigns and rebuilding around behaviour, context and connection. 
Lessons from the legacy frontlines 
Based on interviews with practitioners from organisations large and small, this session shares unfiltered insights from Gift in Will managers who are doing the work every day—what's actually generating pledges, where they're getting stuck, and what they wish they'd known sooner. Through their collective wisdom, and guided by TEDIREX’s Martin Ruane, we'll explore the biggest challenges facing legacy programs today, the opportunities hiding in plain sight, and tactical takeaways that work for both beginners and experienced practitioners. 
Workshop 2 
Facilitated workshop which will provide the opportunity to take the learnings from the afternoon sessions and give you the practical personalisation and AI tools to ramp up acquisition and retention.  
CFRE ACCREDITATION
Full participation in RETHINK Fundraising is applicable for 7 points in Category 1.B -Education of the CFRE International application for initial certification and/or recertification.
EVENT PARTNERS
Change&Co, DATAM, mimo, re:brand and Tedirex. Special thanks to FIA/FINZ for their support of the day.
RETHINK has been designed by fundraisers for fundraisers, and we’re keen to make sure you get the most out of the day. We promise no hard-sell, no product placement, and a 100% satisfaction guarantee.
The idea is for you to leave at the end of the day with a roadmap to greater donor engagement – and a sense of renewed energy for what lies ahead.

description:
Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion, Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion
Te Kāhui Tika Tangata Human Rights Commission is proud to host this discussion for International Day of Older Persons in partnership with Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa (formerly LAGANZ).

Panelists from the Wellington rainbow community - 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗶 𝗠𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗹, 𝗞𝗲𝘃𝗶𝗻 𝗛𝗮𝘂𝗻𝘂𝗶 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗟𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘆 𝗖𝗼𝘄𝗮𝗻 - will join Chief Commissioner Dr Stephen Rainbow for the discussion and a brief Q and A session. 🌈🎙️💫

Prudence Walker, Disability Rights Commissioner and Rainbow rights spokesperson will host the panel.

𝗣𝗿𝗲-𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗱𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴. Pre-register here: https://events.humanitix.com/rainbow-elders-our-aspirations-our-well-being-our-rights-a-panel-discussion 🎟️🎟️🎟️

The discussion runs from 10.30am to 11.30am.

NZSL will be available. The venue is accessible.

Light refreshments will be available.

A recording of the discussion may be made available afterwards via the Commission's website.
❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🩷

description:
SS Hikitia Steam Crane Showcase and Ship Tours, SS Hikitia Steam Crane Showcase and Ship Tours
Come see a nearly 100-year-old steam crane in action! The Hikitia and her crew will be operating a floating crane to showcase technology from the age of steam

You may already know the SS Hikitia as one of the world's oldest floating steam cranes, but did you know that the crane still works?

Our dedicated group of volunteers will be undertaking demonstration lifts with Hikitia’s crane and also opening the ship for tours.

Come see what it takes to operate a heavy piece of lifting equipment from the golden era of steam!


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/ss-hikitia-steam-crane-showcase-and-ship-tours/


Health & Safety
During operation of the crane there will be no members of the public on board the vessel, an exclusion zone set up around the ship, and a crew member on the wharf side providing commentary about the ship and the operations.

During ship tours, there will be 2 tour guides with each group (maximum of 10 people per group) and a full H&S induction will be undertaken. The ship is equipped with first aid equipment and one of the guides will be first aid trained.

description:
Sapphic Speed Dating Dinner Party, This 4-course sapphic experience is more like a big gay dinner party than a traditional speed dating event (it even features fabulous local performer, Ginger Velour, as the MC to guide you through the evening!) With each course in the meal, you’ll switch tables and sit with a new group of 4-6 cute strangers—although it’s Wellington, so no guarantees it won’t be your ex. There will be conversation question cards on the tables if you get stuck on what to say, but your best chats will come from just being yourself!

And don’t stress about asking a hottie for their number if you’re shy—we’ve designed this experience to be as easy and low-stakes as possible. Each attendee will have a paper bag “mailbox” that you can slip a note into at the end of the night to avoid any awkward face-to-face interactions. Whether you both want to connect after that is up to you, but this is the time to shoot your shot!

After purchasing a ticket, you will be sent a short questionnaire. Please fill it out promptly! This helps the organisers place you in groups with similar interests so you have the best chance at finding what you’re looking for.

No TERFs no SWERFs. This event is open to all people 18+ who identify as sapphic/lesbian/queer. Bi, pan, questioning, and ace folks are all welcome.

Additional info:
- Most dietary requirements can be accommodated by the amazing chefs at Everybody Eats. Please include your dietaries when prompted in the questionnaire.
- Accessibility: Everybody Eats is up a flight of stairs and does not have wheelchair access. There are gender neutral bathrooms inside the restaurant and all chairs have backs. If you'd prefer not to stand up and move around the space after each course, please email the organiser with any mobility requests at goldenhourgigz@gmail.com

description:
September Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

description:
Site Visit - Holcim Readymix Wellington, Ever wondered how concrete is made?
Join us on Thursday 4th September, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of the Holcim Readymix NZ plant. Grab a behind the scenes look at:
 🏗️ The Process: How raw materials like cement, aggregates & water are mixed to create concrete
⚙️ Batching & Mixing: How mix designs are selected and adjusted
📏 Quality: Quality controls & production oversight, including testing & slumping
🚚 Dispatch:  Loading, scheduling & delivery coordination
🌱 Sustainability: Low carbon products and how Holcim is approaching driving a circular economy
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Thursday, 4th September, 1pm
📍 LOCATION: 121 Centennial Highway, Ngauranga Gorge
🚗PARKING: Parking is tricky! Please carpool if possible, limited parking is available at the front of the Holcim offices (2 car parks) and one more at the top car park. Alternatively, bus route #1 stops off at Ngauranga Gorge (Kiwi Point) stop and is a short walk away
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 10 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, glasses (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 ABOUT HOLCIM: Holcim is a global company across Europe, Asia, Pacific, Latin America, Middle East and Africa.  Holcim NZ  is a leading supplier of cement, aggregates and ready-mix concrete in New Zealand dating back to 1888. You may have noticed their big silos on the Centre Port (near the Interislander). Holcim have a network of plants throughout New Zealand, and one of their main missions is around sustainability, where they actively promote low-carbon concrete solutions, including their premium range ECOPact ECOplanet.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Site Visit - Studio of Pacific Architecture - Te Aro Double-Header!, Join us on Wednesday 20 August, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of two very different but geographically close projects in Te Aro. The National War Memorial and FPC Martin Square are both undergoing major refurbishment - join us for a look behind the scenes!
National War Memorial: Refurbishing a Wellington Icon
Step behind the scaffolding and witness the National War Memorial Project – a complex seismic strengthening project where heritage sensitivity is of utmost importance. With construction works being carried out by Maycroft Construction, join us for the rare opportunity to explore a significant piece of the capital’s cultural fabric.
Known to many as the backdrop of ANZAC Day commemorations, this national memorial is undergoing a meticulous refurbishment to ensure its legacy endures for generations to come.
 What’s Happening On Site:
Seismic strengthening of the tower and bell frame 
Stone remediation to preserve its historic façade
Asphalt roofing works
The real challenge? Balancing modern engineering with heritage preservation. Every upgrade is being carried out with deep respect for the building’s historical significance.

Then, just around the corner, we will move on to another refurbishment project – at a much different scale and for a very different purpose!
 FPC Martin Square: from Workshop to Office Space
Leading industrial design-and-build specialists First Principles Constructors are celebrating seven years of innovation with a bold move - into a brand-new headquarters in central Wellington. Take a look inside the transformation of a former engineering workshop into the new HQ for FPC. With exposed services, raw materials, and an industrial aesthetic, this compact yet clever refurbishment shows how much can be achieved in a small urban footprint. Construction is well underway by Aoraki Construction, with completion coming up in September.
What’s Happening On Site:
•     Structural steel installation, new roofing, cladding, a new concrete mezzanine slab
•     Interior fit-out works
•     Full building services upgrades
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Wednesday, 20th August, meet at 2.45pm for a 3.00pm start at the National War Memorial
📍 LOCATION: Meet at the National War Memorial (19 Buckle Street) to explore this site first. We will then walk over to 21 Martin Square as a group, for the next site visit.
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 18 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots. (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 🎉 After the site visits, unwind with drinks and nibbles sponsored by First Principles Constructors at a nearby venue (TBC) – a chance to connect, reflect, and chat all things design and construction.
🧡 Huge thanks to Studio of Pacific Architecture, Aoraki Construction, Maycroft Construction, and First Principles Constructors for teaming up to make this event possible.
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

Snacks Amore: Rainbow night - WOAP snack based speed bonding, IRL! Zero dating apps required, We warmly invite you to ditch the dating apps for one delicious night of snack-based bonding. Speed friending is heartedly encouraged along side the serious speed daters so there is no need to miss out on the fun!
Amuse Snack Bar is the new Euro-inspired aperitivo haven on Willis Street. We are making our WOAP debut and singling out the foodie LGBTQIA+ singles and mingles. WE pride ourselves on providing the warmest of hospitality at Amuse Snack bar.
Our gorgeous hosts will provide musical entertainment and a match of perfect Italian wines and aperitivo bevvies. Your heart and bellies will be equally full tonight!
You'll enjoy mini speed dates with our crowd of foodies! Plus 6 courses of Italian-inspired snacklets – cacio e pepe, agrodolce, parmigiana, porchetta, and cantucci, all served in perfect bite-sized form.
A glass of Lambrusco kicks off the evening, with a cheeky mini tiramisu maritozzo to take home and curl up with on the couch.
Our event kicks off at 6.30pm with a drink and a mingle before we split into two areas of the restaurant for the serious dating

description:
Speed Dating 30-43, 40-55, Speed Daters will be split into 2 age groups which will run simultaneously. There will be opportunity to mix with the other group during the break. We will have a private area of the venue for this event. Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Speed dating does not have to be stressful or frightening; you will be pleasantly surprised how fun and positive it is.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!

description:
Speed Puzzle fundraiser for CanSurvive Dragon Boat Club, Join us for CanSurvive’s very first speed puzzling event!
Each team receives the same 500-piece puzzle and races to complete it as fast as they can.
You can have up to three people in a team and there’s a two-hour time limit.
Our unique puzzle design is top secret and stays covered until the timer starts and you can rip into it! What we can tell you is that we’ve created a beautiful new design in collaboration with New Zealand artist Lori Davis, and it’s been produced by New Zealand’s premium puzzle company, PieceHouse.
The best bit… anyone can join in! Whether you’re a speedy puzzler or prefer to take your time over a cuppa, you won’t regret giving it a go.
So, what are you waiting for? You can puzzle solo or team up with family and friends to meet like-minded puzzlers - and a few dragonboaters! - for a fun afternoon you won’t forget.
As well as the main event, we’ll have bonus puzzles on the go for the super speedy, there’s a kitchen on site for refreshments and there’ll be a raffle and CanSurvive goodies to buy, including our new puzzle - because why share the puzzle that's included with your ticket when every team member could have their own?

description:
Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour, Spring Floral Display Accessible Self-Drive Tour
Gather your friends, whānau, or neighbours who might find it tricky to access the gardens, and enjoy a relaxing, self-guided drive through a spectacular spring floral display at Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.

Simply drive along the one-way route past the Display Garden and soak in the colours of tulips, forget-me-nots, dianthus, primulas, chrysanthemums, daffodils, and more.

How it works:
• No registration needed — just turn up and enter through the Glenmore Street gates.
• Follow the designated one-way route through the gardens, keeping within your vehicle at all times.
• Exit through the West/White Gate to return to Glenmore Street.
• Feel free to enjoy the route as many times as you like during opening hours.

Please note:
• Drive slowly (maximum 10 km/h), and watch carefully for pedestrians, especially children.
• Stay in your vehicle for the entire tour to keep everyone safe and comfortable.
• Follow all signage and do not turn around within the garden grounds.

This event is self-guided and unstaffed. If you need assistance during your visit, please call 04 499 1400.
For enquiries, email or call 04 499 1400.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Te Kurae Community Awards, @everyone
Next Sunday we are having a pre awards party to celebrate the legends in our community.
30th November 3-6 at DVB.
Live music from
- Tokowhà is an original and covers band .
- Izzy is an amazing artist covering original and covers.
- SimonByrneSax Expressive, energetic and unique
- ATB Is An Acoustic trio of feminine power.


Monday 1st Dec keep your eyes peeled for a yellow sunburst box from Double Vision Brewing (it's there new box for the up and coming cider) I grabbed a few as they are really eye catching and perfect for my needs. We are using them as BALLOT BOXES.
Shaking up the awards this year as I'm on crutches after surgery and want more locals involved and benefiting from The Kurae Community Awards.
So let's start. If you want to donate please reach out to me, we would love to have you on board. Keen for a hairdresser to help with Let there be pamper or any sponsorship. I went shopping today, spent eeck a few hundred on spot prizes and bits for YOU and our future winners.
Here's the deal. We are having 8 categories this year. 7 will be run through the ballot which will be located at New World Miramar , @miramar library, Wellington Compounding Pharmacy @Seatoun community hall, Bridgestone Tyre Centre Miramar with others to come.
YELLOW Boxes will be out from the 1st December. Pens and paper will be there and we ask ONE VOTE PER DAY PER CATEGORY.
These categories are:
1. BEST TEACHER.
(This is the ONLY award where they don't have to live within the peninsula, tho MUST teach here). Sponsored by Bridgestone Tyre Center Miramar and Double Vision Brewing.
2. OFFICE SHOUT.
(Nominate a office or place of business within the peninsula for an amazing LUNCH shout from our mates Souvlaki at Acropolis valued at $100
3. Most Helpful neighbour
(Nominate and tell us why you have the best neighbour and never know they may take you. Sponsored by Chocolate Frog Cafe and a wee parcel of real chocolates to the winner and a sneaky 6 pack from DVB OR A Vino from us. You decide!!
4. Let there be Pamper.
(We have a female and male edition)
Sponsored by Myself. @MiramarLiquorland with a basket of skincare for her.
Hoi.
5. Most deserving Neighbour
(Some tickets are limited by the issuer )
Sponsored by Miramar New World with an amazing gift hamper.
Staglands Wildlife Reserve & Cafe with a family day pass.
Wētā Workshop with a family pass.
ThermaShield with a petrol voucher.
@Wellington International Airport has generously donated biscuits and chips to be shared.
DVB is putting in a 6 pack for Dad and of course we will get mum a vino.
6. Friendliest Business
(Nominate a Peninsula business that goes above and beyond)
Last year's winner is NOT eligible (Sorry Palmers )
Sponsored by Parrotdog Bar with a voucher valued at $100.
I am sure we can also round up a few treats also.
7. A parents break.
(Nominate a parent that deserves a rest from Housework and the lovely gals Shimmer & Shine will come be domestic goddesses and clean for you.
@Litte Sprig Seatoun
8. Animal Antics.
(This will be our ONLY ONLINE AWARD)
SO Share a photo of your precious pet and go into the draw for an amazing gift from Animates Kilbirnee and the team there.
We also have 3 Volunteer awards tho they will be chosen by our 3 local community centers and sponsored by the team at Parrotdog.
If you come next Sunday you may receive a mini pamper pack. Male and females. So grab the teenagers!!
I brought a couple of LEGO boxes for our younger ones.
Wellington International Airport have given us bags of biscuits and chippies. And I brought over 50 chocolate bars.
Thank you to Duncan Emerson Builders for your support and a beautiful friend whom wishes to remain Anonymous.
And the team at Wellington Compounding Pharmacy .
So keep your eyes peeled from the 1st December for the YELLOW BOX with The Kurae Community Awards on it.

description:
Te Rā o Waitangi - Waitangi Day at the National Library, Join us this Te Rā o Waitangi and learn about the hītori (histories) of the 1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi.

Can you tell which Te Tiriti sheets are made from animal skin? Can you find Hōne Heke’s signature? Did rangatira (chiefs) in Te-Whanganui-a-Tara sign Te Tiriti?

There will be fun activities for tamariki (children), rangatahi (youth), and pakeke (adults) throughout the day.

Join a reorua (bilingual) tour to learn more about Te Tiriti, brush up your whakahua te reo Māori (pronunciation), sing waiata, or add your own tohu (mark) to the collective tiriti canvas. Watch film footage compiled by Ngā Taonga Sound & Vision or test your Te Tiriti knowledge with a quiz.

From 9am to 4pm we will have taonga that relate to the signing of Te Tiriti o Waitangi on display in the Alexander Turnbull Library.

HOME Café will be open until 2pm, and City Gallery Wellington will be open until 4pm.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The 'FEM QUEENS STAND ON BUSINESS' Aftermath, The Marama Fem Queens are taking over and for this Aftermath they are standing on business.
Come celebrate them, buy them a drink and give the girls their flowers!
This Aftermath is an acknowledgment of the mahi and contributions the Marama FQs have each made within our House of Marama whānau and across their ballroom journeys.
All donations will go towards the Marama Fem Queen’s surgeries and gender-affirming care fund.
#MARAMWAH
WHEN: Sun 5th Oct, 7.30pm - Late
WHERE: The Grand, 69 Courtenay Place, Te Aro, Wellington (NZ) 6011
TICKETS: General Admission $25, Extra Aroha Ticket $30+ (Door sales $30)
TICKET RELEASE: This Aftermath will prioritise Ballroom community access until public release WED 1st OCT (2025) 12PM (NZST). Please message @houseofmarama for the community access code.
DJs: MIAMIA and KAYSEEYUH
JUDGES & COMMENTATORS: TBA.
CATEGORIES
F*g Out with a Twist: Calling all f*ags!! First, serve us the f*g that you are and then twist into BQ realness. Are you verse?!
Hands Performance 
Fashion Killa 
Lip Sync: It’s time for you to lip-sync for your GP!! Let’s throw it back to the 90’s and early 2000’s. Get your 10’s to a 90’s track and if those lips and hips don’t lie, you’ll battle to an early 2000’s song for the GP.
*10’s - each song will play, we’ll countdown until we play the next track. 
FQ Sex Appeal: Can you turn it on without taking it off?! Appeal to the judges and sell sex. But remember, clothes must stay on.
OTA Runway
OTA Performance 
Follow @houseofmarama on Instagram to keep up to date with the Fem Queens Stand On Business Aftermath event and details.
