description:
The Fabulous Carmen Walk Tour: Tea, Toasties and Trade, ** FREE, but please register at https://walktours.nz/book

Entrepreneur, entertainer, madam and mayoral candidate Carmen Rupe was based in Wellington for less than 15-years but has left us a rich legacy of memories and inspiring moments.
Join us on this free 90-minute community walk-tour as we trace Carmen's Wellington years (1967-1980). We'll visit some of the remaining inner-city business locations and imagine some of those that are no longer here: Le Balcon, Carmen's International Coffee Lounge, The Peacock, Cleopatra's Coffee Lounge, Carmen's Bazaar, The Gazebo massage parlour, The Cottage brothel and Carmen's Curio Shop.

Learn about Carmen's landmark 1966 court case, her race to become Mayor of Wellington in the 1970s, and how she supported and offered a safe harbour to Wellington's Takatāpui LGBTI Rainbow communities.

“I would more or less hypnotise all my guests like a black widow spider and trap my clients caught in my web. As people left my coffee lounge at 6am or earlier I would splash them with Carmen’s exotic juice which meant that they would be back another night for more. The scent would guide them to me. Some would hear my voice calling like an eerie whisper from the depths of darkness.” [from Carmen’s autobiography]

Accessibility information: The tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to around 20 walkers.

Starts at the rugby sculpture, Jack Ilott Green, corner of Harris Street & Jervois Quay (just by Civic Square)
Ends: Upper Cuba Street

Cost: FREE
Please register (for walker numbers): https://walktours.nz/book/
DURATION: 90-minutes
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Festive Flyer, The Festive Flyer
Join us and celebrate Christmas with a delicious lunch and a day out on the train! Saturday 6th December 2025

Get into the festive spirit with Steam Incorporated—perfect for celebrating with colleagues, friends, and family!

Jump onboard our heritage train departing Wellington Station, and nestle down into your seats for a relaxing journey up the coast behind one of our heritage Da class locomotives.

After arriving at the private entry at Tatum, you'll take a short walk across the car park and follow the music into the Pavilion, where we settle in just in time for lunch!

Immerse yourself in a well-crafted meal, created by the talented chefs there. The menu is set to be a classic kiwi style Christmas buffet feast with all the trimmings!

There will be plenty to keep you entertained such as outdoor games, live music, and 2 dinner sittings, so there is plenty of time to tour Tatum, check out Tatum House, and relax in the gardens on the Tatum House Lawn with a drink. You will be advised of your sitting time prior to arrival.

Departing Tatum, climb on board, head to the Lounge Car, grab a drink from the bar and enjoy the journey home. This unforgettable ride hugs the dramatic coastline along the famed Kapiti escarpment, offering sweeping views of the Tasman Sea and rugged cliffs. It’s a rare chance to relive the golden age of rail in one of New Zealand’s most scenic rail corridors as the sun begins to set.

This excursion will be hauled by our 1955-built diesel electric locomotive, Da 1410, and consist of our steel carriages.

Fares (include your return train travel, meal and entertainment)
Adult 13+ yrs - $229
Child 2-12yrs - $189
Infant 0-2yrs - FREE

Thinking of a larger event, or your corporate Christmas Function?
We're pleased to be able to offer some fantastic packages for large groups, or corporate functions with our friends at Tatum. This all inclusive train ride and Christmas lunch combo is a great way to celebrate 2025 with your team! Please contact us via email or call us on 0800 783 264 for a personalized group package.

Please be at your boarding station minimum 10 minutes prior ready to roll, with your tickets, carriage letter and seating allocations at the ready.

Limited Mobility Disclaimer
Tatum does NOT have a platform. This means you must be able to board and disembark the train from ground level with little to no assistance.

Due to the age, design and nature of our heritage carriages, these are not suitable for passengers with limited mobility. If you have any concerns, please contact us on 0800 783 264 to discuss options with our bookings team!

All tickets and seating allocations are sent via email, within 48 hours prior to the departure of this excursion.

Prior booking is essential, make sure you reserve your spot now to avoid missing out on this experience.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Stories of Our Bodies Wellington [LGBTQIA+ cohort], We often believe we can know something about other people based on what we see of their bodies. Before we’re even conscious of it, we label, compartmentalise or judge - and it can be a real struggle to relish our own bodies when this judgment happens in front of a mirror. 
The Stories of Our Bodies is an affirming and liberating circle, firmly
held in dignity, that redirects this judgement towards positive body image and bodily autonomy. This workshop builds on the living lineage of Australian Radical Faerie elder Uncle Teacosy. It is shaped from gay men’s survival of the 90’s AIDS epidemic, evolved to uplift queer&trans communities and has been offered internationally by only one facilitator.
Each participant is invited into deep connection with their body and then in turn, we share the stories of our bodies from birth til now, removing as many articles of clothing as we choose. Stories often include histories of illness, injury, gender affirmation, addiction, aging, intentional modification, shape, ability or size
What stories can the marks and folds of a body tell when witnessed in belonging and respect? How can we uplift each story and every storyteller?
This circle is for participants from the Takatāpui, MVPFAFF+, LGBTQIA+ communities, active in engaged consent and includes partial or full nudity in a non-sexual atmosphere.
Your Facilitators: Eleven Greenstones and val smith
Eleven Greenstones (she/they, Pakeha) is a cultural worker, community educator, researcher, gardener and facilitator who seeks deep and fertile justice by cultivating rich soil and robust, adaptive communities. For three decades, Eleven has informed and performed behind a radio desk, on stage, in community centres and cultural hubs. Her work spans the Pacific Ocean including in Aotearoa, Australia, Timor Leste, China, Korea, Mongolia and the US: educating in high schools, AOD rehabs, hospitals, police stations, co-housing cooperatives, squatted warehouses, international language schools and mentoring in arts workshops and community gardens.
Eleven is a life-long student, recently in decolonial Fieldwork with Leah Manaema Avene and with Héctor Aristizábal, founder of ImaginAction. They’ve studied post-activism with fugitive philosopher Bayo Akomolafe, Generative Somatics and Undoing Racism® (People’s Institute for Survival and Beyond). They’ve been mentored by First Nations ecologists to work for a living planet, Undoing White Supremacy Austin (Texas) to design and deliver anti-racism ‘unlearning circles’ and by Radial Faerie elders to facilitate liberating spaces for the LGBTQIA+ community.
val smith (Pākehā, they/them) is a choreographic artist-researcher and educator based in Tāmaki Makaurau, Aotearoa. Their practice engages critical somatics and friendship-based collaboration to explore the socio-political dimensions of whiteness, queerness, and transness within the cultural context of Aotearoa. Recent performance work investigates more-than-human kinship, queer intimacies, and temporalities in relationship with marginal urban places.
val’s teaching and facilitation engages with community, secondary and tertiary learning environments. They have a Postgraduate Diploma in Dance and Drama Secondary Teaching, and have worked with kids, young people with disabilities, the Disability dance sector, older folks, as well as queer and trans communities. They teach somatic practices, improvisation, performance skills, critical dance, yoga, creative practice and research methodologies.
A recipient of the Arts Foundation Laureate Award (2019), val was also the 2016 Caroline Plummer Fellow at Te Whare Wānanga o Ōtākou, University of Otago, where they undertook a community dance project with the local queer community.

description:
Towards modernism: The Walter Cook collection at Te Papa, Towards modernism: The Walter Cook collection at Te Papa
Curator and author Justine Olsen will explore Te Papa’s Walter C. Cook Collection of Decorative Arts. Walter intended to trace modernism’s roots from the Arts and Crafts Movement to post-war designbut, but how did he achieve this aim?

Join us at the Library or online. Register for a Zoom link:

Modernism through the eyes of a collector
Between 1965 and 1990, collector Walter Cook built up an extensive collection of British and European decorative arts, mostly purchased in Wellington. In 1992 he gifted the collection to Te Papa, significantly adding to the museum’s holdings of international decorative arts.

In the research for her book, Towards Modernism: The Walter Cook Collection at Te Papa, Justine Olsen drew on Turnbull and National Library collections, including the Wises Street Directories and Papers Past, to understand market trends through the flow of design from Europe to the market in New Zealand.

In this talk, Justine will explore the story of the market and changing taste, both at the time of production and half a century later, when these objects were sought after by dealers and collectors.

The Walter C. Cook Collection of Decorative Arts
The collection was built up over a twenty-five-year period by Walter Cook, a discerning and determined collector of modest means. The glass, ceramic, and metal objects — by designers including Susie Cooper, Clarice Cliff, William De Morgan, Christopher Dresser, and Inge-Lise Koefoed — track the evolution of design from the Arts and Crafts movement through to the British and European modernism of the 1970s.

A Friends of the Turnbull Library event
The Friends of the Turnbull Library, Ngā Hoa o te Whare Pukapuka Turnbull, offers a monthly programme of free public talks. These talks are held in the National Library in Wellington and on Zoom. Some of these talks will be repeated in Auckland. The public programme highlights the work of researchers who draw on Turnbull material for their projects and staff who care for and research the collections.

About the speaker
Justine Olsen has been Curator of Decorative Art and Design at Te Papa Tongarewa the Museum of New Zealand, since 2009. Her special interests include late nineteenth and twentieth century design, and contemporary New Zealand craft especially ceramics and jewellery. With history curator Michael Fitzgerald, she developed the exhibition ‘Walter Cook: a collector’s quest’ in 2012.

Image: Justine Olsen, author of The Walter Cook Collection at Te Papa.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Tram 17 Inauguration (Fathers Day 2025), Join us at the Wellington Tramway Museum as we put our latest restoration project into active service at the museum!
Tram 17 was built in 1904 by the Wellington City Council Tramways as a four wheeled box (Palace) style tram. By 1917 the system had grown and 17 was rebuilt into its current form adding a set of trucks converting the tram to 8 wheels. Tram tram saw regular service until the 1940’s where it was eventually use for peak time travel, before being withdrawn in the late 50’s.
It was then sold, and taken to Bell road in Raumati on the Kapiti coast where it served as a beach hutt until the 80’s where it was donated to the Wellington tramway museum for display and eventual restoration.
2014 a conservation and restoration plan was put together, and the tram was shipped out to the Wheelwright Shop in the Wairarapa for a full body overhaul. It was transported back to the museum in 2017 and put on public display until new trucks (wheelsets) could be manufacturedby A&G price in Thames.
Since 2019 the tram has undergone new wiring, and extensive testing and running in and is now ready to take passengers along our museum.
Tram 17 is a wonderful achievement by all
Those involved, and we cannot wait to welcome you this Father’s Day to enjoy a ride on this heritage tram, saved from the scrap heap, and then saved again from rotting away.
Please note: We intend to run tram 17, however due to the nature and style of the tram, its operation is weather dependent. If we deem that the tram cannot run, we will advise accordingly.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse (8th & 9th Nov 2025), Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse (8th & 9th Nov 2025)
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

About this Event

This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm!
Come visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse between 11am-1pm as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.
"The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came. Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts. Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out."
Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.
We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Voice of Aroha Anniversary Gala 2025, ✨ Experience a Night of Celebration and Impact in Wellington! ✨
Join us at the Voice of Aroha Anniversary Gala on Saturday, November 1st, 2025, for an unforgettable evening of reflection, connection, and aroha. 🎉 Immerse yourself in inspiring stories, captivating performances, and the warmth of community — all while making a real difference in the lives of refugee and migrant communities across Aotearoa.
🌟 Voice of Aroha 6th Anniversary Gala 🌟
For six incredible years, Voice of Aroha has amplified untold voices, empowered youth, and brought people together through storytelling, leadership, and celebration.
💡 This year has been filled with achievements and new opportunities for our young people, but it has also been one of the toughest yet, with limited funding. To keep our mahi alive and ensure our youth continue to thrive, we need your support. Will you stand with us?
🗓️ Date: Saturday, November 1, 2025
🕕 Time: 6:00 PM – 9:00 PM
📍 Location: The Hub, Kelburn Campus (Te Herenga Waka – Victoria University of Wellington)
✨ What to Expect:
🌟 Inspiring youth voices
🌟 Beautiful cultural performances
🌟 Dinner with whānau for a great cause
🌟 Raffle tickets + prizes to be won 🎟️
🌟 A night of aroha, unity & impact
💫 Every ticket is a donation. Your generosity directly supports Voice of Aroha’s ongoing mahi — empowering youth, creating inclusive spaces, and ensuring refugee and migrant voices are heard, valued, and celebrated.
🎟️ Get your ticket today and be part of this milestone celebration! Together, we’ll ensure our mission not only continues but grows stronger, making a lasting difference for generations to come.

WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank, WINTER SERIES: Crop Swap Te Whanganui a Tara X Wellington Timebank
Crop Swap is a FREE heart-warming monthly community gathering to share what we have with each other. Think of it like a community garden potluck when each offering regardless of the amount adds up to a bounty.

Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share🌱

WHEN?
☕ Come along at 10:30am for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free @Peoples coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along.
Swapping kicks off from 11.00am.

WHERE?
You can find us in the community room on the ground floor of block C of the Newtown Park Apartments, 320 Mansfield St, Newtown, Wellington.

IDEAS OF WHAT TO BRING
🧡Bring a friend!
🍪Maybe you like baking?
🍋 Surplus lemons?
🌱excess seedlings
📖 Have garden books or magazines to destash?
🥬Too much silver beet going crazy?
🫘Left over seeds from summer to share?
💐Got some foraged flowers?

Crop Swap is the place for you!
Note; giving isn't necessary but we do welcome koha of help / waiata / pūtea towards costs like room hire / milaka etc.

description:
Walt Quizney @ 1852, Wellington, Hakuna Matata, it means no worries for the rest of your days. And we've got Saturday 20th Sept all figured out for you!
Join us at 7pm for a Supercalifragilisticexpialidocious evening of Quizney themed trivia at 1852 Pub & Kitchen, Wellington!
Sport your best costume, brush up on your movie knowledge (including Pixar) and get ready to put all those years of watching "Quizney" to good use. Oh, did we mention we're having a sing-a-long round where you'll need to remember the lyrics of your favourite song lyrics?
In true Gee Quiz fashion, we'll also have fantastically-fun bonus games including our legendary but stressful Alphabetical round, where your team will negotiate 26 fast-fire questions as the time tick down, plus Last Prince and Princess Standing and The Line Up!
This quiz would not be complete without you, so book tickets today. A team ticket (up to 6 players) is $90).
Booking link: https://www.trybooking.com/nz/YMK
***Minors must be accompanied with parent or legal guardian***

description:
Wave of Light 2025, Hōkai Tahi invites you to attend our Wave of Light memorial to remember all our babies gone too soon.
We'll gather at the Carrington Park Rotunda from 6.45pm for a 7pm candle lighting and minute of silence.
Bring along a candle to add to our memorial display - lanterns or jars are a good idea if it is breezy.
We'd love to see photos of your babies too.
Stay for a hot drink (provided) and add your babies name to our memory tree.
All welcome!
This event is held at the end of Baby Loss Awareness Week 9th - 15th October.
About the International Wave of Light:
The International Wave of Light invites baby loss families, friends, loved ones and supporting organisations from around the world to join in honour and remembrance of all loved and longed for babies gone too soon.
No matter where you are in the world, you can light a candle at 7pm in memory of your baby or babies to be part of the wave of light that begins here in Aotearoa and wraps around the globe.
Wherever you do this, you will be joining a global ‘Wave of Light’ in memory of all the babies who lit up our lives for such a short time.
This is a family friendly event, please be mindful pregnant families, babies, children, as well as health professionals wishing to support our community may be in attendance

description:
Wellington Speed Dating for ages 26-44 by Cheeky Events Australia, Wellington Speed Dating for ages 26-44 by Cheeky Events Australia
Get ready for a night of fun and connection at Wellington's hottest speed dating event!

About this Event

Let’s ditch the apps together and embrace real connections. Say goodbye to the dating apps and hello to your very own Cheeky Love Story! 💖
🍸 What’s included: Your first drink is on us—let’s toast to great company!
👇How It Works:
Before the event:Make sure to download the Cheeky Events App (free on Google Play & the App Store) to set up your profile and upload a photo.
P.S. Don’t worry—it’s not a dating app! We’ve skipped the chat feature because we’re all about real, in-person connections.
During the event:
Check in to grab your name tag and free drink token. 🍻
Arrive on time to enjoy 15 minutes of casual pre-mingling.
Ladies stay seated while men rotate every 5 minutes—don’t forget to rate your matches in the app! 👍👎
Take a quick 15-minute break before the next round.
After the rotations, feel free to stick around for some extra socializing!
After the event: Stay for extra mingling and check the app for your cheeky matches 12 hours later! 📱💖
For more details, check out our blog: What to expect
Who knows? You might just find your next spark! ✨ Our IRL singles events (single mixers and speed dating events) are happening across Australia, New Zealand, London, and NYC! 🌏

About Cheeky Events
We host fun, inclusive singles events across Australia, New Zealand, London, and NYC! Whether you’re in your 20s, over 40, looking for love, or just looking to meet new people, our events are designed to bring people together. Whether you’re seeking romance, new friendships, or even networking, we’ve got something for everyone!
👉 Follow us on Instagram:@cheekyeventsaustralia @cheekyeventsukandireland @cheekyeventsnewzealand @cheekyeventsukandireland @cheekeventsus
Visit our website: www.cheekyevents.net or download the Cheeky Events app to get started.
We can’t wait to see you at one of our events soon! 🕺💃

Wellington Spring Festival – Government House Garden tour, As part of Wellington's Spring Fetival, explore Government House gardens with the BARK garden team (90 minute tour)

Government House was opened in Newtown in 1910, and its extensive gardens have been in continuous development since then. As part of the Spring Festival, the Government House garden team is offering guided walks through our gardens. Tours will go ahead regardless of weather. Tours will not enter the main house.

Bookings are essential for the free tour. Places are limited: https://gg.govt.nz/government-house/government-house-wellington/government-house-tours/upcoming

Some parts of our grounds are not mobility friendly. Please contact the Visitor Centre direct if you have any questions regarding accessibility.

Groups wanting to organise a garden tour or house tour can email our Visitor Centre team direct: bookings@govthouse.govt.nz

If you have any questions or need more information, please email us at bookings@govthouse.govt.nz, or call us at 04-382-0837. You will receive a reminder email 24 hours before your tour.

description:
Wellington WikiCon 2026, WikiCon is the annual gathering for editors of Wikipedia, Wikidata, Wikisource, Wikimedia Commons, and other Wikimedia platforms. Organised by Wikimedia Aotearoa New Zealand (WANZ), our local chapter of the Wikimedia Foundation, this conference brings together Wikimedians from across the country. In 2026, WikiCon will be held in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington.
This event will provide opportunities for editors and contributors to connect face-to-face, helping to build collaborative relationships. The conference will also provide opportunities for editors and contributors to share and develop their skills and knowledge in working with Wikimedia projects. All are welcome, from complete beginners to highly experienced editors.
Conference sessions will be run on Saturday 2 and Sunday 3 May 2026, with informal welcome activities kicking off on the afternoon of Friday 1 May.
Further information will be posted on the event page.
If you’ve got a project you’d like to share with other Wikimedians, or suggestions for topics you’d like to learn more about, please feel free to get in touch at info@wikimedia.nz — we’d love your input.
We are offering grants covering registration, travel, accommodation and meals. Apply now by contacting info@wikimedia.nz with the following information:
Location
Occupation
Areas/topics of interest

description:
Wellington Wizards Quiz Night Fundraiser, ✨ Quiz Night Fundraiser – Support the Wellington Wizards! ✨
Think you’ve got what it takes to be the ultimate quiz champion? Gather your team, put your knowledge to the test, and join us for a night of trivia, prizes, and fun—all while supporting the Wellington Wizards, a brand-new ultimate frisbee club!
📅 Date: Thursday, 2nd October, 2025
🕖 Time: 7pm - 9pm (Approximately)
📍 Location: 1852, 55 Cleveland St, Brooklyn
🧙 About the Wellington Wizards
We are a new ultimate frisbee club training to compete at the New Zealand Mixed Ultimate Championships Division 1—the highest level of competition in the country, held this year in Christchurch.
Our diverse, mixed-gender team includes high school students, university students, and young professionals, all passionate about the sport and eager to grow. As a brand-new club, we’re fundraising to cover essential costs like uniforms, training field hire, travel expenses, training camps, regional qualifiers, and the final tournament.
By coming along, you’ll be helping us achieve our goals - Casting spells and playing magical ultimate 🪄
🎁 What’s in Store:
Quiz Competition: Teams battle it out for glory and bragging rights
Prizes for Winning Teams 🏆
Spot Prizes throughout the night for lucky players 🍀
Raffles with awesome goodies up for grabs 🎟️
Including: Interislander / Bluebridge vouchers, Movie passes, Gym Memberships, Food and Drinks and much more.
💡 How to Join
Get your team together and hit the get tickets button to secure your spot
Book early—spaces are limited!
🍽️ Make a Night of It!
Support our venue 1852 and come for dinner or drinks before the quiz. Reservations can be made here: www.1852.co.nz.
👉 Don’t forget to mention you’re there for the quiz!
📌 Suggested booking time: 5:30–6:00pm
Come for the trivia, stay for the laughs, and help us build the future of ultimate frisbee in Wellington.
Together, we can make magic happen! ✨

description:
Wellington: Te Matapihi Central Library Tour, Te Matapihi/Wellington Central Library Tour with WCC and Athfield Architects

RICS invites members to a site visit of Te Matapihi ki te ao nui, Wellington’s soon-to-be-completed Central Library. Delivered in partnership with Athfield Architects, LT McGuinness, and Wellington City Council, (with Aurecon, Tihei, Fire HQ, Rider Levett Bucknall & RCP), this event offers a look at the revitalised civic space following completion of the main contract works (public opening scheduled for early 2026, following soft fit out).

The project includes extensive seismic strengthening—base isolators, new foundations, and structural upgrades, making Te Matapihi one of the most resilient public buildings in the city. It also targets a 5-star Green Building rating and will house the Library, Capital E/Experience Wellington, Council Archives, and Council Service Centre, in a single integrated facility.

PPE Required: Hard hat, Hi-Vis and steel toe cap boots.

Contact:
For more information on this event please contact Caleb Steiner (RICS Member Engagement Lead) at csteiner1@rics.org

Privacy:
Please note, your details may be shared with the RICS NZ Member Engagement Group where strictly necessary for coordination of this event. Please contact csteiner1@rics.org if you have any concerns or would like any additional information. For more information on how RICS collects and uses information please view our Privacy Policy - https://www.rics.org/oceania/footer/rics-privacy-policy/

FAQs:
How can I contact the organiser with any questions?
Should you require further information, please don't hesitate to contact Caleb Steiner - csteiner1@rics.org
Can I pay by invoice?
No, only credit card payments will be accepted for this event.
Can I update my registration information?
Yes, you can update the information on your order by clicking your order on the Tickets page. First, access the account menu, then select "Tickets." Second, select your order. Third, select “Edit” to update your information. Once you’re done, select “Save” to save changes.
Reschedule or Cancellation of Events
Due to the nature of events, we may require to reschedule or cancel due to unforeseen circumstances. We will do our best to email all attendees as soon as possible, should this occur. Should a reschedule or cancellation occur, RICS will not be responsible for any costs, damages or expenses (i.e. travel) etc. that you may suffer or incur.

description:
Welly On Wheels - City to Island Bay: Confidence & Skills for Biking, Join Wellington City Council, Pedal Ready, and Switched On Bikes for a guided bike tour along the cycle route from central Wellington to Island Bay. Build your confidence and skills to ride safely and efficiently by paihikara (bike), explore the latest cycleway improvements, and learn practical tips for night-time commuting.

The ride starts and finishes at Switched On Bikes HQ near Waitangi Park, heading to Shorland Park in Island Bay. You are welcome to finish the ride at Shorland Park or ride back to Waitangi Park. Note: the event may be postponed in the case of adverse weather.

Duration: Please allow around 2 hours for the ride.
Arrival: Arrive 30 minutes early if you’re renting a bike.
Preparation: Bring clothing suitable for changing weather conditions.

These rides are ideal for people who:
- Can ride a bike but haven’t yet started biking regularly in the city.
- Already ride in the city but want to gain confidence.
- Want to learn how to use Wellington’s cycleway network safely and efficiently.

Who can join: Open to riders aged 18+, or 13+ if accompanied by an adult. Younger children are welcome on cargo bikes or bike seats provided by participants. If you’d like to borrow a bike seat, please contact Switched On Bikes directly.

Bikes and bookings:
An electric bike is strongly recommended. Thanks to Switched On Bikes and Wellington City Council, you can rent one for only $10 if you don’t have access to your own. Please book your e-bike separately here: https://switchedonbikes.rezdy.com/642002/electric-bike-hire-welly-on-wheels

After the tour, you can either leave your bike with us and catch a bus back to the city or keep riding if you’re feeling energetic! You’re welcome to return the bike before 9am the next day at no extra cost or hold onto it for the following day at a discounted rate of $39.

If you’d like to learn to ride a bike away from traffic, check out the free Pedal Ready courses on their website.

For any pātai (questions) about the tours, please email info@pedalready.org.nz.

Privacy Statement:
Information collected for this ride is used for booking and safety purposes. Your name and emergency contact details will be deleted within 14 days after the tour. Other provided information may be stored anonymously to support project evaluation. Your email address will be kept for up to 4 months so we can share follow-up information about biking in Pōneke and invite you to give feedback about your experience.

You have the right to request access to or correction of your information. To do so, please email tours@wcc.govt.nz.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Welly On Wheels Kilbirnie - Confidence & Skills for Biking, Wellington City Council and Pedal Ready are teaming up to run social bike tours of the cycle routes in Kilbirnie and the surrounding area. Build confidence and skills to travel safely and efficiently by paihikara (bike) while getting to know the cycle routes in Kilbirnie!

Rides start and finish at Switched On HQ on the waterfront. A great way to exercise your newfound cycling skills and confidence on a fun social ride!

Please allow 2 hours for the ride. Arrive 30 minutes early if you are renting a bike.

These rides are suitable for people who:
- Know how to ride a bike but aren't yet travelling by bike in the city; or
- Those travelling by bike in the city but would like to gain confidence; or
- Those who want to learn how to use new infrastructure.

Open to riders aged 18+ (or 13+ if accompanied by an adult). Families are also welcome to bring younger children on cargo bikes or bike seats provided themselves. Please enquire directly with Switched on Bikes if you'd like to borrow a bike seat for the tour.

An electric bike is strongly recommended to participate in this ride. Thanks to Switched on Bikes and Wellington City Council, you can rent an electric bike for just $10 if you don't have access to one. Please book that separately here: https://switchedonbikes.rezdy.com/642002/electric-bike-hire-welly-on-wheels

You can either leave the bike with us after the tour and make your own way home (there are regular buses that depart regularly to the city from the Kilbirnie bus depot) or come back with us to Switched On HQ. If you're feeling extra enthusiastic and want to extend your ride overnight, you're welcome to hold onto the bike for free and return it before 9am to Switched on Bikes. You can also hold onto the bike and return it at the end of Thursday at a discounted cost of $...! You can decide what you'd like to do as late as the end of the guided ride on Wednesday.

If you would like to learn to ride a bike away from the road, check out the free Pedal Ready courses on their website. Any pātai (questions) about these tours please get in contact: tours@wcc.govt.nz.

PRIVACY STATEMENT: The information you shared in signing up for this ride is used for booking and safety purposes. Within 14 days after the tour, your name and emergency contact details will be deleted. Other information provided may be stored anonymously to support our project evaluation. Your email address will be stored for up to 4 months following the tour. Within that time, we may contact you with follow-up information about biking in Pōneke, as well as feedback opportunities about the ride and the impact it has had on your travel around Pōneke. You have the right to ask for a copy of any personal information we hold about you and to ask for it to be corrected if you believe it is incorrect. If you would like to ask for a copy of your information or to have it corrected, please contact us at tours@wcc.govt.nz.

description:
William Gray Young: Architect Extraordinaire, William Gray Young: Architect Extraordinaire
William Gray Young, Wellington Architect from 1905 - 1962 left an indelible mark on the architectural landscape of New Zealand. A traditionalist, innovator and architect with meticulous attention to detail.

An exploration into the key stages of his life, his notable works, with some memorable quotes.

One of Wellingtons finest architects of the past. The presentation will focus on his extraordinary portfolio of work he carried out during his career. Familiar to many for its outstanding contribution to the place we all love to live and work in.

Known for his outstanding commercial projects like the Wellington Railway Station of the 1930’s and his Neo-Georgian Architecture like his Kent Terrace House for Sir James Elliot 1913, the presentation will also show Gray Young was prolific for his early residential work in the English Vernacular Style which adorns much of Kelburn and Wadestown in Wellington. Then outline how he built a very successful practice with his brother Jack Young and Herbert Morton designing many outstanding buildings throughout his career.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: $25 (or $20 if booking for the 3 Wellesley talks)
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/william-gray-young-architect-extraordinaire/


Health & Safety

The Wellesley hotel has recently been identified as a potential earthquake risk but remains fully operational while plans are developed for strengthening. Safety procedures will be explained at the talks.

description:
Women Loving Women Speed Dating, Celebrate love and connection at our Speed Dating event for women who love women!

This is a unique opportunity to meet amazing women, forge new friendships, and discover potential romantic connections in a warm, inclusive, and supportive atmosphere.
We have the use of a private function space upstairs.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little. You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!

description:
Women of Pōneke February 2026 Event, Women of Pōneke : Big dreams for a cool Capital
26 February |5-7.30 | Te Ahumairangi Foyer
National Library 70 Molesworth St
We begin the year by inviting you to Dream Big!
We love Wellington for its quirk, culture, connection to nature and its infectious energy. In your wildest dreams what would our future capital feel and be like? How would you live in it and what would you want it to stand for on a world stage? — How can we create a city future generations will love to live in?
As Eleanor Roosevelt once said  “ The future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams”
Who better to dream than the Women of Pōneke!
We are delighted to have the team behind Dear Wellington – Claire Sharpe and Sophie Jacques from Warren & Mahoney and Helen Milner associate at Think Place — to share their dreams for our city in inspired visual imaginings and letters from a future Wellington. They will invite you to join in re-imagining our cool little capital, express your hopes and think about how we can turn ideas into action. 
This is an event where you can surround yourself with great company, enjoy delicious food and wine - unleash your imagination, connect and spark action.  We can’t wait to see you there! 
Tickets are limited to 180 guests.
Get your tickets now! 
Numbers are limited due to space, so we recommend you get in and quick! We are limited to 180 only. 
We will be serving wine, beer and amazing non-alcoholic drinks, inclusive in the ticket price. Platters will also be shared throughout the evening. 
So grab your ticket now and share with at least one amazing woman (and/or ally) in your life.
To cover our costs, we are charging for this event. We know that things are tough at the moment for many, so if this is a barrier for you to attend, please contact us and we will do everything to support you to attend. 
Help a woman in need
If you wish to support someone else who may have a financial barrier, please buy one of the "Buy-One, Give-One" tickets, so we can support more of the amazing women of Pōneke to attend.
Get in quick!
Tickets for previous events have sold out fast. For this event we are capped at 180 people attending and we will be updating our social media channels on the progress of the ticket sales, so get your tickets quick.  
Accessibility
The Te Ahumairangi Foyer, National Library is fully accessible. If you are not able to use the steps on Molesworth Street, you will be able to access the venue via the lift off Aitken Street. There will be staff at the door to be able to support and guide you to the venue space.
A bit about us 
Me.We.Pōneke is our signature quarterly event designed to inspire, connect and raise the voices of our wonderful community of Wellington women, and people who identify as women. 
We believe that magic happens when women come together. We’ve seen it. We’ve felt it. And we want to create more of it with regular events that are open, welcoming, supportive and empowering for the women of Wellington.
Come along, bring a friend and join us as we continue to raise the voices of Wellington women and invite you all to be part of Me We Pōneke.
You can join our mailing list from our brand new website, thanks to our amazing partner Springload. Check it out here and make sure you sign up to our mailing list: https://www.womenofponeke.org....
We are also on Insta! Follow us here: https://www.instagram.com/wome…

description:
Women of Pōneke November 2025 Event, Women of Pōneke: Hidden Stories of Our City
6 November | 5:00–7:30pm | The Exchange (The Atrium), Blair & Allen Streets, Wellington
We’re ending the year with an invitation to rediscover the hidden and magical delights that make Wellington the city we love.
Pōneke is a city of contrasts, wild and urban, creative and political. Its hidden stories are all around us, waiting to be noticed and celebrated. We’ll take inspiration from the Wellington Writers Walk; a trail of words and ideas scattered along the waterfront that invites us to pause, notice and listen.
We are delighted to welcome Dame Fiona Kidman as our special guest. As one of the original founders of the Walk, she will share why this project was so important to her and the inspiration behind it. As an esteemed New Zealand author, Dame Fiona brings a wealth of experience in storytelling, creativity, and reflection that we hope will inspire us to all explore our wonderful city.
Join us for an evening of conversation, discovery and connection with Luna Estate wine and delicious food from Monsoon Poon. Our sponsors are our wonderful friends at Inside Recruitment.

Numbers are limited due to space, so we recommend you get in and quick! We are limited to 150 only.

description:
Women’s Day of Action - Taitoko Levin, Women’s Day of Action - Taitoko Levin
Women’s Day of Action: Celebrating the women in our lives!

RSVP here: https://www.together.org.nz/wdoa_levin

132 years and one day after women secured the right to vote in Aotearoa, we are gathering again in strength and solidarity.

The Government gutted Pay Equity legislation that would have eased the cost of living and lifted pay of 182,000+ people. Across Aotearoa there will be activations to send a clear message: Pay equity is not optional. Our livelihoods should never be on the political chopping block.

Join us for a community friendly event for the whole family. There will be speeches from community leaders, kai, stalls, health checks and more!

When:11am-2pm
Where: Taitoko Levin Village Green - Corner of Queen and Salisbury Streets, Levin, Levin 5510

Wear: purple, green and white in honour of suffrage

Everyone is welcome – bring your whānau, friends and community 💜💚🤍

description:
Wrights Hill Fortress Open Day, Wrights Hill Fortress Open Day
Visit the World War Two Fortress in Karori and learn about New Zealand's war efforts in the 1940's. Photos, displays and DVD of a 9.2 inch gun firing.

Wrights Hill Fortress Open Day - Labour Day October 27th. Come and see WW2 history at the Karori Fortress. Self- guided tours take about one hour. Historic Photos, DVD of a huge 9.2 inch gun firing and other displays. Refreshments available. Entry cash only.

Entertainment for the whole family, and friends at the World War Two Fortress in Karori.
Spend one hour of more self-guiding yourselves through the 620 metres of underground tunnels.
Bring a torch for some fun and stout footwear please.

Families $20, Adults $10, Child $5. NO EFTPOS - CASH ONLY please.

Military living interest displays and historic photos.
Limited parking at the top of the hill. Please park sensibly.


Bookings not required.
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/wrights-hill-fortress-open-day-25/


Health & Safety:
No running inside tunnels, care needed on concrete steps and possible protruding objects. Prams and wheelchairs not accessible Stout footwear please and bring a torch. No smoking.

description:
Writers Retreat, Set in the welcoming embrace of Featherston’s Fareham Creative Space, this weekend retreat offers a unique opportunity for writers at every level and genre to immerse themselves in creativity and community. This retreat will be a two day experience, with optional add-ons, designed to help you focus, recharge, and build lasting connections.

Our retreat is structured for those who are ready to escape the daily distractions, and explore wellbeing through creative practice.

2025 Retreat Themes:

Focused Writing Time: Quiet periods for personal writing, with prompts and encouragement to develop a new writing piece, or deepen your existing project.

Community & Connection: Opportunities for both structured and informal connection, allowing you to build a network that extends beyond the weekend. Optional evening events for building on social connections.

Wellbeing & Renewal: We're partnering with Wellspring Nature Therapy, to bring a wellbeing focus and spark creativity. Nature therapy is amazing for deepening your mind-body connection, and Fareham Creative Space's quiet rural location gives us a fantastic location to explore.

Enrichment & Inspiration: Scheduled time for the sharing work and celebration of each writer’s voice, as well as a Writers Journal, as a takeaway memento capturing a writing sample from each attendee.

description:
[FULLY BOOKED] Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), ** THIS EVENT IS NOW FULLY BOOKED **
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV
In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.
Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.
Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.
Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.
Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.
Time/Date: 1pm, Sunday 2 November 2025
Starts: meet outside St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street
Ends: Vivian Street
Duration: 90 minutes
Cost / Bookings: ** FULLY BOOKED **
Accessibility information: the tour is on flat public footpaths. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.
Image courtesy of the amazing Kym Strathdee
This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
s Wellington Theatre Tours, General Admission OnlyAll Tickets are Mobile Ticket Only. 
Mobile Tickets are like Print-at-Home tickets but instead of having to print off the tickets yourself, you can just show the barcode on your mobile phone. It is the easiest way to access tickets to your events. For more information visit Ticketmaster.co.nz/mobileticket

Join us for a behind-the-scenes tour of Wellington's iconic St James Theatre and The Opera House. Discover hidden stories, architectural splendour, and rich theatrical history as you step behind the velvet curtain and explore two of the city's most beloved performance spaces. Led by expert guides, this tour takes you on a journey through over a century of theatre magic. Tread the boards in the footsteps of legendary performers. Uncover the secrets of stagecraft and marvel at the breathtaking details of these heritage-listed buildings. From opulent foyers and ornate auditoriums to backstage corridors brimming with history, you'll see the theatres as you've never seen them before.

description:
2025 Annual South Coast Cleanup, Welcome to the 16th annual South Coast Cleanup, 10:30AM-12:00PM 13th September 2025.
As well as caring for our coasts and oceans, it’s all about community! Join us at any of our cleanup locations for a morning of litter collection and family fun.

WHEN
We kick off at 10:30am on the 13 September. We host clean up sites at 12 locations between Owhiro Bay to Breaker Bay on the Wellington South Coast. All rubbish will be gathered up around 12.15pm and taken to Lyall Bay by the playground to form one huge rubbish mountain that will be collected by the council.

Pitch in for a rubbish pile up at 12:30 at Lyall Bay playground where we will mound up our rubbish and admire our collective efforts! Then we will head to Parrotdog for a drink / kai after!

WHERE
Our fantastic friendly volunteer groups will be scattered along the coastline between Owhiro Bay and Breaker Bay. You can turn up at any of our volunteer sites:

Site 1 - Owhiro Bay hosted by Project Jonah
Site 2 - Dive Wellington hosted by Dive Wellington
Site 3 - Island Bay West hosted by Mountains to Sea and Island Bay Residents Association
Site 4 - Island Bay Snorkel Trail hosted by Friends of Taputeranga
Site 5 - Houghton Bay hosted by Houghton Valley School
Site 6 - Te Raekkaihau Point hosted by Ghost Diving
Site 7 - Lyall Bay West hosted by Underwater Club Wellington

Site 9 - Lyall Bay East hosted by Earth Science NZ (formerly NIWA)
Site 10 - Moa Point hosted by Places for Penguins

description:
A Walk With Katherine Mansfield - Guided Walk, In this walk of up to 75 minutes we will enjoy the gardens through the words of Katherine Mansfield. Throughout her short writing career she expressed her love of plants and the natural world. Our walk, accompanied by the words of Katherine in her 1907 charming vignette ‘In the Botanical Gardens’, will be essentially on main paths, including some uphill to the Succulent Garden, to reflect on some of her favourite plants.

Meet at the Founders’ Entrance, Glenmore Street.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
AlterCOP30: Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd.
Donations are welcome to support climate education and action!
In solidarity with AlterCOP30, this November we’re running a series of climate events across Aotearoa - bringing communities together to learn, connect, and take action for a just and sustainable future.
AlterCOP is a Global Initiative founded by The Matcha Initiative and The Transmutation Principle, locally brought to you by Climate Club, Climate Crew, and Climate Training Co.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
AlterCOP30: Digital Collage, Led by Climate Training Co. and Jean-Philippe, the Digital Collage is a fun 3-hour workshop centred on collaboration and collective intelligence. 
The aim of the workshop is to raise awareness and train participants on the environmental issues of digital technology. The workshop also outlines solutions for a sustainable digital technology, and allows open discussions amongst participants on the important and timely topics.
A true team-building tool, allowing participants to come together and delve into the sustainability of our digital world, and engage with the solutions. 
It is built on the same theory and structure that underpins the Climate Fresk.
Benefits of this workshop for your organisation:
Build a shared understanding of digital sustainability 
Understand the problems and threats 
Find solutions that you can implement 
This workshop is rigorously sourced from data sourced by ADEME, Green IT, EcoInfo CNRS and the Shift Project’s reports and references.
How the workshop operates:
Understanding: in teams of 4 to 8, the participants identify and then draw the links between the cards of the game to build a “Collage” 
Personalisation: they visually express their key messages and link their work to their context: to take ownership of the content and create a team spirit
Debriefing: each group explains their title and decoration, then the facilitator makes a detailed summary of the whole system
Solutions: a solutions based exercise finishes the workshop, which stimulates discussion, reflection, and action around a sustainable digital world
If you're looking to build awareness and explore real solutions around digital sustainability in your organisation, this workshop is a great place to start.
In solidarity with AlterCOP30, this November we’re running a series of climate events across Aotearoa - bringing communities together to learn, connect, and take action for a just and sustainable future.
AlterCOP is a Global Initiative founded by The Matcha Initiative and The Transmutation Principle, locally brought to you by Climate Club, Climate Crew, and Climate Training Co.

description:
Artistic Potential: Marine Reserves - A presentation/talk, A presentation and talk facilitated by Katy Cottrell, Matteo Collina and Alice Rogers.
Marine Reserves have obvious benefits to the environment, protecting species and providing underwater appeal to snorkelers and divers but a little realised benefit is what they can offer to artists of all mediums. Join artist Katy Cottrell as she chats with academic researcher Matteo Collina and director of the Victoria University Coastal Ecology Lab – Alice Rogers. Alice and Matteo will talk about their work with marine reserves from a scientific perspective and how this has inspired the artworks by Katy Cottrell and Rick Allender for their exhibition Taputeranga: Above and Below.

description:
Botanical Insights talk - Ancient plants, This talk, which partners a major pictorial display at the Tree House, starts with a look at landscapes preceding the rise of trees. It then focuses on the Silurian, Devonian and Carboniferous geological periods, characterised by the appearance of the likes of scale trees, seed ferns and calamites.….and the swamp forests that gave rise to the production of coal. Then it advances to the Permian period, including Gondwana prior to its eventual breakup, and the beautiful, strange, gymnosperm Glossopteris that was widespread in the ancient southern continents, embracing what is now New Zealand/Aotearoa. Finally, it progresses to the world of ‘living fossils’ such as ginkgo and the even more primitive horsetails. Attention will be drawn to some of the animals that populated this ancient world.

Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
Free of charge. You’re welcome to bring along your own ‘brown bag’ lunch to enjoy during the talk.

The speaker is Reg Harris, a volunteer guide [botany] at Wellington Botanic Garden.
Reg delivers botany lectures for diverse audiences, delving into plant interactions, adaptive radiation, tropisms, and more. As a dedicated volunteer guide at Wellington Botanic Garden (WBG), he pioneered collaborations between WBG and Victoria University, organising annual field labs for biology students.

description:
Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa, Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

description:
Cannons Creek community planting day, Join us and Ngāhere Korowai on Saturday 22 November at Cannons Creek Lake Reserve to plant grasses and trees. This planting is part of a project to restore and enhance the mauri of this important body of water.
This community event is an opportunity to meet and greet other passionate locals while we work towards restoring our streams. It is one of a handful of events focused on caring for Cannons Creek Lake. Come along and be part of the ongoing effort to look after this place!
Please note – there is a concrete path to the planting site, but the planting area may be very muddy and slippery.
When: Saturday 22 November, 9.30am-12pm
Where: Cannons Creek Lake Reserve – enter from the footpath on Warspite Ave and follow the flags
You will need to bring:
• gumboots or sturdy closed-toe shoes that you don’t mind getting muddy
• warm and waterproof clothing
• sun hat and sunscreen
• reusable water bottle
We will provide:
• plants and planting tools
• kai
• First Aid trained staff
• hand sanitiser
• sunscreen
• public toilets can be found in Bedford Court.
Getting there:
There is parking available in Bedford Court. The 220 Bus stops at the entrance on Warspite Ave and the 226 Bus stops on Bedford St which is within walking distance to the planting site.
Make your way towards the flags and gazebos, which will be located at the seats in Cannons Creek Lake Reserve. Friendly helpers in high vis from Porirua City Council and Ngāhere Korowai Collective will be there if you have any questions.
Event sign up/admin will be from 9.15-9.30am with the event running from 9.30am-12pm.
We appreciate you giving up your time to do some great mahi for Papatūānuku. Feel free to spread the word to whānau and friends to join you on the day!
See you there!

description:
Cashmere Reserve mini-bioblitz, I'll be at the reserve from around 8.15am until around 10am. If you want to take a look at a small wetland and forest undergoing restoration, and record a few iNaturalist observations, then come along and say hi. Make your way to the back of the grassy area and you'll see where the restoration work is underway. There's no track but you can get some distance following the stream and it's really stunning further up.
Important information: there's almost no selaginella in the reserve, so if you've been in reserves where it's rampant, you might want to clean your boots. Also, it's important to stay out of unweeded parts of the wetland, apart from the streamside area. There's tradescantia in there and trampling will make it more difficult to control in future.
Cashmere Reserve is a dog exercise area and I'll have my dog with me. She's very friendly with people but is a bit grumpy with other dogs, so if you are bringing a dog with you, give me a call when you arrive and I'll put her on leash. 0210 8355 915

description:
Challenges in a Changing World – what kind of future do we want?, Public Talk & Workshop

Humanity is at crossroads
One path into the future leads to increasing social and economic division, environmental destruction, war and planetary peril. The other path leads to increasing social harmony, economic and environmental balance, a golden era of peace.

Throughout history, especially at times of crisis, great spiritual teachers have emerged to show humanity the next step forward.

According to British artist, author and esotericist Benjamin Creme, a group of such spiritual teachers is now living in the modern world ~ Maitreya, the World Teacher and The Masters of Wisdom ~ to help and inspire humanity in its task of global transformation ~ to create a civilisation based on sharing, justice and peace; for humanity to act - to share and save our world.

From ancient times, a body of spiritual teachings known as the Ageless Wisdom has been handed down from generation to generation. A systematic and comprehensive account of the evolution of consciousness in humanity and nature, it describes how the universe came to exist, how it operates, and humanity’s place within it.

As humanity matures, further aspects of this previously hidden knowledge are released in a wider, more open manner. Throughout the last 100 years, the Ageless Wisdom Teachings have been communicated through individuals such as Helena Blavatsky, founder of the Theosophical Society, and later by Alice A. Bailey and Helena Roerich; followed by Benjamin Creme.

Along the lines of these teachings, humanity is once again at a critical point in its further development, now with a growing awareness of the necessity for unity, justice and peace.

According to these teachings, Maitreya – known as the Teacher for this coming Age of Aquarius – will emphasise the utter necessity for peace, and that the complete renunciation of war can only be achieved by trust. Sharing alone, Maitreya will affirm, can engender that trust.


~ followed by short Transmission Meditation session ~

Share International New Zealand. Contact (021) 261 2749
Access - entrance from Raumati Road/ walk - drive past Te Raukura ki Kāpiti / Kāpiti Performing Arts Centre

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!

description:
Climate Kōrero Pōneke - Storytellers Night # 3, Join us for Climate Kōrero #3!
Our free event is an evening dedicated to celebrating the inspiring mahi of individuals and organisations driving climate action in our communities.
After our first two sold-out events, we are thrilled to invite you to the third installment of Climate Kōrero.
We'll hear from four passionate speakers who will share their journeys, insights, and practical ways you can get involved. The event follows the Pecha Kucha format - each speaker presents 20 slides, with each slide shown for 20 seconds. This fast-paced visual format is a great way to share stories and keeps everyone on their toes! After each presentation, you’ll have the chance to kōrero directly with the speakers, so bring your questions and curiosity.
Why should you come along?
* Get inspired by changemakers in the climate action space
* Free kai to enjoy while you listen and connect
* Meet like-minded people and grow your climate action network
* Discover opportunities to get involved, including funding through the Climate and Sustainability Fund
Our speakers:
* Gareth Hughes – Wellbeing Economy Alliance
* Ellie Clayton – Kaicycle
* Emma Osborne & Gareth Jardine – EkeRua Rebicycle
* Orini Rokx-Taratu & Santino Morehu – Future Unity
Event details:
* 5:00–5:30pm – Arrive, grab some kai, and explore info on climate action in Pōneke
* 5:30pm – Welcome and first two speakers
* Intermission – More kai and kōrero
* Final two speakers – Then wrap-up and mingling
Whether you're new to climate action or already involved, this is a great chance to connect, learn, and be inspired.
Come and kōrero with us! Register here: https://www.eventfinda.co.nz/2025/climate-korero-poneke-storytellers-night-3/wellington?_gl=1*14jbvne*_ga*MTQyNDQ2NTgyMy4xNzQ4NDk1OTQw*_ga_QMBB6ELQP7*czE3NTg2ODYyOTkkbzQkZzEkdDE3NTg2ODYzMDckajUyJGwwJGgw&_ga=2.147946549.38973921.1758660978-1424465823.1748495940

description:
Community Agency - a conversation with Markus Luczak-Roesch and Gerhard Reese, Two scholars share their perspectives on Community Agency and discuss the links between the Global environmental and global mental health crises.
  Gerhard Reese
Gerhard Reese works as Associate Professor for Climate Change at Te Herenga Waka - Victoria University Wellington in Aotearoa / New Zealand. Before, he was Professor and head of the Environmental Psychology Research Unit at the University Kaiserslautern-Landau in Germany since 2016. He got his PhD in Psychology from Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Germany, in February 2010. His research focuses on individual, social and systemic catalysts and barriers of pro-environmental behaviour and the nature-health nexus. He attempts and sometimes succeeds to spend more time outdoors than indoors and he still is a serious competitor in Super Mario Kart.
Markus Luczak-Roesch
Markus Luczak-Roesch is Professor of Informatics and the inaugural Chair in Complexity Science at Victoria University of Wellington’s School of Information Management. He is also one of two Co-Directors of Te Pūnaha Matatini, Aotearoa New  Zealand’s Centre of Research Excellence in Complex Systems. He founded and leads the Complexity & Connection Science Lab, an interdisciplinary group developing theories and computational tools to understand how complex systems unfold over time. His research investigates how structure and meaning emerge in systems - from language and brain activity to online communities and the environment - using models that reveal meaningful coincidences and unexpected system-level behaviors.

description:
Community Planting Belmont Regional Park, Help us reforest the hills of Belmont Regional Park. By planting native trees and shrubs, we will restore the native ngahere/forests and create an ecological corridor for wildlife to travel between Wellington, Porirua, Kāpiti and the Hutt Valley.

We have partnered with GWRC, PCC, and local iwi to restore the hills of Belmont Park. Starting on the west hillside, our aim this year is to plant 5,000 native plants to create a forest for the future! This project aims to bring the community together to restore the hillsides of the Belmont Regional Park.

We provide all the tools and training, no prior experience needed. We can even provide transport to the site. Just bring your energy and lunch. We will provide you with a yummy morning tea.

Come have some fun planting with us and TAKE ACTION FOR NATURE!

This event is part of Conservation Week 2025 - www.doc.govt.nz/conservationweek

Sign up for this event on our website ConservationVolunteers.co.nz or email Wellington@cvnz.org.nz

description:
Community Snorkel: Taputeranga Marine Reserve, Community Snorkel: Taputeranga Marine Reserve
Dive into Taputeranga Marine Reserve and take part in a free snorkelling event this summer!

Beginners welcome! We provide all the necessary gear and experienced guides to ensure your safety and enjoyment in the water. Participants just need to be at least eight years old and confident swimmers. Those under sixteen must be accompanied by an adult.

Registrations open at 9.45am. Come down to book a snorkel time for the day, as spots may fill up quickly. Bring your togs, towel, refreshments and make a day of it exploring the activities and environment at Taputeranga Marine Reserve.

This free event is brought to you in partnership with Greater Wellington Regional Council.

Cancellations/Postponements

Events are weather dependent. Stay updated by checking the Mountains to Sea Wellington Facebook event listings for any cancellations, postponements, or location changes.

To get to Taputeranga Marine Reserve

We encourage attendees to leave cars at home and use alternative transport where possible. Locals- please come on foot or bring along your bikes/scooters! For those further afield, the number 1 bus drops you right to the event from the Wellington Train Station.

Accessibility

Island Bay Beach is accessible by beach wheelchair. The nearest accessible toilets are in Shorland Park. There are two accessible parks in front of the Island Bay Surf Club, additional vehicles can be accommodated if required, near to our MTSW trailers. Please see a staff member on arrival if the Surf Club parks are full. We have a variety of options to enable a more comfortable experience in the water, including flotation aids and 1:1 support from our trained guides. Please get in touch with us at in advance of the event to discuss your accessibility requirements, including to enquire about beach wheelchair assistance. We love helping people to experience our marine environment!

The snorkelling in this event is run under the Health and Safety of the Mountains to Sea Conservation Trust programme Experiencing Marine Reserves. Adventure Activity Certified - AA0534.

‍
Photos: Kristine Zipfel

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Caring For Cats Indoors, Join us at Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne for an engaging and balanced kōrero about one of the more challenging conversations in pet ownership today – indoor cats.

Whether you’re the owner of a roaming cat, have a “catio” setup, are thinking about your next feline friend, or are simply wildlife-conscious, this is a chance to hear from veterinarian Brendon Bullen of Kelburn Vets about the facts, the challenges, and the practical options available to current and future cat owners.

We’ll explore how to keep cats happy, healthy, and enriched indoors, while sharing practical tips, surprising cat trivia, and myth-busting insights.

Come along for ideas, open discussion, and a fresh take on feline care and conservation.

This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6.00pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Under The Mistletoe, Join us this December for a kōrero exploring the complex lives of native mistletoes in Aotearoa.

Leading mistletoe expert and hands-on conservation practitioner, Trevor Thompson, will share insights into the ecology of these beautiful yet elusive plants, how he is propagating them, and the challenges they face across our landscapes.

From habitat loss to seed dispersal and browsing impacts, learn what is threatening the survival of these special plants and what’s being done to protect them. Come along to deepen your understanding, ask questions, and discover how we can help ensure these special species remain part of our ngahere for generations to come.

This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6.15pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Conservation Kōrero: Underwater Forests of Wellington, Towering seaweed forests and colourful sponge gardens lie just beneath the surface of Wellington’s coastline. Like forests on land, these underwater habitats support a remarkable diversity of life, including treasured kaimoana species. Yet they face growing pressure from human activity and environmental change.
Dr Nicole Miller will take us on a visual journey through Wellington’s Blue Belt, exploring current conservation successes and challenges. Drawing on years of diving, photography and local restoration work, Nicole will highlight the beauty and fragility of these ecosystems and why it’s more important than ever to bring changes to the surface.
This event will be held in the Pāteke Room in the Visitor Centre with light refreshments provided. Doors open at 6:00pm, parking is available at both our Visitor Centre and overflow parking area on Birdwood Street.
Nicole’s seaweed artworks will be on display at Zealandia Te Māra a Tāne from 1 August to 30 September, with all profits supporting Explore Your Coast: www.exploreyourcoast.co.nz/docu.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Conservation Week, Skink and Gecko Live Show Reino Grundling will talk and show slides illustrating the mostly unrealised role that lizards (skinks and geckos) had in our pristine ecosystems, with some 130 or more different species! And what makes this presentation so marvellous is that he will have a number of living examples there for all to see! Great for the kids!

Conservation Colouring Competition The Masterton Library is celebrating the importance of conservation with a colouring competition—and there are some great prizes up for grabs. There will also be an informative display featuring conservation-themed resources you’re welcome to take home with you.

Dr Marie Doole Biodiversity Funding Talk Dr Marie Doole will discuss the pros and cons around nature/biodiversity credits, an emerging option for funding the protection of biodiversity, particularly on private land, by investors, whether corporate or philanthropic. Worth attending if you've been following the media hype.

Think Like a Forest Film Forest and Bird are showing this film, starring Sam the Trap Man, in three locations. The Regent have generously offered to show it where it will have the most effect—on the big screen! The film is produced by Pure Advantage who have an aspirational programme around landscape-scale restoration of native forests called Recloaking Papatūānuku.

Kōkako Morning Hikoi Join us for a special one-off tour and experience the magic of the kōkako at Pūkaha. Follow our expert guide to a kōkako hotspot and enjoy the rare opportunity to possibly see and hear kōkako. After your walk, return to the centre for a hot drink and morning tea.

Waihinga Bridge Planting Morning Ruamāhanga Farm Foundation is hosting a morning of planting and a celebration of children's voices at the start of the soon to be opened Waihinga Bridge Walkway. Tools will be provided and all ages and abilities are welcome!

Exploring Ngahere Under Story and Campfire Talk The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective (TGCAC) takes up temporary residency at Te Whare Whakapapa Raranga to explore human-centred warning systems and ngahere's role in mitigating danger. Join us in bringing the understory into te whare through kōrero and creative exploration.
