description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures, Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures
📅 Wednesday, 1 October 2025
🕔 5:00–7:30 PM (Networking from 5:00 PM | Panels 5:30–7:30 PM)
📍 Te Aro Campus, Faculty of Architecture and Design Innovation, Victoria University of Wellington (139 Vivian Street)
The built environment is at the heart of Aotearoa’s response to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs). The way we plan, design, and construct our cities influences how we live — and how we tackle challenges such as climate change (SDG 13), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), affordable housing and equity (SDG 10),
responsible consumption and production (SDG 12), and partnerships for action (SDG 17).
This event is part of SDG Action Month 2025, a global campaign that highlights how communities, institutions, and industries are accelerating progress toward the 2030 Agenda.
For Aotearoa, the conversation is urgent: how can planning, design, and construction shape a sustainable, equitable, and climate-resilient future?
The evening will open with a keynote address that sets the stage with global perspectives on sustainability and the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs.
Two panels will then explore critical themes:
• Planning + Place + People — equity, housing futures, cultural identity, indigenous leadership, and policy alignment.
• Materials + Methods + Innovation—construction technology, green standards, digital tools, and carbon-conscious practice.
Alongside the discussions, attendees can view a Student Showcase from the School of Architecture and the School of Design Innovation, and contribute to a Blueprint Wall by writing their own pledges on SDG Commitment Cards, ensuring the event concludes with collective action as well as ideas.
📌 Free to attend | Open to all | RSVP required
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Destination Earth, Expect your senses to be stirred in a new art installation. Destination Earth aims to inspire climate action through art. It incorporates satellite data, real-time generative music, and responds to audience movement in real-time. Using video and immersive sound, audiences will be challenged to reconsider the rhythm of living as humans. 
You are invited to dive into the flow of the Southern Ocean and explore the pulse of the Antarctic circumpolar current. Participate by adjusting your walking patterns and breathing to ‘regenerate’ the world around you. Motion sensors will pick up your activity and adjust the environment to suit. At a sensorial level the effects of climate change will come to life. 

Destination Earth is a collaboration between Cellule Studio (UK) and Victoria University of Wellington. The work, by artist Salome Bazin, mixes art, science, and technology. It emphasises the urgent need to slow down human activity.  

A bi-cultural perspective is also central to the experience. Māori symbolic views of the ocean are included, offering a richer narrative of the global climate.
 
Image credit: Cellule Studio, directed by Salomé Bazin.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Dragonflies & Damselflies are Amazing and Important - Forest&bird Talk, Ruary Mackenzie Dodds and his wife Kari de Koenigswarter are rated as Dragonfly Ambassadors by the British Dragonfly Society. Although they have recently been involved in the setting up of a Dragonfly Hotspot at Exbury Gardens in Hampshire, England, their work currently centres on New Zealand where awareness of the significance of dragonflies is possibly behind that of the U.K, which has a growing understanding that dragonflies are a key indicator of the health of waterspaces. In this talk, Ruary takes his listeners back to basics on the amazing life-cycle of these insects. He outlines typical preferred dragonfly habitats, and touches on identification of New Zealand species. In addition to Ruary’s talk, Kari’s larva demonstration table shows actual examples of the larval stages on NZ species.

In their New Zealand work, Ruary and Kari are carrying out survey work on behalf of the Greater Wellington Regional Council, and are preparing a dragonfly education pack for schools. They have also carried out five summer seasons of night-filming an endemic dragonfly species – the Bush Giant – that lives in a burrow! A Radio New Zealand Our Changing World programme has been devoted to their work. (https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/ourchangingworld/546925/dragonflies-masters-of-flight).

Ruary and Kari have been working with dragonflies since 1985. They opened Europe’s first Dragonfly Sanctuary in 1991, and founded the National Dragonfly Biomuseum in Northamptonshire in 1995. They and their team of volunteers continued work with the National Trust at Wicken Fen in Cambridgeshire, and were instrumental in the setting up of the Dragonfly Centre there in 2009. Their adventures were published in Ruary’s memoir, The Dragonfly Diaries (Saraband, 2014). Kari and Ruary have also published a how-to book, Dragonfly-Friendly Gardening (Saraband, 2024). Ruary is a Fellow of the Linnean Society. He has given talks in eight countries. He has appeared on both television and radio, and was awarded BBC Springwatch’s ‘Dragonfly Geek’ award. He has been featured in BBC Wildlife Magazine, The Scottish Field, and in Wildlife Trust and National Trust publications. Kari specializes in the larval stages of odonate life, while – even after over forty years – Ruary’s heart lifts at the sight of a dragonfly in flight, and he loves sharing this enthusiasm with his listeners!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025, EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025
This year’s EBANZ (Earth Building Association of New Zealand) national conference will see industry leaders, innovators and enthusiasts come together to profile the latest ideas, technologies and projects shaping the future of low carbon, high performing, sustainable building in Aotearoa.

Set at Te Wānanga o Raukawa and the Forest Lakes Conference Centre on the Kāpiti Coast, the earth building conference will see builders, designers, researchers and earth-building enthusiasts explore how traditional and contemporary earth construction methods are shaping resilient, sustainable futures in Aotearoa and beyond.

Themed ‘Earth, Culture and Community’, the three-day conference in mid-November will include presentations, hands-on workshops, site visits and kōrero with leading voices in natural building, indigenous knowledge, climate-responsive design and regenerative practice, while also profiling New Zealand’s own set of earth building standards (NZS 4297, 4298 and 4299) 2024.

A ‘Professionals Day’ on Friday 14 November at Te Wānanga o Raukawa is aimed specifically at architects, engineers, inspectors, builders and designers interested in earth and natural building techniques. It will dive into the Tennent Brown Architects-designed Pā Reo campus at Te Wānanga (a Living Building Challenge project) and presenters will include Rau Hoskins of designTRIBE, Verena Maeder of Solid Earth and Sigi Koko, founder of Build Naturally USA.

Friday will be followed by the in-depth weekend conference at Forest Lakes, featuring talks and presentations aimed to inform and empower people on different aspects of earth and natural building as well as hands-on workshops in different methods and materials, including clay-based plasters, cob, rammed earth and adobe, straw bale and hempcrete. House tours will feature different building techniques, including straw bale and rammed earth, adobe, natural plasters and more.

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

Whether you're interested in solar power, EVs, or energy-efficient products, this expo has something for everyone!

Meet industry experts, discover innovative products, and attend hands-on workshops to learn how you can electrify your life.

description:
Electrify Wellington: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Wellington will show you how.  
Most Wellington homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Wellington has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Wellington.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Wellington is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.

description:
Electrify the Hutt Expo 2025, The Electrify the Hutt Expo is charging into Lower Hutt with a mission to spark inspiration and supercharge your lifestyle with the power of clean electricity. As energy bills climb and climate concerns grow, this high-energy event will show you how to take control—cut costs, slash emissions, and embrace a smarter, more sustainable way of living.
Discover the incredible potential of generating your own local power through solar panels, micro wind turbines, and more. With dynamic demos, interactive exhibits, and expert talks, you'll learn how easy and empowering it is to electrify your home, reduce your reliance on fossil fuels, and enjoy the long-term benefits of clean energy.
But that’s just the beginning. The expo goes beyond saving money and helping the planet—it’s about building stronger, more resilient communities. By embracing local energy generation, we can protect ourselves from rising energy costs, power outages, and climate extremes. It’s about creating homes and neighbourhoods that are not just efficient, but future-proof.
So whether you're a curious homeowner, a savvy business owner, or just someone who wants to be part of something positive, Electrify the Hutt is your place to plug in. Come connect with experts, explore cutting-edge tech, and join a growing movement to electrify our lives and build a cleaner, brighter Hutt Valley for everyone.
Add the date to your calendar now!

description:
Emma La Rocca - Zero waste swimwear, Emma La Rocca is the founder of Emroce swimwear, the world’s first zero-waste swimwear brand.
Her cutting patterns are designed to fit together perfectly- like a puzzle. This innovative technique fuels creativity, reduces costs, and saves up to a quarter of fabric from ending up in landfill.
Now, Emma is on a mission to help other fashion brands embrace Zero Waste Fashion Design (ZWFD). Through fully funded consulting, she’s breaking down misconceptions and showing how sustainability and style can go hand in hand.
Join Emma as she introduces the world of ZWFD, shares her results, and invites you to try out some simple techniques yourself.
Register for this free event, enjoy a complimentary breakfast from our sponsors, and take part in this inspiring conversation about sustainable fashion.

description:
Feed the Trees! W**d & Feed: Shared Picnic, Feed the Trees! W**d & Feed: Shared Picnic
Let's give the trees a bit of summer love, so they can return us a kai in Autumn!

We'll just be doing some mahi to prepare the trees for the hot months, at our two sites around the corner from each other in Titahi Bay. Weeding, feeding and maybe a little mulch if we can get some! We will also listen to some tunes and continue to figure out how to save the world.

We'll start with the trees at the top of Tireti Rd site (walkway entrance: https://maps.app.goo.gl/r6atPhuZECgS5XAn7). We'll do a quick tidy up there, until about 11.

Then at about 11-11.30 we'll head to the Pikarere Reserve site (Top of Pikarere, almost at end of 220 bus line: https://maps.app.goo.gl/TmDKyr4JsXgkjoeY8).

It's the last session of 2025, so we'll have a bit of a shared kai to enjoy the fruits of the year. Then we'll get back into it until the place is looking good!

The plan is for us to catch back up later in summer, and in Autumn we'll come together again and celebrate our harvest together, from our community trees to our backyards!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Forest & Bird Kapiti-Mana - "Argentine Ants", Come along and bring a friend to a talk by Bruce Brewer on Argentine Ants, an inasive species found in areas of Kapiti. These aggressive ants compete for resources, kill local ants and dominate the ecology of the gardens they invade. They can also affect buildings and infrastructure.

The informative talk will cover how to identify them, how to control them, and their wider implications.
7.15pm for a cuppa and a yummy snack
7.30pm start
label: Conservation & Environment

description:

We'd love you to join us at our AGM, where our guest speaker Professor John Cockrem will be speaking about his passion - Little Blue Penguins.

We will get through our AGM matters as quickly as possible. Our meeting on Wednesday, 18 February 2026 starts from 7:10pm, at the Waikanae Community Centre at 28-32 Utauta St., Waikanae.

Hope you can join us there!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Forest & Bird WALK a New Reserve - Mātai Moana / Watts Peninsula, Join us for a guided walk over Mātai Moana / Watts Peninsula (North end of Miramar Peninsula). This guided walk will celebrate the Government announcement (September 2025), that the 72 hectare area is now a Public Reserve and DOC land.
The area's attractions include:
1. strong historical, cultural and military values, (several kainga and pā, and military history from 1880s), and has hosted several prisons, including a prison garden
2. some superb 360 degree views of Wellington Harbour
3. no major animal pest species and while much of the land is grass or in pines, there are several sizable and growing areas of regenerating native bush.
Moderate fitness will be needed. Our walk is expected to take a little over 2.5 hours. It will traverse a mixture of sealed roads and walking tracks with some uneven ground and two quite steep sections, from sea level to 163m above sea level. One section has a gradient of 30 degrees for a short section. There are some stiles to climb over.
Meet opposite the steps up to Massey Memorial at 130 Massey Road, Point Halwsell, Mapuia, Wellington, 6022. This is about 450m south of Point Halswell, and 500m north of the northern end of Shelly Bay. Location of the meeting point: approx 41°17'15" S, 174°49'26.5" E. A Forest & Bird Flag will be on display. See map for meeting spot and car parking suggestions. Please arrive in time to confirm your attendance and receive a quick pre-walk briefing.
Arrive by 12.50 p.m. on Sunday 22 February 2026. Please register on EventFinda in advance - limited to 40 walkers. All aged 10 or more, are welcome - you do not have to be a Forest & Bird member. All children must be accompanied by an adult who takes responsibility for them. Please bring your own sunhat, sunblock, snacks, any personal medications plus water bottle and wear good walking shoes/boots. There is no public transport to the meeting point.
If weather is wet/unsuitable, a decision to postpone will be made by 11:00 a.m. on Sunday 22 February 2026, and a group email will be issued to all those who have registered. Contact Ken New on ken.new@branch.forestandbird.org.nz for any enquiries.
Please register on EventFinda.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Forest & Bird: Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail, Every Last Bird – Birds of Te Araroa Trail

Book your place now to reserve a chair.

Between November 2023 and March 2024, Te Papa natural history curator Dr Colin Miskelly walked the length of Aotearoa New Zealand on Te Araroa Trail – counting every bird seen or heard along the way. His talk will cover some of the logistics of walking the trail, as well as a summary of the birds encountered. This included looking at what difference (if any) predator trapping had on the abundance of native birds. For a taste of what the talk will cover, see Te Araroa Trail | Te Papa’s Blog.

Colin Miskelly on Mt Crawford, Tararua Ranges:
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Forest Giants, Fragrant Herbs and Birdsong - Guided Walk, In this 75-minute walk we will get up close to some delightful pygmy pines before, on a gentle slope, passing under and being awed by their towering cousins en route to a wonderful view of Wellington City. In the Herb Garden we will see and hear a little about the aromatic, culinary and medicinal properties of familiar and not-so-familiar herbs, before descending, possibly accompanied by some birdsong, through a tract of native forest down to Lady Norwood Rose Garden.

Meet at the Founders’ Entrance, Glenmore Street.
Cost: $10 - book now
Free for Friends

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden. They run throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Friends AGM with guest speakers, Join the Friends of Wellington Botanic Garden for our Annual General Meeting and a pair of inspiring botanical presentations. You don’t have to be a member to attend — everyone’s invited!
Programme
Each presentation is 30 minutes, with time for questions.
Paul Bell-Butler
Botanist and PhD candidate, Paul is delving into the hidden world of leafy liverworts (family Lophocoleaceae). His research combines modern molecular techniques with traditional botany to reveal how these overlooked plants shape ecosystems and influence seed germination.
Clare Shearman
Plant Collection Team Manager at Wellington Botanic Garden, Clare brings a career spanning historic English estates to iconic New Zealand gardens. Fresh from the prestigious Longwood Gardens Fellows program in the USA, she shares insights into garden design, conservation, and how public gardens nurture wellbeing and connection.
Come along to hear their stories, celebrate our beautiful gardens, and meet fellow plant enthusiasts.
Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
For more info about the Friends: https://friendsofthewellingtonbotanic.wordpress.com/
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Friends of Tawa Bush Reserves - mid-week working-bee, NOTE - The working-bee that was scheduled for 23rd Sept is postponed until Tuesday 30th Sept due to weather.
Please meet at Forest of Tawa, 58 Kiwi Crescent.
The objective of this working-bee is weeding tradescantia. Please park in Kiwi Crescent and walk up the shared driveway to the reserve entrance, we are about 50m up the main track from the gate.
Recommended to bring – favourite weeding tools for tradescantia, boots, gloves, and clothing appropriate to the weather – a mostly shady area
For further information or directions please contact Richard Herbert, phone 027 4455942.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Fundraiser - Seaweed and Ocean-inspired Art Sale at the South Coast Arts Trail, Purchase ocean-inspired art and support marine conservation!
Seaweed and ocean-inspired artworks by Explore Your Coast Founder Nicole Miller will be on show at the 2025 South Coast Arts Trail in Island Bay, 13 & 14 September 2025 (10am to 4pm).
Nicole will be at the Presbyterian Church both days with the immersive 360° video tours of Wellington's Blue Belt and Taputeranga Marine Reserve. Come along, experience Wellington's underwater world, and be inspired to dive into our local marine reserve!
All profits from artworks sold support the marine conservation and outreach initiatives of Explore Your Coast.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026, Kia ora!
Electricity and electrification are seen as the significant enablers for decarbonisation of our nation. The Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) | Te Whatunga Hiko programme aspires to meet the challenges the electrical power system will face as we journey towards sustainable decarbonisation.
Our vision is to provide an infrastructure paradigm through a hybrid AC/DC transmission and distribution system that meets the needs of tomorrow’s efficient, low-carbon, reliable and resilient electrical power system.
Funded as part of the New Zealand Government’s Strategic Science Investment Fund (SSIF) on Advanced Energy Technology Platform (AETP), the research team is investigating what the future electrical power system might look like.
Hear about the team’s latest achievements as we approach the final phase of the programme.
Attendance is in person at Victoria University Wellington.
Ngā mihi nui,
Prof. Neville Watson,
Science Leader
The detailed programme will be circulated closer to the event.
 More information on the research can be found at https://www.fan.ac.nz/
If you have any questions, please contact futurearchitecturenetwork@canterbury.ac.nz
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
GDNZ 2025 Shelly Bay Cleanup, Join Ghost Diving New Zealand for a community cleanup!

This will be an ocean and shore based clean up targeting rubbish in and around the Wellington foreshore.

Scuba divers, free divers and shore crew all needed! Be prepared to get wet and dirty!

DATE: Saturday October 11th 2025

TIMES:
9.00am - Registrations open
9:45am - Briefing
10.00am - Divers in the water
2.00pm Clean-up and pack down

LOCATION: Shelly Bay - look for the GDNZ signs.

Scuba Divers who wish to participate must have a minimum of 30 logged dives and be comfortable working in low / zero visibility.
Scuba and Free Divers must provide their own gear and tanks. If you also have your own catch bag(s) or float boat for collecting rubbish, please bring this along and ensure they are named.
If you would like to join in the fun and participate as part of the shore crew, you will need to make sure you are wearing fully covered shoes and bring a pair of gardening gloves... also be prepared to get dirty!

ALL PARTICIPANTS, SHORE CREW AND DIVERS MUST REGISTER ON ARRIVAL.

PLEASE NOTE:
• This is a free, family friendly event, but children must be supervised at all times by an adult.
• Closed toe footwear must be worn for safety.
• Please bring your own hand protection (gardening gloves or similar).
• Don’t forget your own water bottle and bring sunscreen if it’s a warm day.
• Dress for the weather (warm clothes and jackets)
• There will also be plenty of work for non-divers to get involved.
Should the event be cancelled due to circumstances out of our control, notification will be given on the Facebook page the night before. Please remember to check prior to the event.
We look forward to seeing you there!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.
Why attend?
Learn about climate diplomacy in action
Engage with leaders shaping global climate responses
Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting
🗓️ Date: Tuesday, 26 August 2025
🕔 Time: 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM
📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington
🎟️ RSVP Required – Limited Spaces
Networking Reception: From 6:30 pm with canapes and drinks kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.
FOR ANY DIETARY:
Please email us at ishant.ghulyani@unanz.org.nz
Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Haewai Catchment Climate Adaptation Workshop, Join us for coffee, kai, and conversation at a relaxed, family-friendly community event in Haewai Houghton Valley. This is your chance to share your thoughts, ideas, and local knowledge about how our community can respond to the challenges of climate change.

We’ll be running interactive activities for all ages, including a colouring contest and lego building for kids, while the adults can share their ideas, experiences and knowledge about the neighbourhood and explore what makes Haewai Houghton Valley special. Whether you’ve been involved in local projects for years or are new to thinking about climate adaptation, your voice is important.
Plus, everyone who takes part goes in the draw to win a 200-litre emergency water tank - a fun (and practical!) way to get your household prepared for anything.

This event is part of the Paekawakawa / Haewai Local Climate Adaptation Pilot, where Council, mana whenua, and the community are working side by side to shape a shared vision for a resilient and thriving Houghton Valley.

bring the whānau, grab a cuppa and join the conversation!
label: Conservation & Environment

description: Halloween Night Tour, Dare to explore the wilderness of the sanctuary after dark! Your guide leads you through the eerie sights and sounds of Aotearoa New Zealand’s native forest at night in search of rare and endangered species, including those that only emerge under the cover of darkness. Encounter spooky critters like wētā, glowing glow worms, and the ancient tuatara. Keep your eyes peeled for the elusive kiwi pukupuku. Although their haunting calls may be heard, sightings (while common, at 80%) are never guaranteed!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Heritage of Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush – The Gardens and Gardeners, Ancient native forest and botanic garden excellence — uncover the unique history of Ōtari-Wilton's Bush on this engaging tour for the Wellington Heritage Festival. Join us and explore!

From forest to farm to internationally acclaimed native botanic garden - let us walk you through the fascinating story of Ōtari-Wilton's Bush. Learn about the visionary people involved. Join us to hear the rich history of this special garden while enjoying the beautiful surroundings.

Meet at Tāne Whakapiripiri Ōtari Visitor Centre. Most walking is on gentle paths, some slightly steeper trails are optional.

Photo credit: Wellington City Council Archives, 00291-5801-7
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Heritage roses and companion plants - Guided Walk, What place did these plants have in our colonial history, and when were they introduced to our botanic gardens? Do these plants still have a place in our gardens today? Join us to explore their history and appreciate their beauty. This will be an easy one-hour walk.

Meet at the Seddon Memorial, Kinross Street entrance to the Bolton Street Cemetery for this 60-minute walk.

Cost: $5 (cash only, please). Or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden; they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

Join the Friends for only $30 a year, and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Hātaitai Spring Seed Swap, Keen to get your garden going?
Come along Sat 6 Sept to swap any seeds you don’t need and get a start on the spring planting season.
Don’t know when or how best to sow your seeds? We can show you and get you going!
As always there will be some free tea and coffee (sponsored by Peoples Coffee), maybe even some home baking too!
Bring any:
Spare seeds
Seedlings (aren’t you keen!)
Spare potting mix
Spare seedling trays
Based on a Crop Swap these events aim to connect the community and reduce food & produce waste, and encourage sustainable practices.
WHAT IS CROP SWAP?
It is a wonderful welcoming monthly community gathering to share the abundance from our kitchens and gardens!
Been madly making chutney? Silver beet going crazy? Been collecting flower seeds? Got some foraged berries or a delicious cake to share?
Come along for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along. Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share.
You can find us upstairs at the Hataitai Bowling Club, 157 Hataitai Rd. We gather from 12pm with the event / swap part kicking off at 12:30pm SEE YOU THERE!
(Thanks @CropSwapTeWhanganuiaTara for support and ideas!)
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Just Sew - Repair Cafe, Repairing rather than buying is a great way to take climate action in your own life - and learn new skills along the way!
Book below and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight items for repair to our September Just Sew!
Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with repairs such as missing buttons, tears, holes and hemming. We will supply a selection of patches and buttons, but you are also welcome to bring your own if you have something specific in mind.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Kai Sovereignty - Parihaka's Maara Kai and Growing for Communities, Climate and Community Activist Tuhi-ao Bailey will talk about Parihaka’s steps towards kai sovereignty, their award winning māra kai and planning a papakāinga to be resilient in the face of Climate Change.
This will be followed by an action-focused discussion led by chef and grower Mara Masarotti on how to connect urban growers with spaces to grow kai at scale.

Kid Friendly!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Khandallah Park/ Waitohi Stream headwaters - mini-bioblitz, A walk up the stream to make iNaturalist observations of ferns and bryophytes. Wet feet expected.
Ferns not often seen around Wellington but in this gully include:
Trichomanes colensoi
Leptolepia novae-zelandiae
Polystichum silvaticum
Hymenophyllum flexuosum
Hymenophyllum revolutum
Hymenophyllum rarum
Hymenophyllum scabrum
Blechnum colensoi
We aim to spend 2-3 hours botanising and photographing what we can find.
Meet by the swimming pool. If you are late, we shouldn't be hard to find as the stream mostly runs alongside the track.
I can be contacted on 02108355915
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Ko Au Te Taiao, Ko au te taiao helps us all to form robust understandings of who we are – as both descendants and future ancestors – in living relationship with this beautiful land. We will:
explore the rhythms of the maramataka and ways we can organise teaching practices in relation to it with Kaupapa Māori Learning Specialist, Leroy de Thierry.
observe the characteristics of mamaku, ponga + whekī, (tree ferns) and consider their whakapapa with Curator Botany, Leon Perrie.
consider how to relate to mātauranga Māori in ways that honour Te Tiriti o Waitangi + imagine rich inquiries in relation to the online resource, Ko au te taiao with Head of Learning, Sarah Hopkinson.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Korokoro to Percy's track working bee, Korokoro to Percy's track working bee
It's time to show some love to the track that joins the bottom of the Korokoro Hill through to Percy's Reserve. There's some great bush there, but it could do with some extra care.

Everyone's welcome to join us for weeding and litter collection. We'll also clear some space for planting in the new year.

Bring gloves, loppers and pruning saws if you're keen to get serious with blackberry. Or just bring your neighbour or your kids and some enthusiasm if you want something lighter.

We'll finish around 3.30pm with cold drinks & snacks provided.

Thanks to @Hutt City Council for support with rubbish collection, and Greater Wellington Regional Council for support of KEG activities.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Launching in-store: Capital Trees by Susette Goldsmith, Join us in celebrating the recent launch of Capital Trees: The Arboreal Legacy of Te Upoko-O-te-Ika the Wellington Region by Susette Goldsmith, author/editor of Tree Sense: Ways of Thinking About Trees.
"The significance and meaning of trees engagingly explored through the way they have shaped our capital.
From the fossil forest of Tītahi Bay and the ageing oak on Plimmer Steps, to the karaka grove on Wellington’s waterfront and a threatened stand of lowland beech in the Hutt Valley, Capital Trees journeys across the region to trace the living legacies of the city’s rich tree heritage and the many people who have shaped, protected and challenged it.
These legacies include arguments around heritage tree listing, the native versus exotics debate, biodiversity, attitudes towards heritage authenticity, trees as monuments and more, explored through facts, anecdotes and field notes.
Illustrated with contemporary photography and specimen illustrations of the species and individual trees covered, this book is a must for all who live in the Wellington region."
All welcome! See you at the signing table.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate
Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!

Why join us? You will:

LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.

Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Lunch & Learn with David Trubridge, Join us for a very special Teulo Lunch & Learn, where design, sustainability, and community regeneration come together.
Hosted by Häfele and Teulo, this intimate event features internationally renowned designer David Trubridge and the global launch of his newest portable light: Dusk.
Enjoy lunch and conversation with peers from across the design and construction industry, with MC DK guiding the session.
What to Expect
Keynote: Think Like a Tree
In his 20-minute talk on biophilic design, David Trubridge shares how we can learn from trees and forests to design healthier, more sustainable spaces.
Film Screening: Think Like a Forest
This short film from Pure Advantage highlights the Recloaking Papatūānuku movement, an ambitious initiative to restore more than 2 million hectares of native forest and wetland in Aotearoa. Featuring Sam the Trap Man and local kaitiaki, it’s both an inspiration and a call to action.
Global Launch: The Dusk Lamp
Be among the first to experience Dusk, David’s most portable light yet, inspired by his collaboration with Pure Salt’s Tamatea Art Project in Fiordland. A new short documentary will showcase the story behind the design and the environmental partnership that shaped it. A portion of all sales will support Pure Salt’s conservation efforts in Dusky Sound.
Local Conservation Panel
Hear from organisations leading vital regeneration work, including the Maraetōtara Tree Trust, Esk River planting projects, and Te Mata Peak Park restoration, and learn how you can get involved.
Why Attend?
This Lunch & Learn is more than a product launch or film screening — it’s a chance to connect with the design community, hear from one of New Zealand’s most iconic designers, and explore practical steps toward a regenerative future.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Matiu-Somes Island Trip, Matiu-Somes Island Trip
Join our club trip across to Matiu-Somes Island. Enjoy a pot luck lunch with time to explore the island before conducting an underwater clean up dive by the wharf (conditions permitting).

After a BBQ dinner it is time for a walk before dessert to observe the Little Blue Penguins returning to their nests at sunset and to hunt for Giant Weta and Tuatara.

Sunday morning is a great time to relax, continue exploring the island before the boats arrive and to conduct a beach clean up before catching a ferry home.

This is a great experience for the whole family.

$100pp + Ferry
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Native plant papermaking for Christmas, Native plant papermaking for Christmas
In this festive papermaking workshop, you will create a range of tasteful and ecofriendly ornaments and gifts, using our sustainably made harakeke pulp. Be ready to get your hands wet!

This is an all-ages workshop and children (5+) are welcome to attend with a caregiver.

All paper produced during the workshop will be pressed and dried by the tutor and sent out to participants 2-3 weeks after the workshop.

This workshop is supported by the Kāpiti Coast District Council as part of their Sustainable Spring programme.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Naturist Open Day, Reconnect with your senses and your environment. Let your skin breathe and de-stress from your busy world.

You are invited to visit our beautiful grounds at Te Marua, Upper Hutt. Lounge by the pool, have a spa or hot tub, play petanque, pickleball, kubb or just chill under a tree, the choice is yours.

Visit our website www.wellingtonnaturists.co.nz for further information

Wellington Naturist Club celebrating 75 years in Upper Hutt.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Ngaio Emergency Response Practice, This event is in partnership with the Ngaio Climate Crew.

A Community Emergency Hub is a place for the community to gather and coordinate efforts to help each other during and after a disaster.

Come along and find out more about the Ngaio Community Emergency Hub and the types of help that may be needed after an emergency.

Have fun meeting together and practicing various roles with an interactive severe weather scenario.

Open to all ages and abilities, no experience needed!

Refreshments provided.

For more information, please email info@wremo.nz

We aim to make our community events inclusive to all people. If you are attending the event and have specific accessibility requirements, you can send us an email at info@wremo.nz with the event name and we will get in touch to see how we can meet your needs as best we can.

About the venue: This event will be held in the Ngaio School Hall. There will be signposts to point you in the right direction.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Northern Suburbs Big Spring Clean!, Hurray, it's nearly spring! Whether you're 8 or 80 come along and show your love for our neighbourhood and come along to this year's Community Spring Clean. This year we're going for Saturday 20th September, which also happens to be UN Community Clean Up Day.
Meet at Pukehuia Park at 10.30am to collect protective gear and rubbish bags, and then head out around our neighbourhood to collect what you can. You might like to head to somewhere you know is particularly rubbish-y around our suburb.
Bring your rubbish back to the park for a weigh-in and to be collected by the Council. Then celebrate your hard work and grab a free sausage or two off the BBQ.
Bring your friends and neighbours and join the fun and satisfaction of making our home a nicer place.
Organised by Newlands Anglican and Newlands Baptist Churches. For more info contact office@newlandsanglican.org.nz or get in touch with Rebecca on 021 0869 9235.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
October Just Sew, Join us for our Just Sew - October edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book online and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

Bookings are prioritised, but we will do our best to fit in walk-ins if there’s space.
label: Conservation & Environment

description: October Walk and Weed, Come and help support the local awa, and water quality for the harbour. We are weeding around local planting to ensure they survive, and picking up rubbish in and around the awa. Meet at Dimmock st side of Onepoto park. We have rubbish grabbers and bags, bring gumboots and gloves. Walk and weeds are the last Sunday of every month.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Our Beloved Indigenous Vegetation - Guided Walk, In this approximately one-hour downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on several native plants from the ubiquitous, such as our well-known cabbage tree, kōwhai and podocarps, to lesser-knowns such as shrubby toroaro/mingimingi, Bartlett's rātā, Three Kings kaikōmako and Three Kings vine/akapukaea. We will also discuss the phenomenon of species radiation exemplified by Hebe and Kauri.

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
PEPEKE meeting - Channels to advocate for invertebrates, The topic is “Channels to advocate for invertebrates”, which we hope to include into our program more often.
We will kick this off with talented Massey students:
India Lindsay (concept art designer) will talk about her board game “Entopia”, a clever game about adaptations and invasive species.
Em Flux will also demonstrate her passion for invertebrates using video installations.
Followed by an activity, where you can get creative as well.
Topic: Pepeke
Time: Aug 27, 2025 07:00 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/84862084139...
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Permaculture for People & Place, Permaculture for People & Place
🌱 Permaculture for People & Place - New Workshop at Mangaroa Farms. Led by our resident permaculture enthusiast Halina Horn, experience a hands-on learning journey for the whole whānau. Come get your hands in the soil, explore the garden, and grow over a 4 week course alongside your tamariki 🌻

Together, we’ll learn to care for land, food, and each other. We’ll achieve this through learning about permaculture systems, composting, water wisdom, nature play, and storytelling.

This event is friendly for kids and adults alike - a great opportunity to get family connection over earth-based practices going.

HOW IT WORKS:
🌀 Sign up for 4 x Saturdays in Nov (1st, 8th, 15th, 22nd) at the link below.

🕙 Each event runs from 10am – 1pm | 298 Whitemans Valley road, Upper Hutt

👦 For families, educators, grandparents, & curious growers (ages 5+)

💚 Different adults and kids ticket options available

This is the first of many permaculture education seasonal offerings designed to re-root us in the rhythms of nature.

The second block course in November will cover key themes in seeds, soil, spring growth, plant communities and more... so come along to continue the learning journey.

Spots are limited. Come and grow with us.

🔗 Book now at https://store.mangaroa.org/products/permaculture-for-people-and-place

📧 Questions?
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Plant Diversity & Human Impacts On Endangered Plants - Guided Walk, In this easy 60-minute downhill walk we will obtain a perspective on plant biodiversity and human impacts on endangered species.

Species radiation in the Southern Hemisphere with New Zealand examples - Kōwhai, Hebe (Veronica) and Kauri.

Examples of rare and endangered species owing their situations directly to human activities. These plants include:

- Shrubby toroaro/mingimingi (Muehlenbeckia astonii),
- Three Kings kaikomako (Pennantia baylisiana),
- Bartlett's rātā (Metrosideros bartlettii)
- Three Kings vine/akapukaea (Tecomanthe speciosa).

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.

Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Plants and Human Health - Guided Walk, What are the connections between kōwhai and lung health; tōtara and eye health; yew, flax and cancer suppression; pōhutukawa, koromiko and gut health; and more. Plants for Health and Healing - Part 2 - Guided Walk, On this walk we continue our exploration of the herbal and medicinal properties of plants.

Meet at the Herb Garden Lookout for this 60-minute walk.

Feel free to bring some ideas of your own to try out!

Fareham Creative Space is an inclusive art space. You don't need experience in jewellery making to enjoy this class, though it's best suited to adults and older teens.

description:
Reimagining Construction: Participatory, Circular, and Open by Design, This presentation examines how the principles of participatory, circular, and open design can transform construction by bringing human and ecological values into the heart of how we build.
Drawing from both ancient timber framing traditions and modern innovations, it demonstrates how modularity and standardisation unlock flexibility, efficiency, and customisation while supporting sustainable, locally-rooted solutions.
A key focus is placed on design for disassembly and reassembly, enabling buildings and their components to be reused and adapted over time—reducing waste, lowering environmental impact, and fostering resilience for current and future communities.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Resilience and Emissions Reduction Workshop for Not-For-Profits | Blenheim, Ready your not-for-profit for the future
Do you know you need to take action to address climate change but don’t know where to start?
Do you want to strengthen your organisations’ planning and readiness for change?
Do you want practical tools and support to measure, assess, and report on your organisations’ impact?

In partnership with Rātā Foundation, our Earth+ Resilience and Emissions Reduction programme has been designed to flip the script on climate change, centering your organisation as agents of change and kitting you with the tools, support and community to make a difference; and it’s free of charge!
About the programme
With the support of the Terra Nova team and other programme participants, you will be guided to identify how your organisation is uniquely placed to contribute to the resilience and wellbeing of people and planet, and the opportunities and obstacles to creating positive change.
The programme is accessible and suitable for everyone, from those just starting on the journey, to those who have steps in place but are looking to gain access to further resources. This programme is not intended to add extra workload or deliverables for your organisation, it is an offer of support to integrate an Earth+ approach into your BAU; an answer to the question “what can we do about climate change?”
We know that every organisation’s capacity is different, so our support is available for you to utilise it when you need it until the end of 2025. This includes:
Access to a dedicated online community where you can connect with the Terra Nova team, other Rātā grantees and specialised partners. Ask questions, find resources and share your journey.
A toolkit of resources and impact sessions to develop your knowledge and connect you with the expertise and support to build resilience and tackle change in a range of impact areas.
Complementary access to the Cogo carbon emissions measurement tool, providing you the ability to quantify and report on your emissions impact and providing recommended actions for emissions reduction and cost savings, in an easy-to-use format.
It begins with a 1-day interactive workshop to kick things off. By the end of the workshop, you will walk away:
Feeling more empowered about the future, with a deeper understanding of resilience and climate change as it relates to your organisation’s context.
Having explored how you can make change positive and achievable, centered on the needs of your community and team. 
With free access to Cogo carbon manager, an emissions profile, report of your carbon footprint and practical action you can take to reduce your emissions.
Having built a network of support and gained free-to-use practical tools and templates.
Note: we will be running multiple workshops throughout the year; you only need to attend one workshop to join the programme. If you prefer an alternate date, please head to our Humanitix profile to find the corresponding event. 
The programme is fully funded for not-for-profit organisations and registrations are now open for 2025! Register for the programme and secure your spot in a workshop through this Humanatix event, and a member of the Terra Nova team will be in touch to confirm your enrollment. For more information about the programme and workshop, visit the Terra Nova website.
We look forward to welcoming you into our community of changemakers!

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we look forward to a day of planting, learning and creativity at Ruamāhanga Farm. Just outside Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are bringing the local community together to help restore wetlands and provide greater access to the awa. The restoration is a foundation for Te Reo o te Wai, an arts and conservation programme for local primary schools.


Our hosts Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will share the story of the land and the conversion of a traditional stock and crop farm into a regenerative, community oriented venture. They will involve us in some of the experiential ways they are helping children and young people connect to hidden places along the Ruamāhanga. The day will include planting trees and grasses along a new wetland walk combined with nature based story telling, art and creative writing. We will have a shared lunch by the awa or under canvas if it is wet.

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
SEED AND SEEDLING SWAP: Join us for the launch of Seeds to Feeds Island Bay!, We're starting a new group dedicated to building a kai secure Island Bay, and we'd love for you to be a part of it!
When: Saturday, 18th October, 10 am - 2 pm
Where: Seed to Sea, 38 The Parade, Island Bay
What to expect:
Seed and Seedling Share: Bring your extra seeds and seedlings to swap, or just come and pick up some new ones - we have plenty!
Learn & Create: Discover how to create new plants from your seeds and make your own seed packets.
Delicious Treats: Enjoy coffee, fresh herbal tea, and tasty treats.
Garden Open Day: Explore the beautiful garden at Seed to Sea and meet the chooks!
Share Your Ideas: We want to hear your thoughts on how we can create a kai secure Island Bay.
Seed and seedling swaps are an awesome opportunity for gardeners of all skill levels to collaborate and share what they might have an abundance of.
It's a great way to save money on buying new seedlings, an opportunity to learn from others, and can lead to new varietals in your māra.
Bring something to share if you can, but if not, come as you are – we'll have plenty for everyone!

description:
Scaling Sustainably with Brianne West, founder of Ethique and Incrediballs, Part of the Pegasus Startup World Cup and Sustainable Spring Series
 Globally recognised environmentalist and entrepreneur, Brianne West, redefined industry norms with her bold vision and innovation, transforming a kitchen experiment in Christchurch into a global beauty revolution.
Ethique was the world’s first zero-waste beauty brand and named in Time Magazine’s Best inventions of 2020. It expanded rapidly, saving millions of plastic bottles from landfill in over 20 countries.
Brianne has won many awards including being an Obama Foundation Leader (AsiaPac), Exporter of the Year (American Chamber of Commerce), and NZ EY Young Entrepreneur of the Year, and was a finalist in the 2024 Kiwibank New Zealand Innovator of the year award.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her incredible journey on scaling, and later exiting a purpose driven, sustainable business. Learn about her current venture, Incrediballs which is set to disrupt the beverage industry, and gain practical insights on how to enter new markets while remaining true to your values.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her remarkable journey of scaling - and ultimately exiting, a purpose-driven, sustainable business. She’ll introduce her latest venture, Incrediballs, poised to disrupt the beverage industry, while offering practical insights on breaking into new markets without compromising your values.
Brianne West is a judge for the Pegasus Startup World Cup held on 9 October 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti. Learn more and book a ticket to the Pegasus Startup World Cup here.
Snacks provided, if you would like to order a coffee, please arrive earlier to avoid noise.

description:

description:
Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe, Join us for our Just Sew - November edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book through our website and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with fixes such as electrical faults, broken clasps, union/wedding ring repair, welding or general fix-up repairs.

These sessions will be held at Te Aro Zero Waste, 2 Forresters Lane, Te Aro.

Bookings are necessary, donations welcome. All koha goes straight back to celebrate our community of generous volunteers.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp, Te Hononga hikoi: Taupō Swamp
Te Hononga hīkoi enable our members to connect with others in the Wellington Catchments Collective. It's pretty inspiring seeing the activities happening in other catchment groups.

The next Te Hononga hikoi will be at Taupo Swamp in Porirua on the morning of Sunday 21 September at 10am – 11.30pm approx.

Come for a spring stroll and bring friends and family. Bring water and own snacks or fuel up at nearby cafes in Plimmerton.

We will meet in Ulric Street by the pedestrian bridge entrance to the dog park (plenty of parking)

Friends of Taupo Swamp & Catchment Inc was formed in 2018 by a group of Porirua residents. Restoration activities have been focused on the part of the wetlands that is owned by Porirua City Council.

Back in 2018 there was a lot of blackberry on the site. Now, some of the 2019-20 locally sourced plantings by volunteers are 5 metres high. By the end of the current planting season FOTSC will have put in 18K plants. An adjacent planting programme around the Plimmerton Domain coordinated by the local Rotary Club and the Porirua City Council has resulted in 22k trees and plants.

Please register your interest/intention to attend by flicking a short email to . In the event of bad weather we will advise cancellation by 8am and rescheduling for a week later.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear
Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray
Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators
Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025, A bioblitz is all about searching for and recording all the species you can over a set time period.
Zealandia is one of the most biodiversity rich places in the motu(show English translation) and the perfect place to come searching for species over the long weekend. You may well find species that we have seldom seen, so this is fun for you and potentially invaluable information for our conservation team. It’s a great reason to go exploring some of the tracks you might not know well, or at all!
All you have to do is upload your observations of species to iNaturalist. It doesn’t have to be done during those four days. In fact, you’ll have a further 14 days to upload and identify all your observations made during the official period.
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025 is run by a network of keen citizen scientists from across the globe.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Power of Community - Dr Amanda Cahill, "What does it take for communities to lead the renewable energy transition - not just be consulted?"
If one person is positioned well to respond to that question, it is Dr Amanda Cahill.
Goodlife Collective, Sustainability Trust and WEAll Aotearoa are proud to be co-hosting Dr Amanda Cahill, founder of The Next Economy
Don't miss this opportunity to hear Amanda's insights from her work in Australia, which demonstrate how acting on climate change can help catalyse fairer, more regenerative wellbeing economies.
Amanda has worked at the intersection of government, local councils, big companies and communities for 30 years, to support communities to transition to a thriving future.
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Event Programme:
5:15pm - doors open, drinks & nibbles
5:45pm - Welcome & Introduction
6:00-6:30pm - Talk from Dr Amanda Cahill
6:40 - Dialogues & Q&A
7:00(ish!): Networking

About Sustainability Trust: Sustainability Trust are your local experts in sustainability, healthy homes, ethical electricity and supporting our local communities.
About WEAll Aotearoa: WEAll Aotearoa is a non-partisan and independent ‘think and do’ tank working to redesign Aotearoa New Zealand’s economy around the wellbeing of our people and te taiao. WEAll use an evidence-informed approach and focus upstream to develop practical, long-term solutions for the public good.

About Goodlife Collective: Goodlife Collective designs and delivers events and experiences to build connection between people, nature and valuable ideas, in service of unlocking our collective potential.
About Dr Amanda Cahill
Amanda is the Founder of The Next Economy, where she supports regional communities across Australia to manage the impacts of decarbonisation and climate change in a way that builds more equitable and regenerative economies. Most of this work has been in coal and industrial regions, where she has brought together government, industry, workers and community groups to co-design transition strategies despite deep-seated tensions. Her work draws on 30 years’ experience working with changemakers across the world to address economic and health inequalities, environmental degradation, women’s rights and climate justice.
Amanda is a Churchill Fellow and has a PhD from ANU in human geography. She is also a Research Fellow at the University of Melbourne, an Industry Fellow at the University of Sydney and a co-editor of the recently published book: Regional Energy Transitions in Australia: From impossible to possible.
About The Next Economy
Next Economy works with government, industry, investment and community to create the conditions for a rapid, responsible and fair transition to a climate-safe, regenerative and socially just Australian economy.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The permaculture design process for a sustainable lifestyle, We invite you to spend a day at Doris & Bob's, experiencing how permaculture can help you design more than just your garden! Applicable in all situations of life, no need to own your own place.
Doris will share her journey of integrating the permaculture design approach into her life's questions, her diverse home and community projects in Paekakariki (eg. PaeCycle, a food scrap collection set up and Pataka Kai, the public cupboard to give and take food abundance), and as Trustee of Toru Education: Motivated by an sense of urgency and responsibility to take care of our finite resources and to care for our environment with all its diverse wildlife and each other. Through storytelling and practical examples, we'll explore how these principles can help shape our lives and communities for the better, and how we all can contribute as individuals. Every choice we make matters.
We also will take a stroll through Doris's garden and engage in some hands-on activities to experience some of the principles in action. Of course, we will spend some time at the various compost heaps (Compost is Doris' middle name!). Regenerating soil with home made compost! Making compost involving food scraps (closely predator managed) or from garden waste (free standing heaps). 
Lunch will be provided—feel free to bring a small contribution to go with the homemade bread if you'd like (but not expected).
After lunch, we will explore the design process of creating a base map for your specific setting, whether it be a your home garden, personal question such as 'What's next?' or a community project.
No prior experience in permaculture is needed. We hope you will leave with new ideas and connections, practical inspiration for your own compost making and an enhanced understanding of how many ways you can apply the permaculture design process and create community, one compost heap at the time!
There will also be a crop swap table where we practice the permaculture approach of reciprocity of 'give and take'; you might enjoy bringing seeds, seedlings, produce from your garden, and walk away with something unexpected (again, don't feel obliged to contribute).
Spaces are limited to 15 spaces to fit into our living room, so make sure you reserve your spot. We are at 59 Wellington Road, up the driveway on your right. Don't follow google directions as that would take you down to the beach. Just come on down Wellington Road, and we are up on your left. Please park below by the lay-by and walk up. We have a friendly little Cavalier type dog called 'Honey' as part of our family.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:

Join us for a hands-on workshop that empowers you to make a difference in your backyard and beyond!



Whether you're a seasoned trapper or just starting out, this free community event will teach you how to use TRAP NZ, New Zealand’s leading predator control platform.



Reino Grundling will show you how to track pests, record trap data, and support conservation efforts that protect our precious native species like kiwi, tūī, and kererū.

📍 Where: Carterton Courthouse, Holloway Street Carterton
📅 When: Saturday 20 September 2025 10am -12 noon
🎟️ Cost: Free
🧰 Bring: Smartphone or tablet (if you have one), enthusiasm, and questions!

What you'll gain:

Tips for setting and managing traps effectively

Skills to use TRAP NZ for recording and reporting activity

Knowledge about the impact of predator control on local biodiversity

Connections with like-minded conservation champions

🌱 Let’s work together to protect what makes Aotearoa unique. Light refreshments provided. This workshop is made possible with funding from WBS.

Spots are limited — register now by emailing

description:
Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms, Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms
Our native riparian plantings from 2023 have really started to thrive this winter, visible as you drive past the farm, or walking the local farm trail loop.

These native seedlings planted alongside the river, act like living sponges, slowing any farm runoff, filtering nutrients, anchoring soil and shading the water so that beneficial invertebrates & life forms can thrive. Creating cleaner water, richer habitat and less flooding downstream.

Keen to get involved? We have a few tree planting events coming up this season:

🌳 TREE PLANTING DAYS
- Sat 16th Aug 10am - 3pm
- Sat 6th Sep 10am - 3pm with @forestandbirdwellington

EVENT DETAILS
- Meet at 10am, 298 Whitemans Valley Road, Upper Hutt.
- We will walk 5-10mins to our planting site near te Awa o Mangaroa / the Mangaroa river.
- Come for a short time, or a long time, and join us for a kai and refreshments at 2pm after the mahi is complete.

BRING WITH YOU
- A Jacket and warm clothes - be prepared for a range of weather
- Boots or stout shoes
- Gloves - if you have them
- A spade if you have one
- Water bottle

Register at https://store.mangaroa.org/collections/events

#treeplanting #mangaroafarms #riparianplanting #nativetrees #volunteer #alwaysbeplanting

description:
Volunteer Info Evening- 2/57 Willis Street, Are you ready to make waves in conservation?
Join Mountains to Sea Wellington on our journey to restore and protect our marine and freshwater environments.
This information evening will give anyone interested in volunteering with us an opportunity to hear all about our volunteer programme and meet the MTSW crew.
There are lots of ways you can help us at MTSW! Are you into photography? Do you make a mean cuppa? Love to snorkel? Love to talk about marine critters? Nau mai, haere mai! We’d love your help! In return, we promise you a summer of adventure and fun times.
You're welcome to join us anytime from 5pm, there will be a short presentation at 5.15pm, followed by drinks and kai. There will be Mountains to Sea Wellington Staff onsite, as well as some of our current volunteers who'll be able to give you the inside word on what it's like to volunteer with us!
We’ll be in the Silver Lining Room at 2/57 Willis Street. Entrance is via the lifts in the alleyway to the left of Unity Books, take the lift to level 2.
RSVP HERE: https://forms.gle/URvGHkFxRmEmALgq8 so we know how much pizza to order!

description:
W**d Releasing Bee, W**d Releasing Bee
Kia Ora Koutou

Now we have finished planting for the year we are turning our attention to the all-important W**d releasing. This is essential to keeping the young plants that we have planted this winter from being overwhelmed by grass and weeds. Also mulching to help with moisture retention over those hot summer days. Our next weeding is on Saturday 29th November, meeting at the Nursery on Hana Udy Place at 9.00am. Gloves, tools and sunscreen provided along with a morning tea and an update on the Reserve afterward. Hope to see you there! Feel free to bring a friend and encourage others to join us. This will be our last volunteer activity for the year.

Also over summer we may need some help in watering the plants we put in this year, I will do a post if we need extra help.


Health & Safety Notice: When working in the Reserve, please ensure your clothing and footwear are appropriate for expected weather conditions (cold, wet or hot) and the terrain (such as holes, hidden objects, blackberry, overhead branches). Trip hazards and slippery tracks are a possibility. Stay clear of waterways. Be cautious if you have allergies and carry the necessary medication. Enjoy your time in the Reserve and please avoid blocking pathways used by other users. Report any accidents, injuries or possible hazards to the H&S Coordinator (021 071 5364).
