description:
WECG ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING 2025, ANNUAL GENERAL MEETING
Tena Tatou Katoa, Greetings Everyone
A WARM INVITATION TO ALL TO ATTEND THE 2025 AGM OF THE WAIKANAE ESTUARY CARE GROUP INC
Venue: The Otaihanga Boating Club, Makora Rd,
Otaihanga
Date & time: Wednesday 3rd September at 7pm
Speaker Mike Joy - see Bio below

Mike is a Senior Research Fellow and Lecturer in Environmental Science at the School of Geography, Environment and Earth Sciences, Mike’s research includes ecological modelling, freshwater bioassessment, environmental policy, biophysical limits to growth and the role of energy in society. He is publicly outspoken about the decline in freshwater quality and ecosystems, especially the impact of nutrient pollution from intensive dairying on New Zealand's "100% Pure", clean, green image.
Mike is an outspoken advocate for environmental protection in New Zealand and for this has received several awards including an Ecology in Action award from the NZ Ecological Society, the Charles Fleming Award for environmental achievement in 2013 and in 2023 the Callaghan Medal for science communication from the Royal Society of New Zealand. In 2015 he was awarded the Morgan Foundation inaugural River Voice Award and in 2017 the inaugural NZ Universities Critic and Conscience award. His book 'The Fight for Freshwater' is a memoir that provides a rare first hand look at those whose voices question the health and future of our waterways.
The Meeting will conclude with supper and korero
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Aorangi Forest Park Old Mill Track, Join the Aorangi Restoration Trust and South Wairarapa locals for a walk along a recently restored track in Aorangi Forest Park. Follow an old logging road to the historic mill site and take in the beauty of the regenerating forest along the way.

Aorangi Forest Park stretches between Martinborough in the north and Cape Palliser in the south, covering much of the Aorangi mountains. By road, the park sits about 80 km south of Masterton and 100 km east of Wellington.

The park is located on Department of Conservation land and features a rich variety of native bush. Beech forest dominates the northern range, while hinau and matai are common in the hardwood forests at lower altitudes. Mahoe thrives on moist soils in gullies and along stream banks. Other species include fuchsia, makomako, heketara, kohuhu, titoki, rewarewa, rimu, and miro, creating a diverse and vibrant landscape.

Walk Format
Meet at 16 Kitchener Street, Martinborough for shuttle transport to the start of this route. The walk itself is a 10km return trip, expected to take 5 hours. It is a fairly easy tramping track - with about 500 metres of more difficult terrain due to the unformed nature of the track and moderate slope at the start. The remainder is gradual slope on a good benched track. We will return to 16 Kitchener Street between 4pm and 5pm.

Important
Once registered, please check your email for the gear list. This walk is partly in cellphone coverage. This walk will be postponed till Sunday 23rd November if there has been significant rain and the river is too high. Tickets will be refunded if cancelled.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Holdsworth Restoration Trust Walk, Led by volunteers from the Holdsworth Restoration Trust this walk highlights community-led restoration in Tararua Forest Park. Walk leaders will guide participants along trap lines and share their knowledge of the pest control project — including how often traps are checked, which pests are targeted, and how bird and animal populations are monitored. Keep your eyes and ears open for native birds such as tomtits, early evening ruru, grey warblers, North Island riflemen, and the ever-present pīwakawaka, tūī, and kererū.

Volunteers will also share their knowledge of native flora, including towering rimu, northern rātā, and miro, which rise above a canopy of kāmahi and beech. The forest is one of the finest examples of mixed podocarp–broadleaf forest in the Tararua Ranges and supports a wide range of indigenous biodiversity. Walkers will also learn how to identify native fungi, understand five-minute bird count monitoring, and discover how to get involved in pest trapping.

Walk format:
This slow-paced walk is suitable for most fitness levels and ages 5 +. The path is mainly on a flat track, however the ground can be uneven with tree roots - not suitable wheelchairs. Note, there is no cellphone reception on this walk. No dogs allowed.

Depart the carpark at 6pm, cross the bridge and along the track, breaking into 3 groups at the Gentle Annie junction. The 3 groups all take a different route along a trap line track, meeting at Donnelly Flat for a hot chocolate and snack before continuing the walk around the loop track and back to the carpark at 8pm time.

Image credit: Jet Productions
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Hāpua Farm, Discover the beauty of Hāpua Farm, a property that combines rolling farmland with wetlands, native bush, and sweeping views of the surrounding hill country. Led by Michael Birch, a member of the Ruamahanga Restoration Trust, the walk begins on the farm’s airstrip, offering beautiful views of the Tararua Ranges before descending through farm tracks, open paddocks, and bush trails.

Along the way, explore wetlands created by large landslides 11,000–12,000 years ago, and continue east to two protected QEII covenant areas of native bush. Here, you’ll encounter towering totara, matai, and kahikatea, as well as abundant birdlife including kererū and tūī. Last year's participants had rave reviews of this walk!

Walk Format:
The walk covers around 6 km. You must be able to climb over fences and walk for 3 to 4 hours over uneven ground. Some climbing is involved - this is a hill country farm. This walk is partly in cellphone coverage. This walk will be cancelled if it has been raining heavily in preceding days. You must arrange your own transport to this walk.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Kiriwhakapapa Loop Track, This guided walk follows the 2km Kiriwhakapapa Loop Track in Tararua Forest Park, about 16km north of Masterton. The track is well-graded with a gentle 50m incline and includes bridges across the Kiriwhakapapa Stream. Walkers will pass through regenerating native forest and a stand of exotic Redwoods.

The walk will take approximately 2 hours and is led by members of the Masterton Tramping Club and Wairarapa Walking Festival Committee, who will also provide information about other tracks in the area.

Walk details:
Meet at 13 Church Street (carpark next to Masterton Police Station) if you’d like to carpool. The track is generally flat, with a 50m incline. Note uneven forest floor and tree roots. No cellphone coverage in the area.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Millennium Native Forest Reserve, Led by volunteers from the Friends of Millennium Native Forest Reserve, this walk offers a fascinating insight into how a once-degraded farmland has been transformed into a thriving native bush and wetland. The Millennium Native Forest Reserve is a community asset established by Masterton South Rotary on land leased from Masterton Trust Lands Trust. It is maintained by a committee called Friends of Millennium Native Forest Reserve. Walk leaders will share the Reserve’s inspiring history — from its beginnings in 1993 as a community-led project to restore local biodiversity, to its official opening in 2000 as part of a nationwide millennium celebration. QR codes placed at key spots offer short films presented by local college students, bringing the Reserve’s stories, conservation work, and unique ecology to life. Along the way, participants will hear how volunteers have reintroduced native plants and nurtured a habitat for native birds, insects, and aquatic life.

As you explore the urban Reserve’s meandering tracks, keep an eye out for tūī and kererū - with a bit of luck, you might also spot a gecko basking in the sun, a darting skink, long and short finned eels in the waterways, koura beneath the shallows, dragonflies, and even wētā tucked away in the undergrowth. You’ll gain an appreciation for the dedication it takes to maintain the Reserve and discover ways to get involved in its ongoing care.

Walk format:
This easy-paced walk is suitable for all fitness levels and ages. The tracks are 2.6km of largely limed winding tracks, with sections of boardwalks. Note: there is no toilet available at this reserve.

We’ll depart from the Hillcrest St Reserve entrance at 2pm. The group will pause at key points to hear stories, scan QR codes, and observe wildlife. Expect 1 - 1.5hr walk.

Photo credits: Friends of Millennium Native Forest Reserve.
This walk is part of the Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Poetry at Dorset Square, The artist collective Tramping Gently Club invites you to welcome undergrowth and fertility at Dorset Square. Join a thought-provoking walk through Dorset Square, part of the Featherston Walkways and Reserves. Along the way, discover a participatory artwork featuring the poetic voices of South Wairarapa youth —where walkers are invited to take part in Poems Against Sustainability.

This unique card-game artwork opens space for sometimes challenging but important conversations about climate change, our relationship to the land, and working with nature. First presented at Featherston Booktown 2022, and later developed during a year-long residency at Turere Lodge in the Remutaka Forest Park, this participatory artwork explores big ideas through creativity and play.

Set within the accessible Dorset Square—the most accessible of four urban bush reserves in Featherston. This walk is an opportunity to connect with a re-emerging under story of kawakawa. Once a paddock used as a training area for the Fire Brigade's competition team, the reserve now offers cool shade in the hot Wairarapa summer and an emerging low flammability undergrowth.

Walk Format:
Walkers can expect a gentle walk - 1hrs in total. Maximum 20 participants. All ages.

Image Credit: The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective

This event was previously advertised to be held at Pigeon Bush - however public access here is now restricted and the walk has been relocated to Dorset Square.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Te Whenua Tapui O Whakamairu Reserve, Discover one of Masterton’s hidden gems with a gentle walk through Whakamairu Reserve, a 1.4-hectare pocket of established native bush within the town boundary. This designated Scientific Wetland, protected by Greater Wellington Regional Council, is home to 200-year-old kahikatea and swamp maire, alongside younger native plantings that signal the ongoing restoration of the reserve.

The boardwalk has recently been renewed by Masterton District Council, and the restoration work continues with the help of the Solway Community Group and local school children from Chanel College and Douglas Park School. Together, their efforts are gradually returning this special site to its original state.

The track is flat, with a mix of boardwalk and limed paths, making it easily accessible for prams and wheelchairs. To access this reserve, head to the end of William Donald Drive off High St. Solway, and park near the junction with Driving Range Road (private road).
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Walking Festival 2025: Wairarapa Moana Wander, Join local freshwater ecologist, Dr Katie Brasell from Kahungunu ki Wairarapa, on the northern shore of Lake Wairarapa. On this 3-4km stroll, you can take in the fresh South Wairarapa air, learn what treasures the moana holds and how local kaitiaki (stewards) are helping to restore mauri (life force) to this jewel of our region.

Meet at the Lake Domain Reserve just south of Featherston. The walk will begin with a brief history of the lake’s importance to mana whenua by the Lake Domain camping area. Continuing for about 1km east across the top of the lake, you’ll hear about the locals favourite native shellfish, kākahi, and what the annual counts are telling us. A few hundred meters away, we’ll take a look at a myriad of aquatic plants (good and bad) and how restoring native species in the lake could turn the tide on this degraded ecosystem.

Walk Format:
This walk is suitable for all fitness levels, and is expected to take 1.5hrs. Children are welcomed but must be accompanied by parent/guardian.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wellington Marine Life VR Experience, Dive beneath the surface and explore Wellington’s Blue Belt - no snorkel required!

Using virtual reality headsets, take a few minutes these school holidays to see the underwater world through the eyes of a scuba diver: swim through the deep reefs of Kapiti Island, be surrounded by schools of fish at Whitireia Park, glide through the lush marine forests of Taputeranga Marine Reserve, and explore a shipwreck! Expect close encounters with octopus, vibrant sea life and even a cute shark with the team from Explore Your Coast!

This free, drop-in event is suitable for the whole family and will be held in the Zealandia Visitor Centre Foyer. Regular admission fees to the sanctuary apply, and overflow carparking is available at Birdwood Street during the busy school holiday period.

To learn more about our local underwater forests, visit Explore Your Coast at https://exploreyourcoast.co.nz/

Sunday 19 October
10am-1.30pm
Te Aro Zero Waste Centre
2 Forresters Lane, Te Aro
--
How it works:
10am-11am:
Drop off your clothes/accessories etc to swap (washed and in good condition please!).
We welcome clothes and accessories from/for everyone - including kids clothes and pet clothes (?)!
~ Have a hot drink while our team sort out the clothes
~
11.30am-1.30pm:
Swap is open! Go and get yourself a whole new wardrobe!

description:
Wellington | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!
Why join us? You will:
LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.
Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.

description:
Whānau Day, Join us for a FREE day of family activities exploring the connection between the whenua (land) and the moana (sea).

Discover raumati (summer) through workshops, performances, and hands-on activities. Learn about seaweed varieties, native plants, and how we can protect our natural environment for future generations.

Activties:
* Identify diverse seaweed species with Mountains to Sea
* Drum and dance to Tokelau rhythms with the Kupega Affect
* Create Moana-inspired crayon pāreu designs with the Pacific Climate Warriors
* Enjoy a live reading of I Love My Island by Moemoana Asfa'ato'a Schwenke, narrated by Inangaro Vakaafi
* Grow native plants and take a cutting home with Te Rito Gardens
* Get your face painted with sea and land creatures by Daizy Designs
* Paint watercolours inspired by botanist and seaweed expert Nancy Adams
* Explore Te Papa's Collections with our art and botany curators

description:
Winter Planting at Paekawakawa Reserve, It's our favourite time of year - tree planting!
We have planted thousands of trees in Island Bay's loveliest little nature reserve since 2013, but there's more work to do. We have around 500 plants that need help to settle into the forest in the next couple of months.
Come to one planting bee, or come to all - we love helping hands.
If planting it not your thing, come for some weeding, or just to give encouragement to the planters and the cup of tea afterward.

Decent shoes, there is often planting on the slope
Gardening gloves
Water
A friend

description:
Workshop: Hands-on Plant Art, Workshop: Hands-on Plant Art
Come and join us for a creative workshop hosted by Kate McAlpine. The workshop supports the exhibition Petals and Threads: Patterns in Nature and Needle, a collaboration between plant artist and ecologist Kate Mc Alpine and The Wellington Embroiderers’ Guild.

In this relaxed, hands-on Plant Art Workshop, learn how to arrange natural materials into unique, ephemeral artworks inspired by the beauty, shapes, and textures of Aotearoa’s flora.
All materials are provided, including a variety of leaves, flowers, seeds, and other found treasures. Or feel free to bring along your own natural finds—plant material or anything else that sparks your creativity. There are no rules! Whether you’re new to art or a seasoned nature-lover, this is a chance to experiment, play, and see the natural world in a new way.

Register Here: https://weg.org.nz/registration-form/

Any questions email:
Or check out Kate McAlpine’s site: https://plantart.nz/portfolio/petals-and-threads-patterns-in-nature-and-needle/

Alongside the Workshop:
The Exhibtition: Petals and Threads: Patterns in Nature and Needle Exhibition
Online Auction: Bid on all 44 artworks during the exhibition period.
Another Workshop at Te Auaha:
Stitching with Nature – 1pm 20 September
Register to save your seat below!
Calendar: A beautifully designed 2026 calendar featuring 12 pairs of selected works, available for purchase via the WEG website https://weg.org.nz/ and in person. More details to come!

The exhibition is part of a fundraising project supporting the New Zealand Plant Conservation Network https://www.nzpcn.org.nz/ and us here the Wellington Embroiderers’ Guild.

description:

Let's protect our local native wildlife by building pest traps to donate to Predator Free Wellington in support of their mission.
With materials and ready-to-assemble kitsets kindly sponsored by Aoraki Construction, we’ll roll up our sleeves and assemble traps at MenzShed Hataitai - all tools and materials provided. No experience required.
After the mahi, we’ll come together to share fish 'n' chips and fizzy drinks on the bowling green, kindly provided by NAWIC. It’s a chance to connect, give back, and make a tangible impact on our environment.

description:
'Una Serenata Italiana' - – an intimate evening of Italian opera favourites at the Public Trust Hal, Te Pae Kōkako – The Aotearoa New Zealand Opera Studio (TANZOS) performs for Wellington audiences for the first time this November with Una Serenata Italiana – an intimate evening of Italian opera favourites at the Public Trust Hall.
Directed by Elaine Kidd (Head of the Jette Parker Artists Programme, The Royal Opera House Covent Garden) and accompanied by Caroline Dowdle (Head of Opera, Atelier Lyric Verbier Festival; repertoire coach with the Jette Parker Programme and the Royal College of Music), the concert celebrates the beauty of Italian opera and the new generation of New Zealand opera artists defining the country’s vocal landscape.
Presented in association with Ambasciata d’Italia Wellington, this special performance continues the vision of Dame Malvina Major, whose support for artist development through TANZOS helps nurture Aotearoa’s rising operatic talent.
Featuring Sarah Mileham, Niamh Bentley, Jasmine Jessen, Katherine Winitana, Ridge Ponini, Faamanu Fonoti-Fuimaono, Tomairangi Henare and Samuel McKeever.
About TANZOS:
Te Pae Kōkako – The Aotearoa New Zealand Opera Studio (TANZOS) is directed by internationally recognised soprano Madeleine Pierard, Dame Malvina Major Chair in Opera, and led by Head Vocal Coach Nikki Li Hartliep, an acclaimed performer and teacher who has worked with major opera companies and conservatories around the world.
TANZOS provides full-time, international-level opera training for up to six exceptional New Zealand singers each year, supported by donor-funded scholarships and guided by Dame Malvina Major’s long-held vision for professional opera education in Aotearoa.
Find out more at https://www.tanzos.org/

description:
A Celtic Christmas By a Taste of Ireland, “Jingle Jigs, Reels a Treat.” Ken Longworth – The Newcastle Herald

Direct from its Off-Broadway season, A Taste of Ireland – The Irish Music & Dance Sensation, presents its holiday spectacular, A Celtic Christmas. Prepare to be enchanted with some of the world’s finest Irish dancers and musicians bringing the spirit of Christmas to life, in a show that will make you laugh, cry, and sing into the night.

After captivating audiences across the USA and around the world, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland returns to New Zealand this festive season following a highly successful 2022 tour. Experience the magic as world-class performers blend melodic folk mash-ups, acapella tap battles, and heart-warming storytelling in one truly unforgettable performance.

Featuring former World Irish dance champions and stars from Lord of the Dance and Riverdance, A Celtic Christmas delivers a holiday spectacular packed with Irish wit, traditional tunes and heartfelt ballads, alongside all your favourite carols. The show’s exciting mix of electrifying rhythms and extraordinary talent promises an evening brimming with Irish charm and enthralling entertainment, all in one powerhouse event.

Immerse yourself in a traditional Celtic landscape and let the magic of an Irish Christmas transport you to a world filled with excitement and wonder, where vibrant music and dance embody the heartbeat of the festive season.

With over one hundred and fifty 5-star Facebook reviews and over 150,000 followers, A Celtic Christmas by A Taste of Ireland promises 100% live singing and dancing as it bridges the gap between energetic folk music, Irish dance, and modern tap styles. Don’t miss your chance to see this magical show as it tours New Zealand for a strictly limited season. Get your tickets now before they sell out.

**musical instruments are subject to change from performance to performance.

SEATING LAYOUT: FULL SEATING BLOCK WITH ALLOCATED SEATING. Rows A-F of the seating block are on the flat floor so they are accessible for everyone with access needs that needs flat floor access – the tiered seating begins from row G. Please be aware if booking in rows G-R you will need to be capable of managing some stairs.

For accessibility seating information and wheelchair space bookings please email events@cdc.govt.nz or call 06 379 4081 during office hours.

description:
Artsplash: Choir, ArtSplash is a week-long festival, held every two years, that celebrates tāmariki and rangatahi experiencing performance on the big stage in dance and choir concerts. This year, we have two separate groups performing – one at ArtSplash and the other at DanceSplash.
Whaea Emilee and Mrs Skippers have an amazing Choir group training to perform on Monday 25 August at the 5pm show, held at the Michael Fowler Centre.
This group will be heading into town by 8:15am and with an action-packed day planned, will stay in town until their 5pm performance.
Following the show, our students will be ready to head home with their spectator parents. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
In the meantime, follow the link to book tickets on the Ticketmaster website– don’t miss out!

description:
BOWIE-OKE at The Last Post Restaurant & Bar, BOWIE-OKE at The Last Post Restaurant & Bar
BOWIE-OKE – David Bowie Karaoke 🎤

Calling all starmen, space oddities, and heroes (even if it’s just for one day) — it’s your time to shine! Step up to the mic and unleash your inner Ziggy.

💥 Venue: The Last Post Restaurant & Bar, 57 Fox St, Featherston RSA
💥 Date: Friday 26 September, 7.30 pm ‘til late

Dress loud, sing proud, and channel your favourite Bowie era — from glam and soul to Berlin cool or ‘90s brilliance. It’s karaoke, but make it Bowie. 🌟

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

☆ BOWIETOWN FEATHERSTON ☆
⚡Enter the Bowie universe!⚡

This September, Featherston transforms into BowieTown for the very first time – a full weekend celebrating the music, artistry, and magic of David Bowie. Expect live music, dance, creativity, food, and plenty of ways to let your inner Ziggy shine.
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1A1dp5NUzJ/

📅 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 September 2025
Featherston, Wairarapa


📍 Here’s what’s happening across the weekend 📍

⭐ Bowie-oke
Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🎤 Friday 26 Sept, 7.30 pm ‘til late
Bowie karaoke to kick things off!
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1TdhZKFpvH/


⭐ Bowie Cocktails & Desserts
Brac & Bow 🍸🍰 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 Sept
Sweet and stylish, Bowie-style.


⭐ Featherston Library Display
30 Books Recommended by Bowie 📚 Friday 26 & Saturday 27 Sept.
Discover what the Thin White Duke read.


⭐ Bowie Collage Pop-Up Craft (Family Fun)
Featherston Library 🎨 Saturday 27 Sept, 10 – 11 am.
Kids (and big kids) welcome.


⭐ Bowie Barkers Dog Party
Dorset Square 🐾 Saturday 27 Sept, 11 am.
Walk & Bark + bring/swap/donate/buy dog gear. Hosted by Madame Mutts.


⭐ Bowie Art Bash + Portrait Exhibition
ANZAC Hal l🎨 Saturday 27 Sept 1 – 3 pm
Life drawing with Bowie models (bring your own gear), $10 cash entry. Plus a Bowie Portrait Exhibition with works for sale (free entry).


⭐ Bowie Pizzas
The Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🍕 Saturday 27 Sept from 5 pm
Thin-crust Ziggy-style deliciousness!


⭐ BOWIE BLASTOFF CONCERT + AFTERPARTY
ANZAC Hall 🚀 Saturday 27 Sept 7 pm
Entry $20 (cash only, door sales)
Live performances from Mad Honey, The Davids, Taza Manaza, Tangle Dance Community, Justine Rose Kingdon, Fräulein Sylvia, and Hugo Del Mar.
Followed by the Blastoff Afterparty – put on your red shoes and dance, dance, dance to Bowie + beyond with DJ Nyx. (Alcohol-free event.)
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1GKm5wibcF/


⭐ The Davids Flashmob Dance
The Squircle (beside Featherston Fresh Choice Carpark) 💃 Sunday 28 Sept 1.30 pm.
Don’t miss this surprise Bowie moment!


⭐ Bowie Storytime with Penny Griffin
Chicken & Frog Bookshop 📖 Sunday 28 Sept, 2 pm
Bowie books read aloud for kids of all ages – with special guest star “Angus.”


⭐ Bowie Feast
At Brac & Bow 🍽️ Sunday 28 Sept 6 pm
Bowie Roast Dinners, Preprandial Bowie Cocktails, and Bowie-inspired Desserts.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

✨ Plus all weekend: check out Bowie-era books in Featherston Booktown and browse vintage Bowie bric-a-brac in local shops.


⚡ Featherston will NEVER be the SAME. Step inside the starman’s world — only at BowieTown 2025.

Sri Lankan Sports Club proudly presents Bajawwa 2025 – Wellington’s ultimate food & dance party!

Back by popular demand after last year’s sold-out success, Bajawwa is our biggest fundraising event of the year – and you won’t want to miss it.

🍴 Food Fair (from 4pm)
Get your taste buds ready! Enjoy authentic Sri Lankan flavours with kothu, short-eats, roti, wraps, biriyani, lump rice, bites & beverages.

💃 Dance Party (from 6pm)
Keep the night alive with multiple DJs spinning the best tracks for a non-stop party vibe along with live Bongos and a Saxophonist.

🎟️ Tickets

Adult: $25
Child (5–12): $10
Family (2 Adults + 2 Kids): $60

📅 Date: Saturday 20th September 2025
📍 Venue: Indian Cultural Centre, Petone

✨ Come for the food, stay for the party, and be part of an unforgettable night!

description:
Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival, Blossom Valley: Wellington's Cherry Blossom Festival
Wellington's annual spring cherry blossom festival is back this September 🌸 A must-see event with 350+ cherry blossom trees creating a sea of pink 🌸

⭐ 'After Dark' evening light experience tickets now on sale.

📷 Capture gram-worthy photos and videos under the blossoms, and find our viral style photo spots including a giant living love heart, a swing, a boat (new this year!), a giant frame, and more

🛏️ Book a night in our chalet accomodation and wake up to a sea of pink 🌸

☕ Pre-purchase a delightful high tea alongside your ticket for the full experience (bookings required)☕

Weekends often sell out so make sure you have pre-purchased tickets online to secure your car park as spaces are limited. We hate to have to turn cars away when tickets are sold out so please do pre-purchase your tickets this year for weekends!! 🚗

🌸 New This Year - Flexi Passes
This pass allows you to come on whichever day you like. Not sure about the weather or at what level of blossom the trees are then this is for you. Purchase this ticket and come during the day on whichever day and time you like. (These tickets do NOT cover the After Dark experience).

Shuttles are available from Wellington, Palmerston North, Masterton or (anywhere!) with Capital Shuttles. With bookings available from 1 person, up to a 54 seater bus, they are the ideal way to get to and from Aston Norwood Gardens 🚌

Our in house photographer Lilia will be back again offering affordable professional photography sessions - perfect for family photos, couple photos, solo, friend groups, or even secret engagements! 📷

🌸 Blossom Valley is more than an event—it’s a fleeting moment of beauty, peace, and connection with nature. We can’t wait to share it with you. 🌸

-
In 1994, inspired by visits to Japan, owners Mark and Fiona Rammell planted over 350 Sakura Cherry Blossoms and are now seeing their dream burst into life each Spring.

Blossom Valley is an annual spring celebration sure to put the spring in your step as you explore the 14 acres of garden with New Zealand’s highest number and density of mature cherry blossom trees in the one place. For just a short amount of time each year at Aston Norwood Gardens in Kaitoke, Upper Hutt, hundreds of cherry trees come alive creating a canopy of pink blossom.

The event is carefully scheduled around the natural blossoming of the trees, with data from previous years informing the date selection. While the team at Blossom Valley do their best to ensure the ultimate blossom experience the timing of the bloom is up to mother nature.
label: Festivals

description:
Bookshop Day 2025, Mark your calendars, Bookshop Day takes place on Saturday 11 October! Bookshop Day is a one-day nationwide celebration of independent bookstores, highlighting the cultural importance of books and bookshops, and the people that bring the two together, our amazing booksellers.
This year marks 10 years of Bookshop Day in Aotearoa – that’s 10 years of dress-up competitions, live music, storytimes, regional bookshop hops, author readings, spot prizes, teddy bear sleepovers, giveaways, arts and crafts, scavenger hunts, delicious baked goods, and many, many more activities and offerings!
Bookshop Day is run by the Booksellers Association of New Zealand to encourage book lovers, like you, to celebrate your local bookshop.
Head to our website to explore our Bookshop Day event calendar and see what your local bookshop has planned this year: https://www.booksellers.co.nz/bookshop-day-2025-events

description:
Carnival of Chaos, Myth, chaos, murder, alchemy, mystery, and devils are afoot in this four-night festival featuring six short retellings of classic works with strange new twists! We invite you to THEA 303’s ‘Carnival of Chaos’ in Studio 77, premiering hybrid works from the House of Echoes (1 & 3 October): The Odyssey, Medea and The Devil is a Lover, and the House of Secrets (2 & 4 October): Rope, The Taming of the Shrew  and  God’s Gift.

Each adaptation has been directed, designed, produced, choreographed and managed by the students.

House of Echoes (Season A): Performs on the 1st and the 3rd of October

The Odyssey – An adaptation of Homer’s The Odyssey
Odysseus just wants to get home to his true love, but the journey isn’t exactly smooth. The streets after 2 a.m. and too many beers are alive with obstacles; cops are grumpy, goth girls are tempting, and the help of the Gods is nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, back home, a dangerous polycule is getting cozy with his Penelope…

Medea – An adaptation of Euripides’ Medea
Medea lives her perfect 1950s white picket fence dream! When her husband starts taking new pills “Conservatol, the wonder drug for traditional love” she learns that traditional love means different to what she thought. Betrayal, hurt, and anger push her to the edge making her act in ways she never thought she would. “Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, nor Hell a fury like a woman scorned.”

The Devil is a Lover – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost and Ben Johnson’s The Devil is an Ass
Satan and two devils, Beelzebub and Pug, make a pact to travel to a 1920s speakeasy on Earth and abstain from corruption for 3 years. As the narrative combines absurdist actions with Shakespearean dialogue, the three devils quickly learn of the difficulties present in avoiding corruption and the effect their devilish meddling has on humanity.

House of Secrets (Season B): Performs on the 2nd and 4th of October

Rope – An adaptation of Patrick Hamilton’s Rope (1929)
Not a whodunnit, but a howdoyahideit? Marion and Melanie are sure they’ve committed the perfect murder by killing their friend Norman and hiding his body in a chest, a chest their select group of friends have been invited over to have a murder mystery games night around. It’s foolproof, until the over analytical Constance comes to play…

The Taming of the Shrew – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew
In 1970's Aotearoa, sisters Katherina and Bianca find their love lives complicated by their father's order that one may not pursue romance unless the other follows suit. The sudden appearance of a charming factory owner and friend of Bianca's beau could mark a new hope for the two, but will this lead to an ocean of love or does something far more sinister lurk beneath the surface?

God’s Gift – An adaptation of Ben Johnson’s The Alchemist
The Carnival has come to town in 1615 London. Lovewit has gone to see the show, leaving her manor in the hands of Jeremy the Butler, the “Alchemist,” and Dol, a hardworking prostitute. Lovewit’s house becomes a place for schemes, with ample opportunities to take money from foolish men. Will Dol be happy with her split of the money? Or will a surprise visitor shake things up?

Content Forecast: mentions of and implied sexual violence and domestic abuse, mentions of drug use, strobe lighting, violence, coarse language, loud noises, haze, and smoke.

description:
Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025, Carterton Daffodil Festival 2025
The Carterton Daffodil Festival is back for 2025!

Iconic daffodil field | Heritage train | High Street markets | Street performers | WAI ART SHOW | Library crafts + MORE... Here's a snippet of what's in store:

Your Daffodil Flyer experience (that's the train between Carterton to Masterton) has been revamped with new one-way options! Book you seat now: https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-festival-flyer/

Wander through the golden daffodils at Middle Run. Access is by free bus only – no private vehicles permitted. Pick-your-own, bunches are $5 with proceeds going to Plunket and Wellington Free Ambulance.

Enjoy music, dance, and live acts throughout the day. From main stage performances to roving entertainers, there’s something for the whole whānau.

Visit the Wai Art Show at the Events Centre and browse a wide variety of art by talented local artists. A must-see stop for art lovers and collectors.

This year, the Carterton Library will be open with simple crafts for kids, a display from the Wairarapa Herb Society, and a free talk from Aratoi about our collaborative POP-UP museum.

Te Wiki o Te Reo Māori also begins on September 14 - to celebrate we invite you to come in and browse our Māori Collection and pick up a flyer – listing 50 of our resources to help you on your te reo journey.

We can't wait to see you at one of Carterton's biggest and brightest days of the year!

Big thanks to our event sponsors; Carterton District Council, Stuff Wairarapa Times-Age, and TSC Traffic Management.

description:
Chilean Independence Day 🇨🇱🇨🇱, Chilean Independence Day 🇨🇱🇨🇱
UPDATE!!!! We’re moving the event to Sunday the 21st because of venue availability.

Vamos a celebrar este 18 de Septiembre como corresponde! ✨

Los queremos invitar a celebrar estas fiestas con la comunidad en el bowling de Seatoun.
Vamos a tener dos parrillas prendidas, juegos tradicionales (gymkana, carrera de sacos, la silla musical, una pichanga y hasta karaoke), además de música y baile pa’ que no falte el zapateo . 🎶⚽🔥
La idea es que cada uno traiga algo para la parrilla y algo rico para compartir: puede ser un postre, unas empanadas, sopaipillas, ensaladas o lo que se les ocurra. En el local se podra comprar bebestibles varios, incluso terremotos!!! 🍷🍻
Y porque no hay primera sin segunda ni segunda sin tercera… 🎉
Este año vamos a celebrar con varios panoramas:
⦁ Sábado 13 de Septiembre: celebración en el restaurant Puro Chile desde las 12pm a 7pm .

⦁ Sábado 20 de Septiembre en la noche: seguimos la fiesta en el barrio con DJ Descontrol.

⦁ Domingo 21 de Septiembre: en el bowling de Seatoun con nosotros desde 12pm.

También para los que quieran ir a apoyar y ver el show de Puku Rangi Tea (Grupo de danza de Rapa Nui) en Wellington.
⦁Martes 16/09: Performance en Scots College Wellington. FREE 7pm.
⦁Jueves 18/09: Presentacion en el musel Te Papa Tongarewa. FREE 1pm

¡Así que vengan con ganas de pasarlo chancho y celebrar juntos este 18 toda la semana!!!

Nos vemos pronto!!!!!!


Let’s celebrate this Chilean Independence day the right way! ✨

We’d like to invite you to join us for our celebration with the community at the Seatoun Bowling Club.
We’ll have two barbecues going, traditional games (gymkana, sack race, musical chairs, a friendly football match, and even karaoke), plus music and dancing so we don’t miss out on some good cueca steps. 🎶⚽🔥

The idea is that everyone brings something for the barbecue and something tasty to share: it could be a dessert, empanadas, sopaipillas, salads, or whatever you’d like. Drinks will be available for purchase at the venue, including Chile’s famous cocktail, the Terremoto.🍷🍻

And because one party is never enough… 🎉 This year we’ll be celebrating several events:

⦁Saturday, September 13th: Celebration at Puro Chile restaurant, from 12pm to 7pm.

⦁Saturday, September 20th at night: we keep the party going in El Barrio with DJ Descontrol.

⦁Sunday, 21 September at the Seatoun Bowling with us from 12 pm.

Also for those who would like to go and support and watch the show by Puku Rangi Tea (Rapa Nui Dance Group) in Wellington.
⦁Tuesday 16: Performance at Scots College Wellington. FREE 7pm.
⦁Thursday 18: Performance at the Te Papa Tongarewa Museum. FREE 1pm.

So come ready to have an amazing time and celebrate this Chilean Independence Day/Week together, not just once but several times!

See you soon. 🎉🎉🎉
label: Festivals

description:
Chillax 2026, Chillax 2026
January 16–19th. Unplug. Unwind. Unleash.

About this Event




Get ready to CHILLAX - JAN 16-19th 2026!
Unplug. Unwind. Unleash.
This January, escape the chaos and step into a world where nature, music, and good vibes rule. CHILLAX is your long weekend paradise — a four-day off-the-grid camping festival set in stunning natural surrounds.
What to Expect:
Live Music from sunrise sessions to late-night jams
Cool off with a river swim
Farm Walks to reconnect with the land
Star Gazing under skies unspoiled by city lights
And the ultimate highlight: The Tropical Lotus Bell Tent Party - a vibrant explosion of colour, rhythm, and wild tropical energy!

No WiFi. No deadlines. Just freedom, fresh air, and a whole lot of fun.
Leave your phone. Bring your soul.
CHILLAX – The name says it all.

Our Chillax Festival gets better each year with the support of our wider Chilled whānau, it grows, matures, blossoms and develops into something new and exciting. We can't wait to see where this journey takes us next.
Without all your support, we wouldn't be able to add little extras each year - so THANK YOU ❤

Our Mission:
At the Chillax Festival, we provide a platform for new up and coming artists to present themselves and grow confidence in front of a friendly non-judgmental group of Chilled Kiwis! To bring happiness and enjoyment, surrounded by the beautiful nature our country has to offer, while focusing on sustainable, safe, chilled events.
Stansborough is a beautiful hidden farm, encompassing 2300 acres of hills, valleys, swimming holes and bush. At the Chillax Festival you can forget the rest of the world exists and leave all your worries behind.
Come for the day or stay the entire weekend it is up to you.
____________________________________________________________________________________________________



Enjoy live music over the long weekend from our 2026 Muso line up!
Our 2026 line up and onsite food options, will be confirmed 3 months prior to the event.
All ticket holders will be notified and kept up to date with all new information.
Here is a snaek peak of what we can confirm!...
Our 2026 Newest Guest Artist is "Raia"
Based in Palmerston North, Raia is a young, confident artist with an amazingly pure voice. By far our youngest performer yet, she has a voice and stage presence that far exceeds her age. Raia performs covers and original songs - both contemporary and old school - layering smooth vocals and charming arrangements across everything she does. Raia is excited to bring her artistry and love of music to this years Chillax Festival.
Our guest band for 2025 'The Archer Project' loved it as much as we loved them - so they are definately coming back!
Of course we will also have some of our other favourites returing! ____________________________________________________________________________________________________


ITINERARY


FRIDAY -

If you are extra keen to make the most of the whole weekend, why not join us on Friday. Arrive from midday and once you are set up you can enjoy the scenery, explore the lake and bush valleys, swim in the river, walk the hills and tracks or climb to the top and see the sea. Wind up the evening with some good company chilling in the barn.



SATURDAY - Event day #1


If you're not already enjoying our company, arrive anytime, pitch your tent, or simply park your car, familiarise yourself with the surroundings.

Live music throughout the day from a range of artists and mixed bands - some regular favourites and some new amazing talent! Maybe even some surprises for the kids.


We have another food truck attending this year, so bring cash if you want a break from the BBQ! Our wonderful friends from Sajitarian IceCreams will be selling their amazing Ice Creams, so bring cash and don't miss out!


This year the main tent will be open for everyone to enjoy throughout the weekend. I great place to relax, sit quietly and get out of the sun.

Saturday evening you can enjoy our CHILLAX tent party - 2026 is 'TROPICAL THEME' so don't forget your Hawaiian shirts and Tropical skirts!


After dark make sure you get in some amazing star gazing in our beautiful dark sky zone!



SUNDAY - Event day #2

Another chillaxed day with plenty of live music from bands.


Appreciate the beautiful rural setting, take a gentle stroll or a hike to the top of the hill to see the sea or simply chill out by the river in the sun with friends. Play a game and listen to music - the choice is yours. How about an evening Comedy Fest in the tent?!


MONDAY - Wellington Anniversary

Appreciate the beautiful rural setting, take a gentle stroll or a hike to the top of the hill to see the sea or simply chill out by the river in the sun with friends. Pack up when you are ready and then we look forward to seeing you all next year!

____________________________________________________________________________________________________

Parking will be provided by the camp site. Once you are set up you can enjoy the scenery, explore the lake and bush valleys, swim in the river, walk the hills and tracks or climb to the top to see the sea.
Fridges in the cottage will be available, so you can put your (clearly named) food in them to store. You may want to bring a chilli bin and ice for beverages.
For lunch and dinner on Saturday, the BBQs will be back for everyone to use. We are also trying to lock in a food truck to add a bit of variety for everyone, so bring your cash so you dont miss out!


WHAT YOUR TICKET INCLUDES
A line up of Live Entertainment over the long weekend by a variety of live singers, musicians and music under the stars.
Use of toilets (Tidy Eco toilet units with solar lights)
Use of BBQs and shared fridges and cash food truck options!
An amazing chilled weekend or day out and the additional option of off-the-grid camping on a beautiful private secret site in the Wairarapa!
Live music, great company, laughter and good memories!
____________________________________________________________________________________________________
Tickets to each consecutive event, will be offered first to those who attended the event previous, so be one of the first so you don’t miss out.
'Ms Magnifique Events' are invitation only and limited numbers are limited so don't miss out. This enables us to keep these events special, exclusive, desirable and personal.
If due to weather the festival must be cancelled, there will be a postponement date or the choice for a refund (minus a small admin fee). All funds are held by Eventbrite until the event date incase of cancellation and refunds.


WHAT TO BRING
Enough food for your group for the duration of your stay or money for onsite food options. There are NO shops close (only a very handy and exceptional cafe 10 mins drive away - but you will need to check opening hours!) You need to make sure you do not run out of food, drinks and WATER. We will have some spring water available which is ok for drinking, but most people prefer to bring bottled water.

BYO drinks and water
Eating and cooking utensils (plates, bowls, cups, cutlery etc)
Cash - for onsite food options
Tent, sleeping bag, pillow and bedroll (if you want one) - If you have a camper van or pop up you are also welcome to bring them.
Togs and towel for river swimming - 3 great swimming holes to choose from
Insect repellant, sun block and antihistamine
Happiness, laughter and awesome dance moves
Please bring bottled water if possible (we don’t suggest drinking the river water)
Torches (there is no power at the camp site so once it’s dark it is super dark! Unpolluted night skies with loads of stars and satellites)
Oh and don't forget, again......BYO water!


IMPORTANT INFO
Notes:
NO POWER at camp site.
NO CELL COVERAGE OR INTERNET (unless you climb to the top of the hill/mountain or visit the local cafe)
NO PETS (as there will be farm stock around)
ABSOLUTELY NO SMOKING (we don’t want to start a bush fire, and you would unfortunately be liable)
POP UPS OR CAMPER VANS are ok, but please note there is no power or waste dumping available.

Closest 'Homewood Storeroom Cafe' 10 minutes drive down gravel road (we suggest you check opening hours) - a great cafe!
Closest basic shop - Riversdale (30 minutes on gravel road )
Closest supermarket - Carterton
Last petrol station: Carterton (we suggest you fill up there)
2 hours drive from Wellington (last 20mins on gravel road)
Exact address on google search ’Stansborough farm cottage’ Kaiwhata valley road, last 20 minutes is gravel. We will put ribbons up along the way for you to watch out for, so you know you're heading the right way.
There is an emergency phone at the farm house.
Make sure to grab a map of the property (will be provided on arrival) which highlights points of interest on the property.


Responsibilities:
Parents are solely responsible for their children at all times. Adults are responsible for themselves at all times, especially if drinking alcohol! Be aware the property and site of the event, is a working farm and there are hazards all around (rivers, lakes, cliffs, valleys and animals) so be careful and responsible.
The nearest medical facility is 50 minutes drive away.
When guests leave, we ask that you please take all your own rubbish with you and leave behind only flattened grass and the site as you found it.
If you are purchasing a Festival Day Pass only you will need a designated driver if any alcohol is consumed. The road to the venue is tricky and gravel in part. We DO NOT recommend anyone drives that has consumed any alcohol or is tired.

Click here to see videos and images from Chillax 2025:
https://photos.app.goo.gl/M25bpTPRvS3mfP45A

description:
ChoctoberFest, Porirua is the home of New Zealand’s favourite chocolate — Whittaker's. So it's only fitting it has a festival celebrating all things chocolate. During September and October, the city is serving up a range of tasty treats for ChoctoberFest, all featuring Whittaker’s chocolate.
More than 30 local businesses will be competing in the Whittaker’s Bake Off and Top of the Chocs. Head in to participating spots, and try unique chocolate drinks and amazing baked goods. You can then vote for your favourites.
Indulge your tastebuds and try special drinks such as a whipped white choc biscoff latte, or a coldbrew shot choc maltini. For a sweet snack, how about a molten embrace, kunafa chocolate croissant, or a banoffee flossy pie? There are plenty of options for all chocolate lovers, including vegan and gluten free items.
As well as voting for your favourite items, you can join the fan club, share reviews, and be in to win. Up for grabs are 100 Whittaker’s Peanut Slabs, an exclusive tour of the Whittaker’s factory, and ChoctoberFest vouchers for local cafes and bars.
The festival has been running since 2022, and is a highlight of the local hospitality scene.

description:
Courtenay Carnival - The Biggest Dress Up Party in the Universe, Wellington’s most electric street celebration is back! The Courtenay Carnival transforms Courtenay Place into a dazzling hub of music, food, dance, and community spirit. From day to night, experience an unforgettable fusion of live performances, street eats, parades, and cultural showcases—all in the heart of the capital’s entertainment district.
What to Expect
Live Stages & Street Performers – From DJs to drumlines, salsa to soul, and everything in between, Courtenay Place bursts with energy. Expect a vibrant mix of circus performers, roaming comedy acts, drag artistry, and pop-up surprises throughout the precinct.
Entertainment Lineup
• Kids Disco – A fun, high-energy dance zone for tamariki.
• Circus & Comedy Acts – Jugglers, acrobats, and comedians bringing laughter and spectacle.
• Drag Performances – Bold, colourful, and high-impact performances lighting up the street.
• Wellington Batucada – The iconic Brazilian drum ensemble leading parades and igniting the crowd.
• Startime Band – Feel-good party classics to get everyone dancing.
• Love Shack – A crowd favourite delivering big vibes and nostalgic bangers.
• Saxy Time – Bringing funky grooves and late-night energy to keep the party pumping.
Food, Flavour & Street Eats – Local venues spill out onto the street with special menus, pop-up tastings, and signature Wellington flavours. From quick bites to sit-down favourites, there’s something for everyone.
Parades & Cultural Showcases – Experience vibrant cultural performances, community groups, dancers, and musicians celebrating the diversity of Pōneke.
Family-Friendly Zones – With entertainment for all ages, Courtenay Carnival is designed to keep families engaged from day to night.

description:
Courtenay Carnival, Celebrate Wellington’s unique spirit at a big New Year’s Eve party in the city’s entertainment district. Courtenay Carnival is set to bring thousands together for a vibrant, free, family-friendly celebration in the heart of the city. This year, Courtenay Place, Allen Street, and Blair Street will be closed from 6 am on 31 December until 6 am on 1 January 2026, creating space for a street party with live music, colour, and community energy. 
The New Year’s Eve event will feature a dynamic entertainment lineup across multiple stages, showcasing exciting performers from Aotearoa. Headline acts include Indigenous rockers Bitterly Divine, afrobeat/jazz dance collective Star Time, party legends Loveshack, and late-night brass band Saxy Time. Local favourites Wellington Batucada and Estudio de Samba Wellington bring big rhythm and colour. Drag artists, circus performers, entertainment for kids, and MC Mamaeroa Munn (Mo) keep the energy high all night. 
Enjoy delicious food and drinks from local venues at Eat Street, soak up the vibrant atmosphere, and join thousands of Wellingtonians counting down to 2026 together.

description:
Daffodil Express 2025, Daffodil Express 2025
Carterton’s Daffodil Festival in the early Spring creates a great day out for the whole family. Why not travel there in style by a heritage train, let Steam Incorporated take the stress out of travel as you take the train to the Wairarapa. This year, our train has reduced capacity, so be sure to book in quickly!

Hauled by our heritage locomotives, take a glimpse into the bygone era of train travel as we clear the rush of Wellington, racing through the suburbs of Petone, Lower Hutt & Upper Hutt. After picking up the last of our passengers at Upper Hutt, we will race through the 8.8km long Rimutaka tunnel. This tunnel remains the longest in New Zealand with scheduled passenger trains, and has just been subjected to a full track relay for the first time since it was opened in 1955.

Passing through Featherston, we head east and navigate the rolling hills towards Carterton.

Arriving into Carterton, you'll have a few hours to disembark and go and explore Carterton's annual Daffodil Festival , before jumping on the train for the return journey home.

The Daffodil Fields and Festival
Located in the heart of the Wairarapa, Carterton’s popular Daffodil Festival offers an abundance of activities ranging from the famous Daffodil picking at Middlerun Farm, markets along High and Holloway Streets, the Big Wai Art sale in the events Centre, live music, and loads more family fun.

Shuttle buses will run from the town centre to the daffodil fields. There will be a lot of people for these buses, so please be patient. The bus transfer is free.

Here you can pick your own daffodils for $5 (Cash Preferred) that is a fundraiser for Wellington Free Ambulance and Whānau Āwhina Plunket, Wairarapa region. While stocks last!

The fields are not suitable for walkers or wheelchairs due to uneven grounds.

Prior booking is essential, this is an annual sell out event!

Fares
Adult (13+) - $125
Child (2-12yrs) - $90
Infant - Free

For more information & tickets, head to https://steaminc.org.nz/book-train-trip/daffodil-express/

This is a new venue for the show, what a treat! This group will be heading into town by 8:15am for the dress rehearsal, before returning to school to catch their breath. They’ll head back in together on the bus and will be ready to head home with their spectator parents at the conclusion of the show. Watch this space for more details and how you can help.
Tickets are now on sale. You can purchase them via the Ticketmaster website. NOTE: Due to limited seating and a high number of schools involved, there is a limit of TWO tickets per performer. Don’t miss out!

About this Event

Welcome to the Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration at AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing! Join us for a vibrant and colorful event filled with traditional live music, storytelling, rituals for remembering the dead and delicious prehispanic Mexican cacao drink. The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

description:
Dia de los Muertos - Day of the Dead Celebration with Claudio Escutia, Dia de los Muertos - Day of the Dead Celebration with Claudio Escutia
Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

About the Day of the Dead
The Day of the Dead tradition dates back to pre-Hispanic times, when a tribute was paid to death; the tribute took place from the last week of October to the first days of November.

Prehispanic Mexicans conceived Death as the beginning of the journey to Mictlán (the Place of the Dead), during which the soul of the deceased had to overcome various obstacles before reaching Mictlantecuhtli (the Lord of the Dead) and Mictecacíhuatl (the Lady of the Dead). Upon reaching the gods of Mictlán, an offering had to be made to them in order to obtain eternal rest.

What to Expect
Claudio will explain why it is important to celebrate and take the time to honour and remember the members of your family, ancestors and loved ones who have passed away. He will also explain the mysticism and spirituality around the Day of the Dead celebration.

We’ll also learn how to set up your ofrenda, or altar, and which elements are important for it (as well their meaning).

It's very common for an ofrenda of the dead to be placed inside Mexican homes, decorated with papel picado, food, traditional sweets, and photos of loved ones. Candles and marigold flowers are also placed as a sign of welcome for our loved ones.

Feel free to bring photos of your beloved ones that have passed away, fruits and flowers for the altar and anything that your beloved ones valued / loved when they were here with us. We will place those on the altar.

The Evening’s Schedule
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

Details
When: Saturday 1 November, 7pm -9pm

Where: AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing - Level 2, 15 Johnston Street, Wellington CBD.

Investment: $55 (first 5 enrolments - $45!); Children under 16 years old - $35

Haere Mai!
Everyone is welcome including kids (see special pricing). No previous experience or knowledge is required. As this is an evening of learning and exploration, come wearing comfortable clothing! Bring an open heart and mind willing to learn and receive.

description:
Diwali Festival of Lights, Diwali Festival of Lights is an exciting cultural celebration with fun activities for the whole whānau . Experience the colours, tastes, and sounds of India and South-East Asia. TSB Arena and Shed 6 will host a variety of performances and plenty of activities to keep you entertained. Take part in henna painting and lantern-making. Feast on delicious regional cuisine, explore Indian fashion and jewellery, and meet local community groups. Most importantly, enjoy this important and joyous festival. 
At the end of the night, enjoy the fireworks show as the event goes out with a bang. The fireworks display will start at approximately 8:50pm on Wellington Harbour (weather dependent). 
Diwali is a significant annual festival that marks the triumph of light over darkness, good over evil, and knowledge over ignorance. It is celebrated by Hindus, Sikhs, and Jains in communities all over the world. It’s marked with candles, lanterns, and fireworks. It is also known as Deepavali and is one of India’s most widely-celebrated holidays.

description:
Eastbourne Garden Show, Step into a world of six acclaimed private gardens each a living canvas of colour, design and inspiration from lush natives to sculpted landscapes. Each garden tells a story and provides a visual image of wonderful creations.
One garden, allegedly with the best vista, has not been opened to the public before. One garden has previously featured in the House and Garden magazine. The tour (self-guided) will begin with lunch and an opportunity to buy potted plants in the tranquil St Alban's church garden, 11 Ngaio St Eastbourne, Lower Hutt, Wellington. The tour will end with hors d'oeuvre, wine and live music in the last garden.
This is a chance not just to visit amazing gardens but support the earthquake strengthening of St Alban's historic church and hall for a rejuvenated community hub.
St Albans church garden
The six private gardens all lie within a less than 100 m walk of the 83 Metlink Marine Parade bus route, but a car or bicycle would be more convenient.
A glimpse of the six separate gardens (a-e).
a
a
b
c
d
e
f
f
The garden show is in support of earthquake strengthening of the de Jersey Clere designed St Alban's church and adjacent hall to remake this a community hub.
For the last hundred years and more, this beautiful church designed by acclaimed architect Frederick de Jersey Clere has been the heart of Anglican parish life for people in the eastern bays of Wellington. People have rejoiced, prayed and wept in it through happy family milestones and sad occasions, through two world wars and countless celebrations and crises. Along with its parish hall and tranquil garden, it has been the base for social and community services and outreach, and its memorial wall houses the ashes of local residents.
But in 2016 the congregation had to suddenly leave the church, which was deemed an earthquake risk.
Since then, the parish has explored alternatives for continuing its life and service to the people of the eastern bays. In that process it has kept its ministry and worship going through borrowed premises in local schools and other churches. Now, however, the parish has decided it needs to go back to its original base and strengthen both St Alban’s Church and the parish hall so it can continue to serve the community from its heart and home in Ngaio Street, for the next hundred years and more.
Detailed plans for strengthening the church and hall to meet acceptable safety standards have been drawn up, and fund-raising is under way. The parish is a registered charity (CC22188) and tax-deductible receipts will be issued for all donations.
Postponement by 1 day to 30 Nov if weather were to dictate and would be announced on this web site.

Tuesday , 2 September 2025
Doors open: 4:30 PM | Performance begins: 5:15 PM sharp
Hunter Council Chamber, Hunter Building, Kelburn Parade, Wellington
Free Entry | All Welcome
In celebration of 80 years of Vietnam’s National Day (2/9), join us for a powerful evening of music, memory, and connection.
Through traditional and contemporary Vietnamese songs, Echoes of Home takes you on a heartfelt journey — honouring the past, embracing the present, and looking to the future. Performed by a diverse group of community members, this special event celebrates identity, culture, and the spirit of resilience.
What to expect:
• A beautifully curated musical programme honouring Vietnam’s story
• Performances of folk and modern Vietnamese music
• Dance, piano, harp, pipa, guitar, and more
• Multilingual storytelling to connect all audiences
• A welcoming, cross-cultural experience for all backgrounds

description:
Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time, Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time
An emotional musical journey that brings us back to childhood memories and the timeless charm of traditional Vietnamese melodies

About this Event

Event Information
Some days remind us who we are and where we come from — when an entire nation moves as one to honour Independence.
To celebrate the 80th Anniversary of Vietnam’s National Day (2 September), Viet Hub NZ proudly presents
“Echoes of Home – A Musical Across Time”

This free concert is a heartfelt journey through the sounds of Vietnamese history — from nostalgic childhood songs to powerful wartime ballads and modern melodies of pride and hope. All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.
Whether you’re Vietnamese or simply curious about a different culture, this is a wonderful opportunity to experience the warmth, resilience, and beauty of Vietnam through music and storytelling.



🎁 Raffle with Over $300 in Prizes
Don’t miss our special raffle on the day. Tickets will be available at the venue for $5 and $10. Payment can be made in cash or by bank transfer.

This event is free to attend, but if you believe in what we do and want to help us continue running community workshops, cultural events, and youth-led initiatives — please consider making a donation.

description:
FRUIT LOOP FESTIVAL, Fruit Loop Festival
Marlborough’s freshest music festival!
About the Festival
Fruit Loop Festival is Marlborough’s juiciest new summer gig! A full-blown celebration of music and dance, kicking off under the sun and well into the night. Think open-air energy - blending Marlborough's summer magic with a full-scale music festival. An insane line-up of DJs and live performers with production to match! From the first drop to the final track, it's where the beat hits harder and the drinks taste sweeter.
Fresh, wild, fierce - Fruit Loop is the party Marlborough has been waiting for.
The Line-Up
DICK JOHNSON: The heart of NZ’s electronic scene, Dick Johnson is a true house music heavyweight. With remixes for global icons like Fatboy Slim and Claude VonStroke, plus Kiwi favourites L.A.B and Tiki Taane, he’s spent over two decades electrifying dancefloors worldwide. A relentless force behind the decks - and music director for Synthony - Dick brings the fire every time.
SIN: Co-host of George FM Drive, Sin is plugged into the pulse of the dance scene and has quickly become a revered authority on all things electronica. She’s torn up stages at Rhythm & Vines, Homegrown, Hidden Valley, and international festivals from Fiji to the UK. With supports for legends like Fatboy Slim, Groove Armada, and Netsky, Sin brings high-energy house, techno, and ravey curveballs to every set.
KITA MEAN: Kita Mean is New Zealand’s award-winning drag superstar, known for her infectious charm, razor-sharp wit, and high-camp aesthetic. With a career spanning 15+ years across stages and screens worldwide, she’s wowed audiences from Aotearoa and Australia to London, Canada, the USA, and beyond. Winner of the very first RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and co-owner of the iconic Caluzzi Cabaret, Kita continues to dazzle with colourful looks, flawless mug, and hilarious timing. Quirky, kooky, kitsch, and quick - Kita Mean isn’t just a queen, she’s an experience.
PETE GREEN: Originally from the UK, Pete is part of the vinyl-digging collective Rare Specimens. His love for deep, worldly electronic sounds brings low-end warmth and an infectious energy to the dancefloor. Along the way, he’s supported artists such as Crazy P, Psychemagik, Audio Jack, and Christopher Tubbs, playing festivals and parties from Creamfields and Rhythm & Alps to Tempo Schmempo. Expect a set seasoned with Italo, ambient, and deep house flavours, dusted with disco, and finished with a splash of techno.
Event Details
Date: Saturday 28 March 2026
Time: 2pm - 10pm
Location: The Fancy Cow, Marlborough
R18 event - Photo identification will be required.
Return Bus Service:
Getting to and from the festival is easy with our return bus service. Pick-up points will include Redwoodtown Woolworths, Seymour Square, and Countdown Springlands. Purchase a return bus ticket when you nab your ticket.
A full timetable and bus information will be announced closer to the event.
Parking is strictly limited at the festival. Drop off recommended.
Tickets
Tickets are limited — don’t wait. Secure yours now!
Door sales may be available.
Have your ticket open and ready to be scanned at the gate.
Kaupapa
Fruit Loop is a safe, inclusive space where everyone belongs. If you can’t celebrate diversity, respect others, and bring good vibes, this festival isn’t for you.
Harassment or discrimination of any kind will not be tolerated. Anyone behaving this way will be removed.
Refunds and Cancellations
Fruit Loop Festival is a rain or shine event. The festival will proceed regardless of weather conditions, except in circumstances where safety is compromised or conditions make it impossible for the event to continue.
No refunds will be given for changes to the programme, line-up, or advertised performers.
Stay Connected
Follow us for line-up drops, updates and key event information: @fruitloopfestival on Instagram

description:
Family Grave Day 2025 - Wellington, Family Grave Day 2025 - Wellington
The world’s biggest family-friendly rave just got haunted… and Wellington, we’re coming for YOU! 👻

This is not your average Halloween party – it’s a full-blown Halloween rave for the whole family, packed with banging beats, dazzling performers, and spooky surprises at every turn. Whether you’re a mini-monster or a grown-up ghoul, get ready for an afternoon of music, mayhem, and memories you’ll never forget. Costumes are highly encouraged – the more outrageous, the better!

Date & Time: Saturday 15th November, 1PM – 4PM
Location The Hunter Lounge

🎟 Tickets
First Release - SOLD OUT!
Second Release - ON SALE NOW

👉 https://megatix.com.au/events/FGDWELL25


👻 WHAT TO EXPECT:

🧛‍♀️ All-Ages Family Rave – Dress to impress in your spookiest costumes for maximum Halloween fun!

🏢 Prime City Venue – The Hunter Lounge is easy to get to with great parking and public transport links.

🎶 Club DJs & Performers – International DJs dropping trance, techno & nostalgic bangers, plus stilt walkers, jugglers, and spine-tingling roaming performers!

🔇 Silent Disco & Sensory Zone – Pop on your headphones and dance in spooky silence, or chill out in our sensory space.

🕷️ Spooky Interactive Fun – Inflatables, Halloween-themed games, arts & crafts, face painting, and more!

🍕 Frightfully Good Food – Delicious restaurant meals available onsite to keep the ghouls fed.

🥂 Adult Beverages Available – Enjoy a drink while the kids rave (responsibly, of course).

💀 Immersive Halloween Atmosphere – Expect haunted lighting, eerie decor, and special effects that’ll transport you to the other side.

🧙‍♀️ Giveaways & Surprises – Don’t miss your chance to rave beyond the grave… and win!

⚡ Spots are limited – secure your tickets before they vanish into the night! ⚡

description:
Folk in the Vines 2025 - December 6th, Join us for an afternoon of music and wine. We invite you to bring your own picnic food, pre-order one of Le Grá’s delish platters (pictured below) with your ticket or decide on the day. Our caravan bar will be set up for all beverage needs – Le Grá wines, cocktails, a selection of beers, ciders and non-alcoholic sodas. No BYO drinks please.

And for the music!

Kyan – a local lad who is making his place in the music world. He and his band took out the ‘next in line’ annual music event in Otepoti. He’ll be playing as a solo act for us with some of his original music and covers.

Another local and one of our absolute favourites, Michael Krishnan Jones, will keep toes a-tapping with his acoustic guitar and legendary voice. From his Johnny Cash impression known throughout the land, expect folky covers from the 60’s through to the present day, Scott McKenzie through to George Ezra. We love Mike!

And to take us home – The Noodles. Based in Wellington and the Wairarapa, and entertaining us for the last 20 years, the Noodles are one of the most selected cover bands, so get ready to Party with The Noodles! They promise to serve up a high-energy blend of Rock, Pop, and Party anthems, guaranteed to get you moving and singing along. With their infectious energy, tight musicianship and catchy hooks, The Noodles are a perfect recipe for our afternoon of fun in the sun.

description:
For Singing's sake Festival, Join community choirs from the Wellington region for a day of singing, sharing, and learning , all while having fun getting to know each other. Experience the magic of mass singing and the energy of performing for and cheering each other. Our song leaders for the inaugural year of this Festival are Susie Hardie (Hutt Valley Community Choir, Andrea Robinson (Khandallah Singers), and Lala Simpson (Wellington Community Choir and Kotaba Voices). We will start the day as a mass choir to learn 3 songs for our combined performance, then in the afternoon we will present a FREE public concert featuring each choir and our mass choir. We are looking forward to singing with you!
Please bring: a drink bottle, keep cups, comfortable clothing for rehearsals, performance attire for the concert, and your own lunch.
Schedule for the day:
10 am -arrivals and first combined rehearsal 
11:00- morning tea break (provided)
11:15 – Combined rehearsal (sectional)
11:40– combined rehearsal
12:30– lunch (Please bring your own)
1:00 – combined rehearsal and individual choirs practice getting on and off stage
2:00- break
2:30 – concert begins
4:00 – finish

description:
Gallop Into the New Year: Lunar Celebrations in the Hutt, Gallop Into the New Year: Lunar Celebrations in the Hutt 🐎
Proudly sponsored by Hutt City Council
📍 Dowse Square & Lower Hutt Town Hall
📅 Saturday, 31 January 2026
🕚 11:00 AM – 4:00 PM
Join us for a colourful, family-friendly Lunar New Year Festival in the heart of Lower Hutt!
Organised by Viet Hub NZ and proudly sponsored by Hutt City Council, this outdoor cultural festival celebrates not only Vietnamese Tết but also embraces wider Lunar New Year traditions from diverse communities across Aotearoa.
Let’s gallop into the Year of the Horse together through music, food, stories, and joyful celebration!
🎭 What to Expect:
Outdoor Cultural Market: Featuring authentic street food, handmade crafts, and local community stalls
Live Stage Performances: Lion dance, drumming, cultural dances, and musical acts throughout the day
Cultural Games & Crafts: Hands-on activities like calligraphy, lantern making, and Vietnamese folk games
Storytelling Exhibition: An indoor showcase of migration stories, heritage, and identity from local residents
Traditional Costume Photo Corner: Indoor area to take photos in Vietnamese and cultural New Year outfits
Family Fun: Face painting, interactive workshops, lucky draws, and more.
🎟️ Tickets:
Free General Admission – Register to stay updated and be entered in giveaways
Optional Donation – Help us grow this community-led festival and support ongoing Viet Hub NZ programme
💛 Why You Should Come:
This is Lower Hutt’s largest, most inclusive Lunar New Year celebration, designed for all ages and backgrounds. Whether you’re reconnecting with your heritage or discovering new traditions — everyone is welcome.
📢 Stay Connected:
Follow us on Facebook or visit www.viethubnz.org
📧 Contact us: hello@viethubnz.org
🫶 This event is made possible thanks to the generous support of Hutt City Council and our amazing volunteers, artists, and community partners.

description:
Gardens Magic, The Wellington summer nights just got warmer with the return of Gardens Magic. The capital’s talented musicians are on full display across January. The annual event, brought by Wellington City Council, presents a series of free concerts in the Botanic Garden Soundshell. 
Each year, a huge range of music genres is represented across three weeks. Choose from rock, folk, country and western, soul, jazz, pop, reggae and many more. Come early to grab a good picnic spot and sit back and enjoy the show with the whanau or a group of friends. Prolong your stay in the gardens by exploring the evening light display afterwards. The pathways near the Soundshell will be colourfully illuminated between 9 and 10:30pm every evening. During the day, the Botanic Gardens host a Kids Garden Trail and Kids Explorer Days. 
See the full 2026 programme online and keep an eye out for rain day announcements. This is your chance to join in on a beloved local tradition.

Gindulgence Wellington 2026!, Gindulgence Wellington 2026!
Welcome to New Zealand’s most celebrated boutique gin festival. NOW FEATURING rum, whisky, vodka, liqueurs and other spirits!

On offer is a fantastic line-up of 20 distillers showcasing a fabulous selection of 90+ gins and other spirits from New Zealand and around the world.

Don't miss this afternoon experience of gin-on-the-lawn at the new location of WAITANGI PARK.
